comments.comment_body: The last candidate standing will be Bloomberg.

Former Democrat, now independent and the answer to your question, "If your preferred candidate doesn’t win the nomination, will you still do everything you can to deny Trump a second term?"

Yes, I will.

This column is an echo things I said, over and over, in 2016.  They didn't matter to the people who needed to hear them; people who said things like "the lesser of two evils is still evil," and "vote your conscience; that's all that matters."  Those people gave us Trump.

And yet, here I am, feeling the same way.  I've only voted for Democrats since I could vote, but I'm not pulling the lever for Bernie.  I did my duty in 2016; let's see if Bernie really can come up with a "political revolution" to replace me and all of the other moderates he's repelling.

If someone has already posted a version of the following, I apologize:  Republicans will vote FOR a candidate they dislike because of one issue (abortion and Supreme Court nominees being the biggies).  Democrats will vote AGAINST a candidate because of one issue, one characteristic, or even one vote from twenty years ago.  This is the quest for @GWE's unicorn and it's truly frightening.
I will vote for any democrat except Bloomberg. If Bloomberg is the nominee, I will vote third party.

The best explanation of Social Democracy I have seen came from Fintan O'Toole, and can be found on You Tube.  Bernie believes in a free capitalist society balanced by social democracy and rules for those who would destroy our civilized society for their own personal gain at the cost of everyone else.  The fascists moved in when we failed to address the people left behind.  Bernie is trying to address their needs and lift their fears so we can have a balanced society again.

Someone has to somehow make sure the 18 - 30 year olds vote.  They will bear the brunt of the horrible man in the White House and the treasonous members of the Senate who are selling their futures down the river.   Nothing matters more than their vote.  If they vote, they save themselves and their children.  If they don’t vote their lives will be very adversely affected.  The ads need to be directed to them showing their lives in 5 - 10 years with 4 more years of t.  The ads need to be on their social media devices.   They need to know and they need to be afraid.   Get to work DNC!

I'll vote a straight Democratic ticket as I have in every election since I was old enough to vote.  I'm afraid the upcoming election will be the last, that the dictator who has seized our poor country by the throat will never let go.

Seeing people like Tlaib booing a loyal Democrat and seeing a non-Democrat using the Democratic Party again to advance his own vicious cult is horrible. The other candidates seem determined to hand what's left of the country to Trump.  Weaklings.  Lewzers.

The only hope is Bloomberg.  He will do what needs to be done.

My fellow Americans,

1. Donald Trump is a clear and present danger to the very American Experiment itself.

2. We must end Trumpism, and we must end the current G.O.P. that supports him blindly, like Jim Jones' kool-aid drinkers in Guyana.

3. This is not your father's Republican Party. This is a doomsday cult. And it must end. Now.

Vote blue. No matter who.
November 3.

Dear Democrats,

A half a loaf is better than no loaf.
And anything is better than four more years of Donald Trump.

Vote your conscience in the primary.
And then vote blue, no matter who, on November 3.
I will vote straight ticket Blue no matter who.
Thank you, Mr Leonhardt. We all need to remind one another of this truth over and over: our Republic can endure nearly anything, but it will not endure the re-election of Donald John Trump.

The progressive voters fail to see that the big, bold ideas of their candidates stand zero chance of being enacted if the Republicans and McConnell control the Senate. They fail to see that the majority of the electoral college doesn't support the ideas their candidate espouses. They fail to see independent (not Democrat) Bernie's shouting at people about inequalities alienates those that disagree with him. Progressives need to listen to James Carville..  "Eighteen percent of the country elects more than half of our senators. That’s the deal, fair or not. So long as [Mitch] McConnell runs the Senate, it’s game over. There’s no chance we’ll change the courts, and nothing will happen. The purpose of a political party is to acquire power. All right? Without power, nothing matters."

I’m 65 and a life long Democratic. There is no way that Bernie Sanders will beat Trump. While I admire the young people who support Bernie, this election is not the time for his proposals. The majority of people my age that I know will not support him and we vote in far larger numbers then the younger people.
I couldn’t support him because of his stand on allowing felons in prison to vote and Medicare for all. I recently went on Medicare and my co-pay for one of my drugs went from $25 to $60. My premiums went from $98 to $144.
Perhaps in the near future his message will resonate but as long as he can be labeled a “socialist “ he will fail this year.

I would have a very hard time voting for Joe Biden. I honestly feel he is no longer able to handle the position of POTUS. His campaign appearances confirm that for me. If push came to shove, I would vote for him. If I'm forced to do that, I hope he has an excellent running mate so I don't feel quite so disheartened by my vote.

February 10, 2020


Yes the is great: get the best Democratic to win the election.
And as well with for all in the party to use their brilliance and purpose that lessons learned are the best remedy to staying the course for accomplishment  and earning the victory for all times. So it is not about Trump as a person but those in national character that enjoys the historic Democratic achievements now and forever.

I don't think fixation on finding a "perfect" candidate is the issue. What is detrimental is the lack of diligence in fact-finding, as demonstrated by some factions on the left.  It is exhausting to have to correct the misinformation posted in NY Times comment section.  Indeed,the fact is that Pete accepts *only* individual contributions, each capped at $2,800.  It doesn't bother me that Bernie is supported by dark money, has a network of wealthy donors (see vtdigger.org), got flagged by FEC for illegal and excess contributions in 639 pages in 2016.  It doesn't bother me that Warren got $175,000 from a wealthy doctor to purchase database from DNC, and while she doesn't do private fundraisers, her campaign treasurer and close allies do it for her.  But for someone who cares and is ready to lash out accusation at a candidate, please do due diligence.  And while most commenters here advocate "vote blue no matter who,"  some party leaders act the opposite - they are leading the misinformation campaign to tear the party apart.  For example, Pramila Jayapal, who is a surrogate of Bernie, tweeted a news article dated a year ago, ignoring the fact that Pete's campaign provide healthcare and officially acknowledge union of campaign workers.  It doesn't bother me that some factions intend to win by any means, at all cost.  But spare me the grand-standing and the talk of compassion for fellow citizens.
My sister likes Bernie.  I like Amy.  We both voted for Hilary in 2016 and will vote for the Democratic nominee in this election.

When you get down to it, moderates and progressives want to wind up in exactly the same place. Universal health care, equal treatment for people of all colors, nationalities, and gender, and the ability to support yourself and your family with a wage that doesn't have to rely on SNAP or welfare. 
Among other things.
The difference is how you get there: by a process of gradual change through compromise when necessary in the right direction or an immediate revolution with change right now.

America is blocked from needed, long-delayed progress by our system of wealthy mega donors legally allowed to dominate our campaigns, setting the standards of what's 'centrist'  or 'radical left wing'.  

Any politician who disagreed with them too strongly would not get funding to run. They fell in line. But now some candidates are using small donations from voters---that's progress. 

The big story the news media neglects ---now most voters and many politicians want to reverse Citizens United, and use more public funding for elections. This will help restore citizen influence on law making, that's been muffled by mega donors. Is that a radical idea?

 The far reaching effects of public funding---in amounts set aside in advance for both parties ideally -- could restore an operating democracy, and prevent another Trump type swamp creature from rising up to take power. 

See Feb 1-- NYT editorial written on 10th Anniversary of Citizens United.  
"More Money, More Problems for Democracy.
Countering private campaign funding with public campaign funding is the most viable way to limit the political influence of the wealthy."

Any comment, David? Boring topic, compared to Dems fighting among themselves?

What we need is a true Left party concerned exclusively with economic issues, including rigorously enforced regulation to stop ongoing discrimination against women and minorities in employment, housing, access to credit, and other benefits. But no policies on other issues, including the environment, gun control, abortion, or ‘lifestyle issues’.
I’d vote for my cat if I thought it’d get DJT out of office. He’s a very nice cat, btw. Very friendly. I’m sure he could run a great campaign.

You're never going to get a candidate whose priorities will match yours 100%. I'd like to have the policies of E. Warren as our national priorities starting next January. But any of the Dem candidates would be an improvement, and if you don't vote because you didn't get your first choice, or as a way to punish the DNC, then you're being petulant and enabling another 4 years of Trump.

The question Joe Biden needs to ask himself is:

"What will I say at the next debate when they ask me why I got Victor Shokin fired when he was investigating corruption at Hunter's company? That's gonna be a doozy - better have a prepared answer. I wonder who will ask it: Pete?"
To those who say they can’t stand Trump but will refuse to vote for Bernie:   Please dear God, you must vote against Trump even if you have to hold your nose.

Generally yes I would unless the candidate is Biden.  He is simply too senile, weak, and old - plus he seems to revel in insulting voters with weird name calling or just referring to them as 'fat' or 'too old',  Luckily it's looking like both Yang and Steyer are going to beat Biden like a drum in NH - so no need to worry.
How about, no.
Vote BLUE no matter who!

Why can't we have anti-Tump/pro Democracy rallies?  Have a few politicians from the state educate the people on what all we have lost, and what is now on the chopping block. Democrats have been derelict in communicating with their constituents.  Did you know that Medicare no longer supports home visits for housebound elderly patients? Did you know Social Security is on the chopping block to replace the money taken from the military budget to build the wall? the average person does not take the time to search for this information. Let's excite our base like Trump excites his base.  No more boring Town Halls, lets call them Celebrations. The Democrats need to wake up and change.  They need to get off of their butts. This isn't just about who is running, it is about who the candidate is running against and that should be the message.

There is no more important election than the 2020 election. Period. The Trump administration has perverted every aspect of the US Government in the last 3 years. Scan NYT articles from just this week and you'll find news that the current administration has drafted an Executive Order that all new government buildings should be built in the classical style; and also decided to punish NY residents for state government decisions by banning them from Global Entry programs. You'll learn that the Attorney General will now decide which presidential candidates can be investigated; and that he's established a backchannel with a private citizen to review information from foreign influences about one of those candidates. If we don't get these people out in November, what will the headlines in 2024 read?

A friend and I kicked around a revolutionary idea, after agreeing that, of course, the only intelligent course for the general election would be to vote to oust Trump:

Impressed, overall, by the intelligence on display during the New Hampshire debate, we thought, Whoever gets the nomination and then (we hope) wins, why not invite the others (along with Chris Christie, a brilliant mind) to become a regular, if informal, Brain Trust during the new president's first term in office?

That may sound crazy, and it may be impracticable, but if we are constrained to vote for just one president, I wouldn't mind if that president took advice regularly from a range of others of somewhat like mind--or even (in the case of Christie) of differing mind.

The Cabinet doesn't function as this sort of Brain Trust. (In the current administration, what substitutes for it is the echo chamber of Trumps.)

Could my friend's and my suggestion produce anything as bad or worse? We think not.

OF COURSE, most of us will vote for ANY Dem against Trump!  But let's admit that Trump's worst effect is to make even a mediocre Dem look like an absolute saint who will save us. 

Instead this column should discuss how the progressive agenda we badly need could be financed. Use advanced countries as role models that work---explain tax rates on citizens of various income levels and what they get for it. 

America lags other capitalist democracies, that generations ago started universal health care. And low college tuition. That's what this column neglects. 

Our legalized campaign subsidies by corporate donors have blocked  progressive policies that are centist in other democracies---also capitalist. Their govts have more respect for their citizens, with HC as a right, while US voters are exploited and manipulated. 

Many countries ban the paid campaign ads on media that inundate Americans. These are our biggest expense, needing big donors or self funding billionaires to pay for. Money calls the shots. We lose out.

In 2020 we  finally get some progressive proposals, but opposed by some Dems. But  I can't imagine any Dem or Independent voters being SO turned off by health care for all that they'd go and vote for Trump.

Will we stay 'moderate' and stuck, then wait for 2024 or 28, to again push for the Representation for our Taxation that we deserve?
Please educate voters on policy choices. We need better than 'just better than Trump'.

If the battle is between Bernie and Bloomberg—which I think it will be—the Bernie Bros will throw a fit and relegate this nation to another four years of a president who will do damage to the nation and the world that is beyond our worst nightmares. 

We need to stop battling over the small stuff—and everything except getting trump out of office is small stuff.

The remaining crop of Dem candidates is uninspiring to me.  When Joe Biden is reduced to attacking Pete B. on his lack of experience, rather than focusing on what HE will do, we’re lost.

And it’s a shame, because we had all the momentum after the 2018 mid-terms.  Those elections were issues-based, and the Dems simply out-competed the GOP.

All the candidates should return to issues Americans care about.  That list doesn’t include Trump.  And while they’re at it, put together a comprehensive plan to maintain control of the House and win back the Senate majority.  Even if Trump wins, he’ll get nothing done until we get a Dem back in the WH.

I just wish the old geezers who are trying very hard to win this nomination by attacking anyone who is having some success in the campaign would wake up (woke) and accept the fact that their time is past.  Let the leadership of the party pass on to the next generation.
I sometimes get the feeling that these folks  would rather lose to Trump than put up a candidate who might upset their 'apple cart'.  
I am obviously of the older generation.

I hope and pray that a large enough majority of Americans, throughout this country, vote for whoever the Democratic candidate is.  I will.  The nightmare of a continuation of the current situation is unbearable.  Whoever the candidate is, they must make sure that areas that Hillary disregarded are not disregarded this time around.  Unfortunately, the Electoral College can't be disregarded.  And while we're at it, hopefully the Democratic party can gain control over the Senate.  I'd like to wave good-bye to Mitch McConnell as much as wave good-bye to Trump!

Bernie or bust! None of the neoliberal centrist candidates give a wooden nickel about me or my family and I refuse to vote for them. Going to vote on the props I like, write in Eugene Debs for president, and call it a day.

Anyone who stays home or votes for a third party candidate this November is de facto voting for Trump, the GOP and an ongoing erosion of our constitutional democracy. 

Warren was my candidate early but I see the energy and base firmly behind Sanders. Scorn the will of the base and pay the consequences, just like in 2016. For this reason I have donated to Sanders but will support any one of the candidates in the general election. 

Voting for the democratic nominee, whoever they may be, is the only responsible, patriotic recourse we have.

There are many candidates still in the race for the democratic nomination but the leaders fall into two groups. Sanders and Warren are the leading progressive leftists and Biden, Buttigieg, and Klobuchar are the leading neoliberal centrists. The candidate from each group who is most likely to be victorious will become clear after South Carolina and Nevada. The two leading candidates will then face-off with billionaire Mike "I-believe-I-can-buy-the-election" Bloomberg on Super Tuesday. Then, if the leading candidate after Super Tuesday is Sanders or Warren, Bloomberg will stay in the race just to try and knock them out. If Biden, Buttigieg, or Klobuchar are in the lead, Bloomberg will hang in the race  just long enough to create doubt in the minds of the public that his only  motive for entering the race was to scuttle a win by Sanders or Warren. Then, having set up his preferred candidate for a win, he'll go back to doing whatever else billionaire manipulators do.

Getting out the vote will do more to help depose Trump than bickering about the minutiae. The 2016 election was won by about 20,000 votes in Wisconsin. Call, write postcards, write letters, etc., to democrats in swing states to convince them that it is worth their time, money, and energy to vote and/or help alert them to the fact that they can vote by mail, as was recently instituted in Florida. There are websites available that allow you to send postcards to voters (just google that phrase) or give you a simple list of phone numbers to text or call (and if the latter, mostly you just leave voicemails for people because who even answers their phone anymore?)--all just reminding them to vote. Just getting people to show up at the polls is more important than all the efforts and details about changing policies, etc. Electoral politics is only one avenue for bringing about a better world. So let's do what we can in that realm to make the most impact for the least amount of energy, and let's not confuse feeling or saying things on social media for actual action. Then let's apply our energy to making real change in other ways.

So well said. I feel like many moderates and progressives would prefer to see Trump be reelected, than to have someone who agrees with 95% of their perspectives in office. It makes no sense to me, other than as reenforcement of the idea that America has succumbed to decadence and a sense of bloated entitlement. Trump gives his supporters license to hate -- but are Trump opponents really that different, when you get right down to it? If he is reelected, it will be because we are getting what we deserve -- the end of American democracy. "A democracy... if you can keep it." I'm not so sure we can.

I'm confident that essentially all Democrats will unify behind whomever wins the nomination.  I certainly will.  A first Trump term was horrendous, I have trouble imagining a second.   But this is the moment for each of us to work for the candidate that we would prefer.  I assume electability" is part of every Democrat's calculus.   But a decent sense of humility should lead us to admit that absolutely no one knows who the most "electable" candidate is.  That, in part, is why we have a primary process.  For now, let's focus on choosing a candidate.  When we have one then it will truly be time to put the primary process behind us and elect a President to replace the caricature now sitting in Pennsylvania Avenue.

Trump's past and future actions will give responsibility to the democratic voters responsible of which person will our next president.  If you feel that corruption which comes from a system that rewards those who can raise vast amount of money to get elected, then your choices are Bernie or Elizabeth,or the progressive candidates.  If believe it is not then your choices are others. 

Since the current system benefits democrats who has the banking of millionaires and billionaires or corporate democrats, they have the resources to do whatever it takes to defeat these two.  During this election cycle, depending on primary results, they will probably switch between different candidates to defeat the progressives. 

Bernie made the progressive and inclusive America possible, Hillary made America realize that America can have a woman president, Warren's is the evolution of both thoughts.  I believe the anti-progressive movement consisting of the GOP and corporate democrats know that she is more of a threat than Bernie because has put up viable policy position on every issue.  Bernie has Sheppard the young while women should stand behind Warren, together this demographics can change America and even the world for the better.

I believe Warren is the better choice because she has demonstrated that she can compromise some of her ideas for greater good, while Bernie continue to show his stubbornness making political solutions more difficult.
We need more support from the media if we're going to win - so many outlets are giving increasingly positive coverage of Trump.

If Democrats get there act together in bringing about options for public a right choice then there is a chance. Pete Buttigieg? Really.
If he ends up in top three and even not get nominated, the Democrats have shot themselves in a foot. 
Even hard Democrat as myself will vote for Trump.

With the Republican party gone and replaced by the Trump Cult Party, all of the former-Republican moderates are wandering over to the Democratic Party like political refugees. And now the Dems have to find a way to incorporate them. Like the Electoral College, it's time to do away with our catastrophically broken two-party system. The Dem party will ultimately need to become two separate parties that reflect the former, better-functioning system we had in the first half of the twentieth century - a Leftist party and a Centrist party. At least until we can fumigate the house and rid ourselves of the poisonous TCP.

Why would someone vote for a self-proclaimed socialist candidate when they think socialism is a disaster?  

Why would someone vote for a candidate pandering on identity when they've grown sick of identity politics?  

Why would someone happy with the economy vote for a candidate who could, quite literally, cause a recession with massive change?

These are some of the more obvious reasons why, Mr. Leonhardt, why democrats may not support the nominee?

All I can say is, Amen, Right on, Mr Leonhardt. And I don't always agree with you. A friend of mine said at the beginning of this mess that we cannot afford to be purists of any ilk. As they say, "Vote Blue no matter who". Most of my Dem friends here in the Sierra foothills agree. We live in red counties, we do not want to live on a red country.

Yes, spot on!
Fight for your candidate of choice.  However, in the end Trump must not win a 2nd term!  Any of the Democratic candidates are 1000 times better than Trump.
Vote.  Don't waste your vote.  No excuses!

I've already voted for Buttigieg in early voting in Caliifornia. I also voted for every local bond measure that supported  our schools and area community college.  I'm a Boomer and I'm a progressive.
I'm a progressive that knows the only way we will win this election and avoid the possible end to our Democracy is to nominate a moderate that can win in the moderate states.
It is more than obvious that Sanders cannot win while promising to raise taxes on everyone...partially to supply free health care to anyone, including any illegal immigrant that waltzes across the border....because he basically advocates for open borders, too. 
He's also saying that the Government should take over all the companies that supply us with electricity.  That would horrify moderate voters and Trump would have a hey day pummeling him relentlessly over his goofy ideas. 
Right now, Sander's opponents are basically going easy on him and not bringing up much about his history of being very friendly to left wing dictators.  Trump and his allies will have no problem turning him into Daniel Ortega..the vicious left wing dictator of Nicaragua because Sanderson once was a devotee of Ortega. 
I'm also a progressive that supported McGovern way back in 1972 when I was young and idealistic.  We were all certain he would defeat Nixon.  He won one State and even lost his own.  Pete has great ideas, is very intelligent, and we need some fresh blood running this Country.  Vote moderate. Any moderate.
I would vote for a random GS-12 over Donald Trump.

The Democratic party has lost a huge amount of momentum by not being the adults in a closed room and narrowing the field themselves to achieve focus early on. Instead we have a bit of a circus, with more rings than anyone can focus on and a clown show in Iowa. I'm pretty sure we will put forward a mistake, someone with zero chance of appealing to those who supported Trump in the last election. Personally, I think Bloomberg could make that appeal, but I will hold my nose and throw my vote away if push comes to shove.
We're doomed if Bernie Sanders  moves into the White House  and Mitch McConnell  is still  the Republican  majority  leader.
You do realize that the answer HAS to be “yes” for virtually every registered Democrat or, given the electoral map and the moment, we’ll have 4 more years of Trump?

In a word:  No.

In more words:  I will never vote for Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren.

I'm in Ohio.  I know what my vote -- of lack of vote -- means.

I will not participate in setting the USA up for worse than Trump in 2024.

Think things can't get worse?  Remember when so many of us thought that W was the worst President in our lifetimes?  Well, he was ... until we got Trump.

So it can get worse than Trump, and if we're going to try to shove a Sanders or a Warren down all Americans' throats, it will get worse in 2024 and I will not be a part of making that happen.

You make it sound that Trump is the devil himself.  He is really not so bad. 

 Look at our economy.  It has never been better.  His approval rating is nearing 50% which means half the country is 100% with him.  Evangelicals have it right we are blessed to have such a wonderful man leading this country,  Even such past critics as Lindsey Graham have seen the light and now sing his praises,  

Give it a little more time and you will be there too.

I will vote for whoever is the nominee but I do notice a news media bias against Sanders for no good reason.  Maybe because the owners are the 1% and don't want to pay taxes?  Search for "Sanders is ahead in New Hampshire" and you get a load of articles about Mayor Pete.  Is that google gaming the system or someone gaming google searches?  Are republicans doing this?  It's very annoying and not right.

Iowa and New Hampshire in sum have only 1.1% of the US population, they get 99% of the media attention. 98.9% of us don't want the 1.1% choosing our candidate for president. How can the Iowa - New Hampshire system be more undemocratic than it is?????
I'll commit to Bernie if Larry David commits to playing Bernie on Saturday Night Live.
I want Trump out but I will never vote for Bernie Sanders.
Definitely.  Right now I'm rooting for Andrew Yang to beat Joe Biden like a drum in New Hampshire!

Three questions for the Dems. Why hasn't Mike Bloomberg purchased both the NY Mets & Knicks and hired me to coach both teams? Should Donald Trump gets free season tickets to both? - If yes, will DT be able to put up with the boos?

Let's recall the Republican primary of 1980. George H. W. Bush ran against Ronald Reagan for the nomination. Mr. Bush famously called Reagan's fiscal ideas "voodoo economics" -- a phrase* that has survived to this day.

Yet Mr. Reagan picked Bush as his running mate. And won the election.

Perhaps those on this comment board who are suggesting that the eventual nominee pick a running mate from the opposite wing of the Democratic Party are on to something.


===
* History has shown that Mr. Bush was correct. Trickle-down economics is indeed a fraud. And Mr. Bush was the last of the fiscally responsible Republicans. And he lost his re-election in 1992 in part due to this. "No new taxes. Read my lips."
Any sane adult, 2020.

Looks like the Dems will torpedo themselves, if they don't pull their act together. Infighting is unproductive and to continue spells disaster for developing a credible platform. Kids in a schoolyard.

There is a trump rally in New Hampshire tonight at 7pm (EST).  You should tune in and compare the size of the crowds to the Democratic candidate of your liking.   This comparison will give you the best overall picture of where the Democrats stand in 2020

Vote your conscience in the primary.
And then vote blue, no matter who, on November 3.

Why is Pete Buttegieg such a front runner? It's an attack on the 2020 election. I have nothing against gays . . . but Buttegieg is Trump's dream opponent. Even Democrats who voted for Buttegieg in the Iowa Primary said if they'd known Buttegieg was gay they wouldn't have voted for him. (I know, it's unbelievable they didn't know.) What about Trumpers who are sitting on the fence? The fix is already in.
Of course  I will.

Can we win no matter what we do to you?

Will you vote for any abuse at all, as long as it is us?

No. No.
Reprint this article every day between now and the election!  VOTE!
We can all make a difference.  Be sure to mark your calendar for November 4, 2020 and charge with enthusiasm to you nearest polling location and cast the vote that will be heard across America!!!
Any Functioning Adult 2020

American voters are probably the dumbest and most gullible on the planet. They are always fooled by the rich who put up one candidate on each side and present them with a "choice". 
That is the state of the fake American "democracy" so much touted by the news media.
How else do you explain the support for Buttigieg and Bloomberg amongst self-described liberals?
I will vote blue no matter who.
Yes, yes and yes!
I'll vote for ANYONE other than Trump!  A two-headed spitting cobra would be better than what we've got now.
YES.
Yes.
YES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I still hope it can be Warren.  I'd love to see her mop up the floor with the moron during debates.

"Will you do everything you can to deny Trump a
 second term ?"
 Yes, absolutely !  I am so sick of the clashing egos and the so called "revolutionaries" along with the PC folk.
If they don't quit this garbage -it is going to be 4 more years of Evil deeds by the mentally defective fool in Washington. He will reap so much destruction upon this nation and the world in those 4 years -and beyond. So you better wake up, suck it up - whoever the nominee. NONE of them are worth much, but any - yes ANY are better than what we've got. Please stop the fighting and aim it at the Target.
No. I'm volunteering for and donating to one of them right now. I will vote for any of them in the general, but there is only one candidate whom I'm willing to volunteer time and money for.

Good column. I'm getting pretty tired of hearing people like Chris Matthews and James Carville rant about how awful Bernie Sanders would be (at the same time that they denounce Sanders supporters for their lack of enthusiasm for Biden or Buttigieg). Recently Amy Klobuchar said she'd have a problem with a socialist at the head of the ticker. Get over it - I will, if one of my less preferred candidates is nominated.

This column is a useful reminder that compared with the modern GOP, all of the Democrats are moderate and sensible and propose policies that would be far better for future generations than those espoused by the nihilists in the Republican Party. Trump and the GOP must be defeated.

We need to find a candidate who can also ensure that we ALSO take back the Senate and keep the House. I'm having doubts on whether Sanders/Warren can do this in critical swing states. Democrats, do we really want #MoscowMitch to be at the helm in 2021?

Winston Churchill famously said that, "Americans will always do the right thing-- after exhausting all the alternatives."

Let's prove him right.
- Trump was the 'alternative' in 2016.
- Now is the time to do the right thing.

Vote your conscience in the primary.
And then vote blue, no matter who, on November 3.

How about a "co-presidency" for the strongest coalition against Trump? Say, Biden or Buttigieg as President in charge of national security and foreign policy, and Warren as VP in charge of the domestic and legislative agenda.

Donald Trump has never even attempted to be the president for all Americans. To the contrary, he has actively expressed contempt for over half of the American people.

Each and every potential Democratic nominee for president seeks to be the president for all Americans. To work for a better future for all of us. 

What unites us is far greater than what divides us. Mr. Trump will never understand that.

Vote your conscience in the primary.
And then vote blue, no matter who, on November 3.
Yes, I will vote for whomever wins the Democratic nomination. And prior to the election, I will do whatever I can to ensure that Trump is not re-elected. The future of my grandsons depends on this.

The 3600 and counting comments on this opinion piece demonstrate that the Democrats are united going in to the November 3 election.

Vote your conscience in the primary.
And then vote blue, no matter who, on November 3.

Thank you, Mr. Leonhardt.

- "A house divided against itself cannot stand." - Lincoln
- The American people shall demonstrate on November 3 that we are a house united -- for the Constitution, for the Rule of Law, for the American Experiment itself. We shall vote to reject Mr. Trump, and to support our nation, with a better future for all Americans.

Will I do everything in my power to deny Trump a second term? You BET I will. Yes, of course I have a preferred candidate. but as Leonhardt rightly notes, ANY Democrat is infinitely better on all the things that really matter, from civil rights to education to the environment--the things that mean the survival of our small-d democratic society in the long run. I will vote for whomever is the ultimate Democratic nominee, when it comes to that, although I will vote for the person whose specific ideas I like best in the primary. If everyone were to do the same, the strawman of electability would be toppled from its throne.

I agree that beating Trump is the most important thing. That's why I think we have to vote for Bernie Sanders. Although none of us has a crystal ball, there are very strong reasons why this is so. First of all he is strong in head to head polls against Trump. For example, in todays Quinnipiac poll he beats Trump by 8 points, and beats Trump in almost every head to head poll this election cycle. Also he is seen favorably by more people than any other candidate, probably because of his reputation for authenticity, the consistency of his views and the clarity of his proposals. Lastly, and maybe most importantly, because of experience and political skill, he is viewed as very tough and able to bring the fight to Trump with confidence.  In an election where we can expect the kitchen sink to be thrown at whichever democrat is chosen, Bernie thrives in such circumstances, as his performances at Liberty U. and the Fox town hall demonstrated. With all of the candidates having their strengths and weakness from an electability perspective, these strengths put Bernie substantially above his rivals.

Every Democrat I know celebrates the diversity of the United States of America. We understand it to be one of our nation's essential strengths, an eternally renewable source of energy and ideas.

Sometimes when we talk about our party, however, we tell ourselves that our problem is that we have too many good people with too many good ideas and too much energy; that what we really need is a lockdown on ideas and the kind of fearful, mindless unity that Mitch McConnell is able to impose on his caucus. 

Regarding our platforms and our policies in the run-up to the election, the paradox here is that any insistence on absolute unity will be sure to divide us and conquer us. As far as I can tell, it's Donald Trump's only possible pathway to victory. 

We are in the majority, people: We, the People. This election is, once again, ours to lose.

Diversity has been, is and always will be our strength. Let's not forget it, good people.

At the risk of oversimplifying, Bernie and Trump are two sides of the same coin. 

It is well known that the financial recovery was not even across the US. It is well known that us so-called "coastal elites" were blindsided by the depth of the anger a lot of the country felt that led to Trump. But it led to Bernie too, just with a different target. 

Trump's supporters see where they are at as the fault of the "other," usually immigrants, people of color, or the government itself. They think Trump is finally standing up for them. On the other hand, Bernie's supporters are just as angry and disillusioned, but they direct this at billionaires, Wall Street,  and capitalism itself (far less empathetic targets, sure). But they are just as isolating with their rhetoric. Bernie tapped into the same vein of anger Trump did, but directed it somewhere else. 

I am not sure how we fix a fractured system with the left going the same way the right went four years ago. Honestly, Bernie is just as isolating and inflammatory to half the country as Trump is to us. Can't we stop with the nonsense and get behind someone who wants to unite the country? This is what Democrats are failing to see— issues matter—and the Democrats do not have a cohesive platform or an efficacious plan to remedy the nation’s ills. In fact, their ‘problem statement’ (of what wrong with America) is all over the board: the existential threat of climate change, wealth inequality, the need for universal healthcare, the students debt crisis, illegal border crossing and undocumented immigrants, gay rights, and a women’s right to choose, to name only the most topical issues. By contrast Trump has a single issue—the economy— and a single message—make America great again. Given that 49% of Americans approve of his overall performance and 63% approval of how he is handling the economy, his message and credibility are solidly in-line. Not so for any of the Democratic candidates. The only thing bigger than the problems they are trying to solve is the cost of the solutions themselves! Despite the range of candidates - from "centrist" at best to left wing , we are too quick to find all sorts of "fatal flaws" in them, be they Bernie Sanders or Amy Klobuchar - not exactly ideological soul mates. But all these explanations about their "flaws" overlook why they will really lose to Trump. 

Trump supporters are an easy demographic to campaign for. They are either white nationalists or whites who may not be racist themselves, but will easily tolerate an avowed racist in the White House. White resentment has been building for decades. They have accepted Trump's lies that brown skinned people are the cause of all this nation's problems. They are single issue voters despite their claims to dislike "identity politics". And they will be the largest single voting bloc for some time, and can easily consolidate Republican control.

Democrats can "fine tune" their messages and run the "ideal" candidate, but they will never win the support of Trump voters because to do so would require embracing bigotry. 

Contrast Trump voters with Democrats - suburban white conservatives to young, very left-leaning voters. We are a much more heterogeneous voting bloc, and so of course it will be impossible for one candidate to appeal to all of us. We made this mistake in 2016 and our democracy is hanging by a thread because of our selfishness. We cannot afford to make this mistake again.

Here we go again...another article subtly bashing progressive policies like Medicare for All. Why is Medicare for All considered such an extreme idea? You know what's an extreme idea? Continuing the status quo, or continuing it with "tweaks."

Health Insurance premiums for a family currently cost $20,000 PER YEAR. Add in out of pocket, and the cost is ~$25,000 per year. Those costs have tripled over the past 20 years.  With median incomes at around $60k, that's an effective tax rate households are paying of 33-40%! By 2030, if we do nothing, those costs will hit $30-35,000.

Add the likelihood that you will go bankrupt due to medical bills, even if you have insurance, a 1 out of 20 chance in the next 10 years...add in the likely hood that you or a loved one will have a disability or major health event in the next 10 years, a 1 in 4 chance, and the aforementioned costs go up far beyond the averages cited above.

Ask yourself this: Are you prepared to shell out $20,000....$30,000 per year in insurance premiums plus more in out of pocket costs each year for the next 10 years?

Are you prepared to see Medicaid and the current Medicare for seniors cut benefits because the costs aren't addressed?

It is for me, and always has been, a vote of conscience. The person, the issues, the strength to fight for them. Not the Party.

If a presidential candidate can place country before self interests, welfare of people before party, leadership before loutishness, exhibit integrity, accountability, empathy, humility, resilience, vision, influence, and positivity, they have my vote regardless of party.
Thank you.  Yes, I will.  I’m not optimistic, though.

The danger now, as I see it especially in this part of the country, is that people are getting used to Trump. We ignore, filter out the bluster or just hit the mute button. A numbness sets in. So the question now is how much longer can we stand to do this?

Framing this solely as us being out to "deny Trump" lumps sane folks into the stereotype of Dems, progressives, and other sane people interested in restoring decency, honor, respect, democracy, and commitment to challenges that we all share and should value (climate change, social welfare, equity, etc.).  Can't we (someone??) reframe this in a positive way:  "you still do everything you can to restore democracy ...", etc.?

Doesn't matter.  Never enough Democratic turnout in national elections.  Need independents in WI, MI, PA, etc. otherwise its game over.  Perhaps this is the hard lesson Democrats need to learn.  Or maybe the real change is electing at least 4 independent Senators around the country (i.e. Angus King, (I)ME) to counter the majority leader's autocracy and serve as the real kingmakers in the federal government.

Asking people to vote for the lesser evil didn’t work in 2016. Why would it work in 2020?

Incidentally, there’s one more presidential candidate in the running - Andrew Yang - who inspires hope and unity. He’s right when he says Donald Trump is not the source of all our problems but is a symptom of the problems and challenges facing America today. And we lose to him when we act like he is, because it takes the focus away from solving the real problems on the ground.

His ideas have propelled him from a nobody to one of the 7 qualifying candidates in the last debate. He has earned the right to be included in the conversation. New and unconventional as he might be, he could just be the democratic nominee that we need.

I'm a Bernie supporter, and I agree 100 percent with Mr. Leonhardt. A split Democratic Party will never defeat  a united 
Republican front.  Both left and centrist have strong points and weakness' and neither are a sure bet without a united party.

God help us if the democrats turn on one another and eat their own young.

To answer your question: A resounding YES!  I am not for Bernie but I think it is imperative to remove Trump in numbers that cannot be manipulated behind the scenes by Putin or challenged by Trump.  I will canvas, call, organize for anyone who wins the election.  The trick is not selecting someone who is the walking wounded emerging from the primaries.

But it is not just Trump.  As we have seen in spades, we must take the servile and corrupt Senate as well as retain the House.  This may be the most important election since the 1860 pre-Civil War vote.  Surely, as much, if not more, of whether we will survive as America will turn on voter turnout and everyone--everyone!--must vote and be counted.

Even if all registered Democrats rally behind the eventual nominee, it won’t be enough to win the election.  To win, Dems have to be able to convince swing voters, some who voted for Trump and almost all who voted third party in 2016, to vote for the Democratic candidate, especially in swing states.

There have only been four incumbent presidents in the last century who have lost their bids for re-election (Hoover, Ford, Carter and Bush Sr.).  All were struggling with bad economic conditions.  Although Trump is a uniquely polarizing individual with serious moral failings, the economy is strong.

I just do not believe that swing voters in swing states are going to gamble on a candidate like Sanders who rails against capitalism and threatens their job security.  The economic pie is large and certainly could be divided more fairly, but Sanders’s policies would shrink the pie.  And that scares a lot of people.

People who read the media have been asked this question a thousand times.  It actually encourages people who might support a candidate based on their personal preferences to wait out the primaries.  This then leaves them with a candidate in whom they may not be particularly interested.  Which depresses turnout in the general election.  

Why not let the primaries be the primaries?

It will be the responsibility and duty of the losing Democratic candidates to persuade their supporters to actively support the eventual nominee. Senator Sanders was largely unable to rally his supporters to vote for Clinton in 2016. A half-hearted endorsement speech at the convention isn't going to cut it this time. Enthusiastic support and active campaigning for the nominee is the bare minimum that will be effective and acceptable to both moderates and progressives.

A very wise piece.  
I think party unification may require a leader or leaders to step up, someone(s) respected by—or capable of gaining the respect of—both halves of the party.  We need moral leadership that understands the stakes, and sees—and can effectively communicate about—the value of both sides.

A vote for Warren is a vote for the greatest strength of each top tier candidate: Bernie's decades long commitment to nationalized to health care, Biden's (I'm sorry I can't think of anything), Buttegieg's eloquent, youthful optimism, Klobuchar's solid work ethic and persistence, Bloomberg's financial backing, only all in small donations. (Ah well, he may have more $ but then also he's a Republican.)

And plus, a very big PLUS, she has successfully combated corruption in the financial world and has made clear her priority and specific plan to expand and continue.  She has specific policy plans for the challenges our nation faces across the board - and nothing is going to happen without those. I don't see the equivalent elsewhere. 

Americans put so much value in the rhetoric and, far too often, don't look under the hood. 

Yes. Yes. Yes. I will vote for any opponent of Trump's and I will cling to any of the positives listed above. But, truly, I'd rather vote for the best candidate with all of these qualities irregardless of  the lies we hear about electability. 

Warren (most portrayed as unelectable) beat Biden (most portrayed as electable) in Iowa. So that means the electability part is up to voters.

The differences here downplayed. The emphasis on identity politics is only coming from a fraction of the party. Some candidates are advocating a 50% expansion in government - i.e. major increases in taxes on the middle-class, not just the wealthy, because there is no other way to pay for their agenda.

Despite being a registered Republican until late last year, I have voted Democrat in the past several national elections, and will do so again in November. Is it too much to ask Democrats to do the same?

I have been asking my friends and family this for almost a year. My 31 year old son can't get past what he perceives as the unfair media attention to Bernie, but he better hurry up and move on if Bernie is not the candidate. Anyone who cannot see the daily danger we are living in is a danger to the country themselves.

Like countless others have been saying, Vote for the Democratic nominee.

Trump and Trumpism are Existential threats to our nation and the world.

Vote for the Democratic nominee.

Trump will render America unrecognizable with another 4 years.

Vote for the Democratic nominee.

Who would you rather have appointing federal judges and Justices to the Supreme Court?

Trump or any Democrat?

Who would you rather have constructing fiscal and tax policy?

Trump or any Democrat?

Who would you trust to fight for our laws, values, institutions, and constitution?

Trump or any Democrat?

There will be a Democratic Nominee.  The nominee will not be everyones preferred choice, first choice, or anointed savior of the Democratic Party.

Vote for the Democratic Nominee.

Our nation faces a true existential threat, autocracy is here and dictorship awaits if Trump is reelected.

If you don't vote, or you write in other candidates, you are De Facto voting for Trump.

Period.

Some of the comment here seems to focus on internal Party differences and, hence, misses two critical political truths:

1)  If Democrats fail to win in November all else, and the second point below, becomes moot -- and we likely will lose our Republic.  WINNING is paramount.

2)  Democratic intra party differences, about the merits of "socialism", progressivism, centraism, etc., can be effectively adjudicated only AFTER electoral victory, not before.  No need to rush this matter via a divisive primary.

As a college Professor working with undergraduate students for over four decades, I see a series of problems and potential roadblocks that are concerning.
Students are more than ever hardened in the belief that their vote does not matter. They say if their candidate is not nominated then they may not vote a all. I hear talk of a desire for real and substantial change in the American political system that is matched only by their fear that they are doomed to inherit a world of environmental calamity's and economic uncertainties. They are saddled by student loan debt and do not see a way out. But perhaps the biggest  impression I am left with is their feeling that older white men have failed them, their country and that they do not represent them or their generation. From my position this is going to be the group that will make or break the Democrat's future. I do not have an answer except that I never fail to use the appropriate time to stress the importance of being involved in the upcoming Presidential election process. Parents you need to have a talk with your kids. They need a pep talk and soon.

The first, and only order of business for the Democrats and those with an interest in promoting democracy, protecting the social safety net, accessing quality health care, stopping the republicans corruption nationwide,  and addressing the impending  climate collapse is preventing the re-election of Trump.

An implicit issue that needs to be explicitly discussed is how Democratic tribalism has hurt the interests of all democrats. Despite 2016 election campaign character attacks, I argued the Democratic presidential candidate was far more aligned with my values than the Republican. Yet many I argued with could only see flaws, and were determined to aim their vote at a more "pure" candidate - and felt vindicated by the result!!! Until a future brings Ranked Choice Voting, the purists need to climb off their mountain and elect 'good-enough' Democrats.

My motto for this election is "Vote Blue No Matter Who!"  Still, moderates should realize that they are at least a partial cause for the emergence of Trump.  Last election, Hilary had to be persuaded to support a $12/hr. minimum wage, and said she absolutely wouldn't support a $15/hr. minimum wage in the year 2016. Many Trump supporters are hurting terribly financially, and were persuaded to vote for Trump even though that was folly.  The moderate wing of the Democratic Party really hasn't helped anybody financially for decades, including Obama (who bailed out the corporations but not the underwater homeowners), and they are a major cause of the amount of support Trump has obtained.  If a moderate wins the nomination, they had better start taking care of the less fortunate or we'll be fighting off Trump-type candidates for many years to come.

Absolutely true! Progressive independents (myself included) and Democrats must immediately unite behind the Democratic nominee. The candidates should be telling their supporters that NOW, especially Bernie. I believe Warren has the best chance at uniting the party; already she has been flexible enough to take the health care concerns of moderates into consideration and adjust her plan accordingly. For now the Democrats are our best hope to restore moral, accountable government in America. Looking to the future however, our democracy would be healthier with more than two parties. Ideally the Tea Party would break right, the Progressives left, and those of us who put saving the planet above all else could vote Green.

Just maybe the Democratic party is too diversified to agree on any strategy for survival. The middle class and the workers started going down economically after Ronald Reagan left the unions and declared (after being mentored by GE) that he didn't leave the party, the party left him.
So Democrats can start by undoing everything that Reagan and the Republicans accomplished after the 1980s.
Democrats should advocate higher taxes on the wealthy corporations who now own our government, thanks to Citizens United. So, repeal Citizens United.
Bring back the unions, because American workers do not have the power to defend themselves against greedy corporations.
Close the loopholes that allow corporations to outsource jobs for pure profit to the detriment of our middle class workers.
Reinstate antitrust laws to compel corporations to share the wealth with the workers.
Get rid of Trump. Select a candidate who can go toe to toe, punch for punch against Trump in the coming election.

I fully intend to do what I did last time: vote for the candidate I want in the primary, and vote for the Democratic candidate in the general election.

What will I do differently this year? I'll fight like heck to get to get the Democratic candidate elected. Rallies, protests, get-out-the-vote, knocking on doors, whatever. It's mobilization time.

Why does unequal results of human achievement conjure up simple notions of injustice for Dems? Dems most often learn harsh economic truths in the pursuit of financial sustainability/funding. Unfortunately, human impulse is generally towards equality or generosity. Equality is as undesirable as it is unrealizable. Attempting to achieve equality requires that each of us forego who we are & what we can do in order to create something in which no one ultimately believes - a society everybody is the same or has the same. It’s very common for people to change economic philosophies & political parties based upon experiences, education & self interest during their lifetime. Democrats have to understand our emotional side is like an elephant & our rational side, it's rider. Perched atop the elephant, the rider holds the reins & seems to be the leader. But the rider's control is precarious because the rider is so small relative to the elephant since it is not reason who guides life, but customs. Trump understands that a belief doesn't have to be the truth - what matters is the utility of the belief (even if it's a lie). As Trump relentlessly pokes the elephant with lies, Dems can't take the  bait.  If Dems want to change how things are, they shouldn't be fixated on language since most talk is cheap & language-games won't set us free. Dems must vote in 2020, despite at  times feeling alienated, cut off from Rep & themselves as Trump's base seem contented, untroubled & free of worries.

As much as you guys all dislike Trump, his approval rating is now near 50% because he's shown that he gets stuff done. You might not like his style or the fact that he so openly takes for his own pocket, but get over it, every single politician is an opportunist. Just look at your senators and representatives. The suits on their backs cost $5k a pop and they're not paying for that out of their salaries! I mean really, are any of these people on stage any better? If you really want to hire someone that doesn't care about enriching himself further, then vote for Mike Bloomberg. He's already worth more than every politician in America combined.

Yes.  America can go in two directions: reactionary or progressive.  Will we appeal to our best or basest instincts?  What kind of world will we leave our children.  Will cynicism or optimism prevail?  Who will be our role model?

It's the same choice which allows us no choice. Democrats, Independents, and progressive Republicans must deny Trump a second term.  

I support Bernie, but if the Democrats choose another nominee, I will vote for that person regardless of any shortcomings I feel they might have.  There is no third way, no other choice in American politics until the Electoral College is abolished or circumvented.

We have no choice.  That is our choice!

Yes.  America can go in two directions: reactionary or progressive.  Will we appeal to our best or basest instincts?  What kind of world will we leave our children.  Will cynicism or optimism prevail?  Who will be our role model?

It's the same choice which allows us no choice. Democrats, Independents, and progressive Republicans must deny Trump a second term.  

I support Bernie, but if the Democrats choose another nominee, I will vote for that person regardless of any shortcomings I feel they might have.  There is no third way, no other choice in American politics until the Electoral College is abolished or circumvented.

We have no choice.  That is our choice!

So far as I know, no one else is willing to say it, so I'll say it regarding the candidacies of Warren, Sanders and Buttigieg. 
Sadly, misogyny, anti-Semitism and homophobia are deep and pervasive prejudices in America. Much of the bias is not overtly expressed, but it's there and would harm each of the Democratic candidates listed above. 
It hurts to write this, as I abhor bigotry, but in the upcoming general election voters need to see things as they are and not as they wish them to be.

I'm a Republican in a VERY red state. Trump has single-handedly destroyed the Republican party as I knew it. I will be voting for his opponent--no matter who it may be. Policy can be overturned, but the destruction Trump may wreak in his second term cannot.
My answer is a resounding YES. I'll support whoever is nominated to run against Trump. I'll even support the village idiot to beat the idiot in the White House.

Hey David, maybe you want to sit down with your NYT co-workers and explain this to them too.

With the size of your megaphone you guys have an inordinate amount of pull and access.

As you point your fingers remember to look in that mirror and around your boardroom.

Not holding my breath on this one.

We are Sander's supporters and understand the need to appeal to a broad audience.  We feel like Bernie will get the blue-collar workers who went to Trump in 2016.  We personally know many union workers, who were Democrats forever, who then voted for Trump.  We could not understand why.  These Trump supporting union workers will not come back to the Democratic party unless you listen to them.  They hate the Democrats now, because they feel abandoned.  Last night, we saw a commercial on TV that had Obama promoting Bloomberg! What direction is the Democratic party going, when they support a billionaire who has been a life-long Republican?  We lost the last shred of respect we had for Obama last night. Obama won because he promised "Hope and Change", but failed to follow through. Then Trump won, because people want change. People are HURTING in this country and want a president who has their back.  Bernie is the only one that gives us HOPE and that isn't taking money from the same donors as the republicans.

From Mr. Leonhardt, a timely and important message. I'm struck in reading comments sections over the last weeks how often tempers flare between Democrats over their respective preferences. 

I also note---and I realize how early it is in the process---that reports of voters having difficulties making up their minds keep popping up. Almost as if, given the stakes, we're terrified to get it wrong.

If so, it's understandable. I've noticed that concern in myself.

The preferences don't seem to be peaking very much. I was reading on the FiveThirtyEight website about the lively possibility of a contested convention. Perhaps that's good thing. We don't have to decide today.  We may not be able to. For now, without setting our collective hair-on-fire TOO often, we can fully gauge our candidate pool, our polls, our situation, Trump's relative strengths and weaknesses. And what new messes he has presented to us.

Come the convention, we have to come together. We can then count on the best among us, like President Obama, to issue the clarion call to put the primaries aside and come together for the final united push.

The irony of all of this is, it would be so easy for the Dems to win: reform immigration; add a public option to the ACA; bring colleges and universities to task for the inflation of costs and the suppression of free speech; move some of the massive number of government grants and subsidies from the coasts to the rest of the country; spend on infrastructure; allow school choice. These are all "common sense" measures. However, Dems are just not going to win on gun control and pandering to to the hyper-Left fringe.

Having voted Democratic since my first vote for VP Mondale in 1984, through disheartening Dukakis and Gore and Kerry and Clinton losses, I cannot support a Democratic party migration towards a conviction and plank based on the notion that things (education, warplanes, interest rate subsidies, carbon sequestration, whatever) are free.  I do not dispute that the GOP is the party that speaks out of both sides of its mouth, asserting there is no free lunch but giving away the environment and corporate welfare year after year after.  But it makes no sense for Democrats to be equally reckless, and that is what Sen Sanders promises, indeed promotes.  Worse, the Sanders' promise isn't just captured in the use of the word 'free'.  It says in effect each of us as citizens has no responsibility.  We aren't obligated to work to pay the bills; we aren't obligated to do sit ups to stay fit, et/c.  This it seems is incredible corrosive to the notion that you give to get, not just get.  Rallying the troops to ensure the current President is not re-elected is one thing.  Supporting another version of reckless profligacy is quite another, and I suspect most Democrats are actually not willing to defeat Trump if it means trading in a core conviction of personal responsibility somewhere in the formula.

If there is a democracy left where voting is allowed, I'll vote blue no matter who.

Also, Is Bernie Sanders a Democrat? I'm not really sure why we let him continue to run on our ticket?

The columnist asks us to be the sheeps blindly following two political parties.

He demands loyalty without rewards and protection,
or without responsibility and transparency from the politicians bought by the big business long ago.

Of course, a columnist is paid for by the same wealth that owns the politicians.

This is not freedom of press but freedom of corruption.

Bribery is now perfectly legal and branded as freedom of speech.

That's why the columnists want to focus your attention on Trump in order to mask the chronic structural problems.

The problem it seems with many Democrats is their sense of idealism. Idealism is great especially in a proper European Parliamentary system. However in our American style “democracy” there are really only two choices, red or blue. 

Protest voting accomplished nothing but put Trump in power.

It may make more sense to allow Trump to continue for another 4 years if we cannot have a truly progressive candidate. I'd rather stack Congress against him than put someone who will be a conservative with a friendlier face and the Dem brand in office. We'll have a better chance of reversing policy in the future if we forgo 4 years of Biden or  Buttigieg.

Most democrats will vote for the nominee - it's simply the immature Bernie supporters who may sit it out.  And, I don't trust Bernie to encourage them to vote if he is not the nominee - he isn't even a Democrat.
What we really need to ask ourselves is - who will suburban Republican women (and some men) vote for in states that matter (sorry but CA, NY, NJ, etc don't matter) - it isn't Bernie (or Warren, and unlikely Pete).  If Dems don't nominate a moderate we will never win the electoral college and probably lose the House.
My hope for party unity in November rests heavily on VP candidates available to the nominee from all the other candidates, including Kamala Harris and Cory Booker.

The candidates are too busy attacking each other, wasting precious time and their constant bickering does not solve problems nor elevate the party. In fact, it elevates Bloomberg as the only adult in the room (and frankly, I don’t care if he’s rich, it’s what he does with his money and he is using it for good, such as climate change).  As for the others (aka the Bickerstons), I keep waiting for them to rise up, and so far, they they have failed.  

The big question is this, are the candidates fully willing to support and endorse the nominee, and ask their supporters to vote for that person? We can’t afford a 2016 repeat of the Bernie/Hillary feud...which is still ongoing and not helpful to the party.

Here is the definition of "socialism":

""a political and economic theory of social organization which advocates that the means of production, distribution, and exchange should be owned or regulated by the community as a whole."

Bernie Sanders does NOT advocate that.

I propose we stop calling him a socialist and reply to anyone who does that he is lying.

If Sanders wins the nomination, moderates are going to have to pick sides: the "socialist" (who isn't really a socialist) or the authoritarian (who really is an authoritarian).

I will vote for whomever the Democrats nominate. We make America great when we remove authoritarians from office.

The flawed question is whether the Democrats will support the nominee, whoever that is. The path to the White House and defeating Trump, however, is what will Independents do? Personally, I don’t see them flocking to Bernie or Warren, too left; Biden, damaged goods,and a train wreck on the campaign trail; or Buttiegieg, with his youth and thin resume.  Klobuchar and Bloomberg seem to me to be the most likely to attract independents.

David Leonhardt is right that we all need to unify behind whoever wins the Dem nomination.  But he glosses over one of the prime reasons why so called “moderates” in the Dem establishment have been so congenial to corporate interests and so indifferent to the needs of everybody else.  MONEY!

Leonhardt also forgets that labor rights were won after a near century of bloody battles and massacres of working people.  Until FDR, the Federal Government was solidly on the side of the corporate murderers.  This generated the inequality (and resulting lack of effective consumer demand) that made the Great Depression possible. Social Security was partly a response to the utter deprivation and misery that could befall workers cast aside because of age. But it was also part of an effort to (counter-cyclically  maintain consumer demand to mitigate the effects of future economic slumps and crashes.

We should unite behind whoever wins the Dem nomination and then make sure held are really accountable to human needs and not just pandering on behalf of their billionaire donors. Or, if we elect a true progressive populist like Bernie or Elizabeth Warren we need to stay mobilized to ensure Republicans and corporate democrats don’t water down necessary reforms in the interest of protecting greedy boardroom profiteers.

This is a single issue election- There is no, NO issue more important than beating trump so blue no matter who for sure.    All dems support equality, human rights, womens rights and pay equality, climate change issues, challenging the 1%, student debt, healthcare, advocating for science/STEM, ending endless war in mid east, etc., etc.
 ALL dems are in line with these issues- albeit to different degrees, but the point is I personally can live with those different degrees, I can't live with more trump- so whomever can beat him needs to be supported. i don't think bernie's the guy, but if there party mistakingly nominates him I'll vote for him- no way I'll sit home like the bernie or busters did when HRC ran.

In 2016, I wrote Bernie Sanders in for the general election as a protest to the DNC and Hillary for their egregious dirty trick of running 'Clinton Wins the Nomination' across the evening news on June 6. The next day six states would hold their primaries including mine in California.
On that morning I was walking precincts here encountering people who were not going to vote based on the evening news.
There was no way I could have voted for her!

Here we are in 2020 and the Democratic party and its supporters still have not learned to represent the People, only their own wealth-holdings. 
We still have no Medicare for All, no control over insurance or drug companies prices, sky-rocketing student loan debt and unaffordable housing.

Bernie is the only one to heal this dark chasm and garner enough votes from Trump voters. 
If you don't want Trump, then Bernie is the only person who can beat him!

This is exactly the question I wish moderators would ask each potential presidential candidate: If you're not selected by the voters to be the nominee, will you vigorously support the ultimate candidate which comes out of the Democratic convention? They've all averred not wanting Trump to have a second term; let's get them specifically on the record.

A great deal of talk from progressives about wealth gap and inequality.  If I understand the argument correctly, the government should tax the wealthy to fund higher education, social security, healthcare, and other entitlements?  Were that possible, how is this not also theft?   Because it's already assumed that the wealthy became that way through theft?  Also, from a practical standpoint, why wouldn't the top 1% just leave the US and move their offices and factories to other countries with more flexible government regulations?  So what happens when multiple business begin doing this, and you see a contraction of our economy and GDP?  What happens to international investments when these tax rates go into effect?  Please enlighten me about how this policy will correct the wealth gap

I will be out campaigning for whomever is running against Trump.  He has trashed the United States and will continue to do so so long as we allow it.  Of course I prefer some candidates more than others, but the differences between them pale in comparison to the difference between any of them and and Trump.

Job One is denying Trump a second term in 2020.  Any purist who niggles- doesn't vote- about a particular Democratic nominee because they might deny them their policy "must-haves" is completely missing the point.  First we have to cut-out the malignancy, and then, afterward, it's on to rehab.

It is truly astounding to behold the breadth and depth of ignorance on the part of the DNC when it comes to software and cybersecurity, especially in light of what happened in 2016.
The announcement that Bernie's campaign had recorded evidence from every location... That really tossed a spanner into the gears of their plot.

There is an hypothesis that the ostensible incompetence of the DNC is part of a deliberate effort to dismantle the democrat party, the goal being to transition the country to one party rule.  Arguably, we have had one party rule going back to the days of the Clinton presidency, during which the democrats allowed themselves to be corporate captives just like the republicans.  But the appearance of differences has been maintained up until now, to maintain the illusion that the electorate has a choice.

Once the number of political parties has officially been reduced to one, we can then continue the metamorphosis by replacing Congress with a committee of CEOs chosen from the largest international corporations.  This in turn will speed the demise of national governments everywhere, and the return to a form of feudalism based on market rather than geographic segmentation.

We Democrats must unite over the Democratic nominee, whoever that turns out to be. Even if the nominee is not your dream candidate, he or she will bring greater equity, sense, smarts, and graciousness than our current president. Apart from his giving tax cuts to the wealthy and cutting food stamps for the poor, increasing the defense budget, ad infinitum, look at the way foreign leaders roll their eyes when they see him at conferences. We will soon have the international standing of the Canary Islands. No offense to the Canary Islands.

The answer must be yes. No Democratic candidate having a chance to win would be worse than Trump. That includes Bloomberg who is going to be a major contender.

Democrats also should be talking about making our government more efficient, focusing on making our government more results oriented.

For the past 50 years many new programs were past to improve the lives of average citizens. After passage there has been no focus on doing this efficiently. The Democrats were good at passing new laws andspending our tax dollars, but with no controls and accountability.  

This must change or the chump Trump will remain in the White House.
The question that Leonhart needs to answer is whether there is enough support and mobilization in swing states for Bernie to win.

Wonkishness isn't centrist or moderate it is wonkish, it is finding solutions that work regardless of ideology.
You can solve income inequality the Russian way where there is virtually no poverty but everybody has just enough except for their Donald Trumps. Or you can do it the Quebec way where everybody has at least enough but most have far more than enough and a few have incredible amounts.
Russia is a far right constitutional Republic whose leader is rumoured to be the world richest man. He has been richly rewarded for being a devout Orthodox Christian.
I don't get all the Russia is our enemy Ukraine is our ally bull. 
Here in Canada Russia is our enemy and Ukraine is our ally because we share Ukraine's stated ethics and values and Russia has already condemned them.
We are already fearing November because regardless of who wins we have very difficult decisions to make Russia is not our friend and what must we give up to make pretend that we are losers in the zero sum game.

In summary - don't fall prey to the trolls who clearly see we're not strong enough to completely ignore them yet.  We're weak, and fall for every diversion, especially the ones that highlight our differences and subject us to purity tests.  

Be strong, we want to same thing at the end, but we're fighting about the route to take to get there.

Vote blue, no matter who!

I'm sorry this election is so polarized, and I agree that most Democrats will vote for the nominee in order to beat Trump. I also think that the Democratic Party leaders have to continue to emphasize how Democrats will provide a better future for all Americans, not just the followers of Trump. Trump's lies have to be challenged. Trump has not been exonerated; he was impeached and squeaked through by two votes. He has not created a better economy for many of those who voted for him; income inequality is worse under Trump, the rich guy's tax evading friend. He plans to pay for his tax cuts by cutting Medicare, Medicaid, Food Stamps, and Obamacare, and to fix elections for Republicans through gerrymandering and appealing to Russians and China. Additionally, we need to keep the house and turn the Senate blue.

If this isn't the last election before we lose our country completely, I certainly hope it's the last election for both the Republicans and Democrats. Republicans are simply going to age out as no one under 40 will vote for them.  We're witnessing their violent death throes and we need to sluice them into the dustbin of History while gently protecting what's left our shattered union. The two top Dem contenders who actually have a shot at going head to head with the creature in the white house are Bernie and Mike, neither of whom are Democrats. But they do terrify the creature and that will redound to America's benefit.

I'm a 67 year old independent,liberal Viet Nam era vet who will grimly pull the lever for any of the ancient ones with a D after their name. But really... in a country of 330 million can't we find someone under 70 to inspire the young generation to vote? (no, it's not mayor Alfred E Newman Pete) Can't the Dems find someone with more charisma than a peeled grape (sorry Mr. Perez) to lead their party in this battle?
