The challenge of this election is whether we place our confidence in those we judge as having integrity or in those who justify our need to feel superior. A person of integrity personifies our shared values with honest and consistent actions that uplift us to a greater appreciation of our collective virtues.
 In judging those we vote for we need to recognize the human weakness for emotional satisfaction in would-be leaders who violate integrity in using power to justify our need to feel superior to others. Given this human flaw, we must judge our own integrity in order to place confidence in public figures. This begins with an awareness of what integrity is not.
A person lacking integrity will be impulsive refusing to examine the alternatives.
A person lacking integrity will propose reasons to justify dishonest behavior.
A person lacking integrity believes his non-virtuous actions are necessary exceptions.
A person lacking integrity believes those who oppose him are inferior and should be severely punished.
A person lacking integrity will demand loyalty over respect for facts or truth.
A person lacking integrity will accuse others of evil intent doing the very action he has done himself.
We all fail the integrity test to some degree. The only true choice is, "Do I place my confidence in consistent honest actions or in feeling superior to other people?"
Your response will determine if you are fooled just some of the time or fooled all of the time.

Any of the candidates in our tent would improve or let stand so many important parts, and also "...remember which parts of the campaign they can't control.." If your person doesn't get the nomination, support the candidate of the Democratic Party who did. If we stand together, we could remove the current resident in the White House.

The very problem with the Democratic party is its tone deaf nature.  If the party wants to mimic OccupyWallstreet and turn itself into the Socialist, grievance party, then it will not win the next election.  Mike Bloomberg is completely correct in pointing out that if Bernie is nominated, his left wing policies will define not only a failed election but every other Democratic candidate in the country who will be forced to promote the Bernie Socialism band-wagon.  So the answer to Davide Leonhardt is NO.  The Democrats must put up a centrist or they will not only lose the election but cement the Republican party's control of government in general.

I admire the determination of committed Democrats to ignore the highest stock market in history, lowest unemployment in half a century and fewest American combat casualties in at least 3 decades to save democracy. If they fail, I’ll try to survive Trump’s second term.

Of course I will fight for whomever is nominated.  If Trump wins, more than likely the Supreme Court will turn hard right.  Democrats must win, or my daughters lose control over what happens to their own bodies.  I’m not forgiving any so-called friend who sits out this election.

Spot on, Mr. Leonhardt. Purity tests on this issue or that amount to taking one's eye off of the prize, and ceding the game to one's real opponent, in this case, Donald Trump. Sadly, vanquishing one's primary opponent and petulantly losing interest when one's most favored candidate fails amounts to a pathological lack of enthusiasm when it comes to solving the real problem. 

It's time for Democrats to get real, decide what they really want at the end of the primary season, and vote like it matters, because it does.

I really like Sanders, however I will vote for whoever is nominated. All the divisiveness in the Democratic Party is like candy for republicans. 
Be part of the be solution vote blue no matter who. Not voting is like a vote for trump. Wake up people!!

Perceptive article - the nihilist/arsonist approach of the Republicans has indeed pushed any actual meaningful debate on what policies should be to the Democrats - the only one of the two parties that still purports to actually govern.

You pose this question as if it were a really thorny or difficult one. The irony is the fact that the answer is so simple and inescapable. I've been saying this for months: the best thing that could happen for the Democratic Party at this point in time would be an enthusiastic pledge by each candidate to fully support the eventual nominee in whatever way possible. Imagine the effect of, for example, Sanders expressing, in his best pugnacious manner, his earnest desire to see Elizabeth Warren defeat Donald Trump. Or Mayor Pete campaigning relentlessly to see Sanders beat Trump. OK, maybe a heavy lift, but at minimum, it has to be a very easy answer for every ordinary Democratic voter: I will vote for the eventual Democratic nominee and do everything I can to promote turnout of Democrats on Election Day.

It seems to me that the way the various campaigns are being funded, it will take longer to winnow the field than it should. Sanders' and Warren's small dollar donors won't likely desert them en masse, and Steyer and Bloomberg can self-fund well past the time when other factors should indicate it was time to exit gracefully. That leaves the middle (Yang, Klobuchar, Biden, Buttigieg) as the only candidates whose decision to exit can be signaled by the desertion of a handful of large money donors. We may well see some dropouts after New Hampshire, after South Carolina at the latest.

Others have mentioned various inverse pairings (e.g., Sanders/Klobuchar vs Klobuchar/Sanders). I would argue that unless the nominee is Buttigieg, the pairing should be older/younger. We find ourselves in this mess in part because Joe Biden was Obama's VP. Aside from personal issues, he would have been the natural nominee in 2016. That moment passed. He shouldn't have jumped in this time around. It is time for the baton to be passed to a younger generation. (I say that as a Warren supporter. She's right on the cusp.)

What democrats lack this election was what Biden was supposed to do and failed, take command, unify the party, and get the primaries organized toward the convention. Now he's more an after thought while Sanders seizes opportunity to replace him against backlash about his his politics and history.

The idea of backing the nominee regardless won't work unless nominee proves they're a unifying candidate and represent the whole party. Sanders isn't it. Buttigieg isn't qualified. That leaves three to take the lead against those two. It will be hard for all democrats to back one of two white men.

Please realize that these are questions all R's D's and Independents are asking themselves Mr. Leonhardt.  Do not assume it is an ignorant electorate that is going to vote, as that is insulting.  There are intelligent voting members of the public that are not loyalist to either party and do not vote along party lines of any spectrum.  Right, left, or center.  But there are some public informed about issues and concerned about where the candidate will take us down the road and come up with the right solutions and can really solve the problems in the best fashion.

I'll vote for whoever the Democratic nominee is, just like last time.  I wasn't thrilled with Clinton but we'd sure be a lot better off if she were in office now.  I sincerely hope that anyone who doesn't want another 4 years of the Mandarin Menace will  vote straight Democratic ticket regardless.
Simple answer: If the Democratic Party gets it wrong - again - then this Politically Agnostic Voter will either vote for Trump, or stay home.

Here's what the Democrats need to be screaming, from the Washington Post:

"The White House is proposing a $4.8 trillion election-year budget Monday that would slash major domestic and safety net programs, setting up a stark contrast with President Trump’s rivals as voting gets under way in the Democratic presidential primary.

The budget would cut Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program and also wring savings from Medicare despite Trump’s repeated promises to safeguard Medicare and Social Security."

And if Democrats do not retake both the Senate and the president, and hold the House, this will become reality, not just Trump's wish list.  Use this for  messaging Democrats!
Stand with Amy because she is the most balanced of all candidates.

What about wonkish authenticity?

Looking at where we are as a nation, moreover where we need to go, I'm down for the one candidate who has a solid record of fighting corruption with public policy and winning, the one candidate who will not take a penny from billionaires. (What would this race look like if ALL dems followed suit?)

But, sure, I would support a demented gerbil over Trump. It's just, let's not allow Trump to manipulate us with fear the way he does his base. Let's not let him decide who he'll be running against.

We're supposed to revile him, right? Let's not feed him.

When we do that, when we vote for the candidate we think most "electable" overlooking all evidence to the contrary (most glaring that Warren, thought the least electable, just beat Biden, thought the most electable) we lose big time far before November.

Elizabeth Warren: competence, experience, intelligence, detailed policy, kindness, compassion, authenticity, integrity, positivity, persistence, courage...and so on.

Progressive and moderate Democrats must realize that none of their legislative goals will be accomplished if Trump is re-elected, and not much will happen unless Democrats also take the Senate.

Hopefully, citizens who might not vote or could vote either way realize the danger of a President unchecked by Congress, one who purges those who have testified to his abuse of power, one who makes very clear he does not represent all Americans - only those who support him, and one who lies repeatedly to Americans.  The norms that protect our freedoms need to be re-established with a Senate that will perform its role of Checks & Balances and a President that will be honest with Americans, represent all of us and uphold his or her oath of office.  Trump has bent those norms toward authoritarianism.  In four more years he could do a lot more damage to democracy.

My dog, Dante. is surely a Democrat, and if he were nominated, I'd vote for him. Sure, he doesn't have a lot of experience (neither does Trump, even after three disastrous years), but he's smart and kind, as Trump is not, so we'd be ahead from the start.

Anyone is better than Trump,   and those who think they should sit out the election because their favorite candidate wasn't selected should think hard: What would our country look like after four more years of Trump?

Be part of the solution, everyone.
"He or she is, of course, better than Trump and we will totally support him or her if he or she is the Democratic nominee."

Democrats have to remind themselves that what they need is a strategy to win the electoral vote.  They're doing OK with the popular.  It's far from a mandate, but the Republican Party has effectively staged a coup that did not begin with Trump and won't end with him.  Convince the people that the economy is good principally for reasons other than Trump and was hauled out of the mess it was in by Obama who kicked off the recovery.  And concentrate as you say on the environment, the income gap, and the deficit.

The lesser-evil candidate has always dominated thinking about voting in the Democratic Party. It's been going on for a very, very long time. I think of the nomination of Hubert Humphrey in 1968, as the peace candidates fell to the side (In the case of Robert Kennedy, of course, it was his  assassination that led the way for Humphrey to be the Democratic standard-bearer). Nixon won and the war in Southeast Asia became more heinous. 

What to do now? I've worked in the campaign of a liberal candidate once again. On election day, a person would have to be seriously deranged to sit by and allow for Trump to be reelected. A Trump second term will be the end of republican democracy (what's left of it) in the US!

I am not happy with what I saw in Iowa. I am beginning to lose interest in this election especially having to do with the Democratic candidates. The only time I never voted in an election is when the Army sent me on a overseas assignment during the early 1960s. 

I am not enthusiastic about voting for Sanders, Warren or the former mayor of the little town in Iowa. I will only vote for a moderate or just stay home on election day.

I am sad to see a lot of conspiracy-mongering and name-calling happening already amongst my progressive friends. We all need to calm down and realize they are all good candidates and we should be glad to vote for any of them, even if we'd be more glad for some than others.

The author misses the point a bit. I am sure the far left will work to defeat Trump regardless of nominee. The problem is the same as last time: they have no idea how.  Indeed, their antics almost always strengthen him.

Unfortunately, there are die hard Bernie bots who already admit that they will either sit this one out or vote for trump again if bernie doesn't get the nomination. While this is profoundly sad, they are as cultish as trump supporters and I'm afraid there's no changing their minds. They care little about our country - only about getting their guy in at all costs. To me, trump and bernie are just opposite sides of the same coin. On the other hand, if Bernie gets the democratic nomination, I will most definitely vote for him because I care about this country and will do what I can to assure that trump does not get a 2nd term.

Yes.
 
Period, unequivocally, without question or failure.    If there is a GOP alternative in the primary, I would support him/her to weaken Trump, then the Democrat in the general election, (they are all about equal, and will spend a first term attempting to undo the damage Trump has wrought, rather than accomplishing anything anyway...

If i remember correctly, in the 2016 elections, many of Sanders' people voted for the Republican Party rather than for Hilary Clinton.  i do hope this time, the Democrats remember that they are voting for their Party, not for a person. Hate to say it but that's one thing they should learn from the Republicans who probably learned form the Communists.

Interesting that Sanders voters are completely dug in for him, attacking those who dare disagree or say, rightly, that a "Socialist" cannot beat Trump, etc., yet young people - who are Sanders voters - apparently stayed home in Iowa.  That is one reason a Sanders nomination terrifies me.   But then, will Sanders voters turn out for a different nominee?  Seems to me Sanders supporters are big on responding to polls and defending him as fiercely as Trump supporters defend Trump...but then they stay home when it matters.

There is a danger of sending the message to potential voters that their individual vote is of little consequence.  The focus seems to be on the swing states: Wisconsin, Michigan, etc.  Other comments have made the point that who controls the Senate sets the agenda and has the power.  So get out the vote!  And, vote against the senators who are lock step with Trump and Mitch McConnell.

Perhaps I will be roasted by everyone if they read it at all, but here it is.  The future is not for Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders  Joe Biden or myself an aging boomer who are intent in jamming a lifetime into the final years of our lives.  It is for the three beautiful young women who I shared soup with at our after church get together,  all students at the local university, one studying industrial engineering, one theater  arts, the last communications and political science.  we can advise them, but considering the mess we have allowed to happen with such thing as climate change and income inequality I hope they do a better job of it.  Politically, make your own conclusions.

Yes, Iâ€™m a Biden supporter but I will come out for Sanders. Iâ€™m a centrist, and Trumpâ€™s far-right government followed by a Sanders far-left government would be centrist on average. Also, the only damage Sanders may do to people is financial; you wonâ€™t see the government doing malicious things itâ€™s doing today like separating families through travel bans.

Yes, Yes, Yes. Emphatically. Unequivocally. A question to those considering not voting if their candidate doesnâ€™t win the nomination. would you rather have Trumpâ€™s finger on the nuclear trigger or a sane person whose policies you donâ€™t agree with.

Absolutely.

Elections are about preferences. I'd prefer any non-Republican candidate to the person in the White House and the party that controls the Senate. 

I'd argue that anybody that feels otherwise simply hasn't been paying attention, both to current events, and to their eerie parallel with the dark chapters from history over the past 100 years.

Think such horrors can't take root here? Think again.

No way I'll pull a lever for any Republican for the next couple of decades at least.

If you want to regain the White House, it may feel like you have several choices to pick from.

But if you want to win the White House, hold onto the House and perhaps take the all important Senate, then Bloomberg is the only choice.

Perhaps, maybe, possibly, any of the current primary candidates if nominated, might possibly beat Trump. I have a stronger feeling for moderates having a shot at this than say Sanders. But none of the front runners including until a few months ago my pick - Biden - will win over the Senate let alone hold the House.  They are a crap-shoot.

Bloomberg on the other hand is the only candidate I believe that might win the trifecta. He is competent, extremely intelligent, extraordinarily well prepared and most certainly capable. 

His vision is not just to win the White House, it is to govern.

And he knows that in order to be successful, he will need to hold the House and win the Senate. Using poker terminology, he is "all-in".  If nominated, he will use his indispensable wealth and business acumen to insure that his presidency is not blocked by McConnell and his minions.  

He is the only "take the gloves off" candidate left with the power this fight will now take.
The issue is that the further left the Democratic candidate is, the more likely the American voter will vote for Republicans for the Congress to offset policies of the Democratic nominee.

The "debates" are not debates.  They are a waste of time, talent, and campaign funds that should be focused more on beating Trump.  They don't really educate the voters.  They feed "gotcha" barbs to media who should be covering, and demanding, more substantial news.  There are far too many "candidates" who don't even qualify as would-be candidates.   The new impression, to the outside world, is one of disorder and disorganization caused by overinclusiveness.  Why does Tom Perez even have a job?  That's another vital question candidates should ask.

Though I applaud Mr. Leonhardt's reminders to keep our heads and focus on the larger perspective, I find it disturbing that such admonitions are still necessary.  

If Donald Trump, Mitch McConnell, Jim Jordan, FOX News and all the destructive capabilities of the current conservative universe are not seen as a far more negative choice than one between Bernie and Biden or Warren and Bloomberg, the Democratic Party has only itself to blame.  It will be difficult enough to win even if we are united, given that money, gerrymanders, voter suppression and the structure of the system itself (electoral college, Senate apportionment by land, fixed size of House with each state guaranteed one rep, etc.) favor the Republicans. 

It is easy to become passionate about a favorite and become disappointed that our favorite was not chosen.  It feels like a personal indictment.  But that is not the main issue here:  dump Trump, ditch Mitch, regain our dignity as a nation and start moving in the right direction.  Bernie, Pete, Elizabeth, Joe, Amy, Mike, Andrew, Tom - any of them - plus a majority in the Senate and the House.  Much is at stake.

Let me say that I will vote for  whatever Democratic candidate emerges from the scrum. But the implication of this piece that the differences between the progressives and the moderates within the party don't really matter is simply wrong. Let us remember that "Third Way" or "New" Democrats have been in the saddle for three decades now. Not only has their temporizing with neoliberalism's market first (and only) solutions failed to reverse the inequality and climate change trends of the last forty years, they haven't put a noticeable dent in them. Now, unfortunately those trends have grown to the point where only drastic solutions may avert catastrophe. For those of us who agree with the take of environmentalist Bill McKibben that "winning slowly is the same as losing" the differences within the party do matter.....bigly, to borrow a term.

If only the Democrats would coalesce quickly around one candidate, and let him or her be the face and the rallying point of the party through the November election. I like, and dislike, some thing(s) about each Democratic nominee. But I haven't found my Aha! moment yet to fixate on and support one candidate. 
Admittedly, I'll vote for Spongebob Squarepants if he is he nominee of the Democratic party. But I really can't put my emotional and monetary support behind any of the candidates now. To do so would diminish my ability to provide that support (especially monetary) to the eventual Democratic nominee. C'mon Democrats, find ONE person who can capture the imagination and support of the party and those lost souls around our country who abhor Trump but haven't found a good alternative.

Wonderful piece and right on the money.  I couldn't agree more.  You clearly defined what Democrats actually stand for and that we shouldn't be fighting each other.  Let's remember that our system of government can actually work but it ALWAYS involves compromise.

I have been a Democrat all my life. Of course I will vote for whichever candidate emerges from the primaries. I would cut off my hand before I'd cast a vote for Trump. I hate what I see happening in my party right now. This year, of all years, when we should be united we seem to be coming apart. David's column speaks the truth: any of the Democratic candidates will fight for the issues important to Democrats. Please, please, please, put aside your differences and do what is necessary to defeat Trump. If he has  his way we may  not have another election to vote in. Make this one count.

"If your preferred candidate doesnâ€™t win the nomination, will you still do everything you can to deny Trump a second term?"

No, because I could never vote for a socialist like Senator Sanders or Senator Warren.

If Mike Bloomberg does not win the Democratic nomination I'm going to have to vote for Trump. Trump has many problems but he would not destroy the American economy.

I am so looking forward to the November elections and they can't get here soon enough given the speed at which Donald Trump is doing grave damage to our country. Supreme Court, Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security and Global warming. all of which are hugely important issues, to name just a few. My question would be, why would any person sit this election out and i would ask the media to refrain from going on about the differences between democrats and oh no, the iowa caucuses, who cares at this point. The only issue at stake is getting rid of Trump, that's it, perod.

I will vote for the eventual nominee if it's not "my" candidate, but I'm not likely to have the heart to work for him/her that I had for my own favorite. If the candidates belittle each other, mock each other, insult each other, or appear to try to game the system, it will be pretty hard to get us to forget all that and go forward with high enthusiasm.  We have raised the competition to such a pitch that coming together may be tougher than expected.  Bottom line:  PLEASE don't run negative campaigns against other Democrats.

The argument I have against any of these Democrats is that their soft approach leads to cities such as Chicago, San Francisco (in spite of its median wealth), and South Bend - in spite of it being a college city and Buttigieg doesn't get respect from its residents. In contrast, Trump's approach rejuvenated NYC (Giuliani), Los Angeles (the 1990s with Riordan), and I dare say the United States.

This column hits the most critical question of the election. Dems can go at each other's throats during the primary for all I care. At the end of it, I hope all Dems will see that there is one purpose that "trumps" all else. 

The problem comes when we hem and haw after the primary. That serves no purpose other than to hand the election to Trump, and we watch as America and the world take another big step backward. If you want change, suck it up and vote for the Democrat who wasn't your first choice but is your only choice come November. 

I don't want to hear from Clintonites about how Sanders didn't do enough for her in 2016. Go vote for Sanders, if he is the nominee. That includes you, Hillary!

I don't want to hear from Sanderistas about how they got shafted. Even if you think you got shafted in 2016 and in 2020, you've got to hold your nose and vote for Biden or Pete or Bloomberg or whoever. I know you'd rather make a huge jump to the left. I get it. But, if all that's on the menu is a practical modicum of left-leaning policies versus four more years of Trump, you need to wake up.

The answer to the rhetorical question is, of course, yes.  Without a Democratic senate, and (god forbid) without a Democratic house, it will be sheer hell to enact any "revolutionary" legislation.  Those who answer "no" to Bernie, or to Bloomberg, have to consider this as the safety catch.  I'm more afraid for down-ballot voting if any one of the "hold your nose" candidates is the nominee.  

And if the House and Senate are not Democratic, and the President is, we're in for the start of revenge impeachment and removal on January 21st, 2021.

I am all in for the warm body running opposite Trump. I am also all in to help anyone running against Trump disciples in the Senate. I am visualizing and working toward a Trump loss and the Senate flipping from red to blue. My bonus dream is Mitch McConnell losing his seat in the Senate.  Volunteer! Donate! Vote!

Many will not like this comment, but I don't agree with Mr. Leonhardt; there are some Democrats for whom a  Sanders or Warren nomination would create a real dilemma. If you believe, as I do, that both of them advocate policies that if adopted would be truly destructive, it is not very comforting to rely on their inability to get them enacted. 

This is an election that the Democrats should be able to win;  please don't blow it with a nomination that drives some of us away.

Vote blue. This is war. Suck it up. Do not cry in your beverage of choice. Klobuchar is my pick but I will write checks and convince my neighbors to vote blue no matter the nominee. It is all hands on deck since trump will fight dirty and cheat. Stop the niceties and nick picking policy. Vote blue. Thom Tillis, NC senator, must be thrown in the dust heap of history along with trump. Corruption must end. Vote blue. Rinse and repeat. Vote blue.

I will vote with enthusiasm for whomever the Democrats nominate for President.  Watching the last debate, I said to myself that I very much liked every single person on the stage.  In fact, I could see a composite there of a President, Vice President and Cabinet.  They all have excellent ideas, they are all very bright individuals and they all have significant accomplishments under their belts in terms of fostering a progressive agenda.

When I hear some of the moderates, like James Carville, complaining about how a progressive cannot win the White House, I wonder to myself whose team are they really on?  In this interview, he sounded more like a Republican than a Democrat.  Why is national healthcare a radical idea, when the rest of the developed world has it and it delivers better results at far less cost?  Why is a $15 minimum wage a bad idea, again, when countries like Australia have high minimum wages?  Why is free public tuition for state colleges a off-putting, when most of western Europe and parts of Asia provide this educational benefit for their citzens?

I want the most dishonest, corrupt, criminal, indecent man who has ever occupied the White House gone now.  He literally sickens me.  He has genuinely screwed up my life over the past three years, causing me great angst over the future of this country and our planet.  Trump is dangerous.  As Trump said about our Ukrainian ambassador, "get her out tomorrow-take her out."  My sentiment about Trump precisely.

James Carville had some very important words for Democrats.
He said democrats don't know how to win, because they have no idea how to fight.
He, also said that even if we win the Presidency and leave the senate to republicans, nothing will ever be done and it's back to the same quagmire of vicious cycles.
"I'm very scare" he said repeatedly at the end.
Depressing...
If Bernie is cheated out of winning the nomination again then Democrats should not be rewarded for it and his supporters should either stay home or vote for Trump in the general election

I'll vote Sanders in my state's primary. I voted for him in 2016, then voted for Clinton, whom I thought was a poor choice of candidate in spite of her qualifications. It was clear that Clinton was a polarizing figure, which is why so many Democrats supported Obama in 2008. It was a mistake for Clinton to run and for the DNC to back her in 2016. This is a failure of the party apparatus rather than any bloc of Democratic voters. Not all qualified individuals make good candidates.

I'm fed up with accusations that Sanders backers won't support anyone else. Like in 2016, the DNC is trying to undermine Sanders; a huge mistake given his strong following among young voters who should be the future of the party but they are not fools and they see how corporatist Democrats are not getting it done for their generation.

There are just as many stories about conservative Democrats not willing to support Sanders or Warren. Shall we label these people "Buttigieg Bros" and sneer at them?

I suppose this is what David is writing about though I don't  personally know any Dems who won't vote for the nominee. Instead of claiming that one candidates' supporters won't vote for the eventual nominee, we should direct our ire at the DNC, which is clearly trying to manipulate the vote once again (see John Kerry's overheard phone call) to nominate an establishment Democrat, regardless of his ability to beat Trump.

Here's the real question the Dems should be asking: why aren't you supporting a candidate who can actually win over the crucial variable in this election  -- that is, independent and traditional-Republican women?  That candidate is obviously Amy Klobuchar, whether the pundits and the woke like her or not.

I truly don't know why this should be a question in any Democrat's mind. Yes, ANY Democratic nominee will be a better president than Trump, and do less damage to the nation and the world. Sure, let's fight like hell now, during the primaries, to try to get our preferred candidate over the finish line. But once that's over, our paramount moral obligation is to make sure the eventual nominee, whoever it is, wins the election outright, and hopefully wins it decisively.

If a Democrat you didn't prefer becomes president, the nation perhaps goes in a more radical -- or less progressive -- direction than you wanted. You'll live to fight for better leaders and better policies. If Trump is reelected president, this nation, and the world, are very likely doomed. Let's do all we can to prevent that.

Oh, that's an easy one, David.  I am a charter member of the ABT party, so will gladly cast my ballot for anyone from Bernie (my choice in the primary) to Bloomberg on the Dem side. Hell, I'd vote for Romney if he were the Dem nominee.

Next question?  How about the DLC and DNC corporadem types?  Will they do the same?

The mayors of the two big cities in Silicon Valley have endorsed Bloomberg. 
Our booming economy does not need Sanders and his class warfare.

Give it a rest.  Our country is in the best fiscal shape it has enjoyed for some years.  Yes, the national debt has increased, but it has done so with visible rewards for the American worker.

I have been looking at the Democratic candidates in the run up to November's election and I do not see one of them that is capable of continuing our prosperity.  Most of them do not even have complete set of ideas as to how to run our country.  Their only pervasive push is to oust Trump.

Therefore, try not to fear a Trump re election.  Right now, you have never had it so good.

I see three choices:
-- vote for Trump and enjoy the expedited ruin of our once promising nation
-- vote for Bernie and there is hope that we the people can wrest control of our government back from the rich, powerful, elite in hopes that it will again truly represent and support us
-- vote for one of the other democrats and resign yourself to the somewhat slower road to ruin as the rich and powerful who control both parties (one side simply moreso than the other) extract what is left of this nations resources (human and otherwise)

The country would be better off in so many ways if there simply were no parties. No more perverse team mentality (Exhibit A: Trump’s impeachment). No more false solidarity. Greater intellectual diversity. Richer pre-election debates. Less package-deal advocacy. Politicians and voters would no longer have to shoehorn themselves into whichever party they object to least. 

I look forward to a day when there are a lot fewer (D)’s and (R)’s and a lot more (I)’s, and that damned tired phrase “both sides of the aisle” is rendered obsolete.

We are voting in States that's are overwhelmingly Democratic. The Electoral College almost pre-determines the outcome. We need majority voting, sincere the Country has expanded beyond the original number and is now locked in regionalism.

Of course I'll vote blue no matter who. Hell, I'd vote for a turnip against Trump. But be warned DNC: If a centrist billionaire is given a leg-up to the nomination, I suspect that many of Bernie's huge following of young supporters will be furious...to the point of never voting Democrat again in a very long while.

You damn well better believe it. I will do everything in my power to help the Democrats on my ballot win. Up and down the ballot. I’ll try of get rid of John Cornyn and try to oust Trump/Pence with whichever combination the primaries deliver. I’ll drive the poor and the elderly to the polls, put up signs, etc. I’ll do whatever I can to end this national nightmare.
Damn straight - I don’t care if Bozo the Clown is our nominee - let’s come together and stop being the party of precious purity. Let’s be the party of what is right.

Doubting Democrats need to understand that the Republicans' advantage (for now) is that they behave like true believers, not agnostics. It's understandable to recoil from hypocrisy and illogic. But there is an alternative way to think through what we need most NOW.

We need to believe in other Americans and old and new Democratic voters, like ourselves. If we're not fond of the candidate who wins the primary, or see problems with personality or the policies...okay. But we must be fond enough of other blue voters to release insistence on being "right." It's NOT more fun to be right than to be happy. We'll all be happy when the blue wave comes.

Once we have our candidate, even if you wouldn't have chosen that person, now favor your fellow blue-voting Americans. Have faith in THEM. Donate and volunteer for THEM. Bond with THEM if you can't bond with the candidate. You don't need to join a cult, you need to tap into love for your fellow blue voters. It ultimately doesn't matter who it is, as long as we believe in and support each other enough to Vote Blue, No Matter Who.

I'm agnostic but this is a time for faith. The perfect truly is the enemy of the good. If we make an imperfect choice? Show up with perfect good will and help us win our country back.

Yes, I will.  

Yes, a hundred times over, with an urgency I haven't felt in a very, very long time.

I have my preferences, but I will do as much as I can, regardless of whether it's Pete, Bernie, Amy, Elizabeth, Andrew, or Joe.  

The only thing I'd ask is that the DNC do the same - if the people choose Bernie, let it be Bernie.  If they choose Joe, let it be Joe.  If they refrain from putting their finger on the scale, we have a great chance of beating Trump.  Contrary to what many posters here are saying, there is not just one candidate that makes sense...it's not just Bernie or bust, Amy or bust, Mike Bloomberg or bust.  Everyone thinks they have the answers.  

The only way to bust is to disengage voters from the process by manipulating it.  Youth turnout was up enormously for the Iowa caucuses - let's keep the momentum rolling.

I am very disappointed that all the Democratic candidates are offering only slight variations of 2 positions on health care: Either Medicare for All or incrementally improve on the ACA starting with a public option. But other developed countries show us there are still other ways to provide universal, affordable, quality care. In 2017 a TIMES Upshot article ran a mock tournament matching up systems of 8 countries. The descriptions show a lot more variations than the candidates are offering, with the "winner," Switzerland, providing a mix of public & private insurance options but with the caveat that private insurers must provide mandated coverage on a NONPROFIT basis. (They can make a profit only on added services.) Sounds to me like a potential way to cover many more people at lower costs without scaring people that they'll lose private insurance. I'm not saying the Swiss plan is best for the U.S. But there are other potentially more effective & politically viable options than those being offered. That article looked at only 7 other countries and showed plenty of options. As voters, we deserve more options on health care in the debate. Here's the article: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/09/18/upshot/best-health-care-system-country-bracket.html?searchResultPosition=1

The present circumstances call for a set of commonsense rules for Democrats and their candidates. For example, for the candidates: Don't call the other candidates untrue things, e.g., corrupt, corporate, elite, Marxist, radical, extremist. Don't retweet the most outrageous thing you can find, out of context, about other candidates. Vigorously and publicly protect one another from the Republican lies and propaganda. Talk about how you plan to support the nominee no matter who it is. Don't make inflammatory divisive unverified claims of rigged this and that, media bias. For example, for the voters: Don't do anything that imperils your willingness to vote for the nominee no matter who it is. Be polite to other Democrats. Don't bully, browbeat, swarm online. Don't call the supporters of other candidates untrue things, e.g., Republican, DINO. Don't spread baseless conspiracy theories, e.g., the Iowa chaos was a scheme to deny Sanders a win. Finally, say it often, online and out loud in the presence of others: "I will vote for the nominee no matter who it is. They candidates are all pretty darned good." None of the candidates are centrists. They all plan to try to get significant stuff done. They agree on virtually all of the same broad general aims. As I take this article directly aimed at Sanders supports who are "Bernie or Bust", let me share this (shortened) story of one of those people (twitter @BernieOrBust)

"Two years ago I tried to kill myself. I've had five attempts since. I had a decent job. I was on a "silver" level Obamacare plan through UnitedHealthCare. That plan did not cover the treatment my doctors prescribed. It only covered 1/6th of my prescribed treatment. I was faced with a choice: fight or die.
I chose to fight.
I quit my job so that I could qualify for Medicaid.
Without income, I was forced out of my apartment.
My only income right now is a DJ gig once a month ($200). I otherwise exist off of EBT benefits. 
I've been wearing the same pair of shoes for a year. I cut my own hair. I stretch food stamps by eating ramen.
I want to go back to work. I'm a reasonably talented web/graphic designer. 
Bringing in income risks losing Medicaid. Atm, I don't feel like I ever have a chance at a normal existence. 
I don't date because I'm embarrassed about my financial situation. I don't go out because I can't afford to. I've sold my hobbies.
Bernie Sanders represents hope for me.
None of the other candidates are offering anything that would help someone in situations like mine.
I'm told that unless I "vote blue no matter who," that I'm privileged. That I'm pro-Trump. That I'm being a child. 
This is dismissive bullying. Some Americans don't have their medical privilege, financial privilege, or racial privilege."

What leaps off the page with this column is that there really are 3 political parties in this country: Republicans, Liberal Democrats, and Moderate Democrats. Combine this with the old adage that Republicans fall in line and Democrats fall in love, and it becomes obvious that this split in the Democratic plays well for the Republicans. They can count on the 2 party Dems to tear each other to shreds during the primaries, then refuse to support the candidate if he/she is not their political paramour. Meanwhile, the Republican monolith persists, everyone standing in a straight line behind Trump all the way to the horizon and beyond. 90% Republican approval rating as of this January, trending upward.

What it comes down to is exactly what Mr Leonhardt points out --- Democrats cannot win if they go into this election as 2 separate parties, each hesitant or refusing to support the other because of ideological purity. I think if you love this country and want to keep it a democracy you have to vote for any candidate but Trump.

I'll vote for anyone who wins the nomination except for Bloomberg. I know everyone is scared of Trump, but Trump is a symptom, as Yang said, not the problem. We can vote Bloomberg in, but the problems will persist, and it will just lead to another Trump in the future. Perhaps someone even worse. Would you vote for anyone over Trump? Even say, David Duke? Yes, we can have worse than Trump, and while Bloomberg is not that, I can have the dignity to say that I will not vote for someone for president I believe to be an oligarch, who once went to city hall and bought himself a third term, despite the fact that New York had repeatedly voted against third terms (for just one example).

Bloomberg is (politically) a Republican who labels himself as whatever party seems most convenient for his goals at the moment. In no way is he running left of Obama. If the new parties are now Bloomberg Republicans (the new Democrats) and the Party of Trump, then I don't have a party anymore, because I can not in good conscience vote for that man.

As an African American, I hate Trump, but I am not as afraid of him as others are. Our people have been persecuted by racist presidents and populaces for centuries. Pretty much every president before Jimmy Carter was flat-out racist, and most since have been too. I'm certainly, as a left-leaning black Democrat, not going to vote in a racist Republican who checked the Democrat box because it was politically expedient.

Not just the voters, but the candidates as well, need to internalize the idea that no one person is absolutely essential or entitled to the nomination. If you lose, you lose. Big deal. But ejecting Donald Trump and his criminal syndicate out of Washington is VITAL for America to remain the country we love. 

Dear Dems: please stop with the negative attacks. It’s alienating voters and damaging both your reputations and your electability.

The message from all the candidates needs to be: “Hi. I’m running for President and so are my friends and colleagues. We are all good, capable, moral people with an actual, positive plan for bringing America into the future. One of us is going to be nominated and defeat Trumpism. No matter who the nominee is, we will all support them, and you should too.”

Period.

Defeating Trump is my second priority.  My first is electing someone who has a plan to solve the problems that got Trump elected.  And those candidates would be Elizabeth Warren or Bernie Sanders.  Ask yourself, what did Clinton or Obama do about climate change, or big money owning our government, or good jobs for working people?   Ask yourself, do you want to waste four more years or eight?  Stick to your guns, progressives.

The current kerfuffle re the Democratic nomination for president is similar to the one in the 2016, where a ridiculous number of Democrats sat out the election or voted for a third party candidate. Behind this immature behavior is a basic misunderstanding of the democracy. Elections are not about the ideal candidate (who, by the way, never existed). Instead, American elections are about getting the best candidate, or if you prefer the glass-half-empty view, the candidate who will do the least harm. 

There is, however, another element to this season’s angst: The notion that the Democratic candidates labeled Progressives are somehow radical, in the mold of Stalin or Mao. This distortion is similar to the political cowardice of Democrats who, in recent history have run away from the “Liberal” label, which was a capitulation by Democrats to right-wing extremism that emboldened the extreme right wing, which eventually took over the Republican Party. Do Democrats today realize the extent to which their previous drift rightward has shifted the definition of the left-right continuum? Democrats bemoan the brainwashing effects of right-wing media, but do they realize the extent to which they themselves have been affected? Come on folks, the policies being advocated by Progressives are not communism or socialism, and shame on those who are caught in that web. The true test of the Democrats this year is whether they continue to fuel that distortion or whether they grow up a little.

I am so sick of Trump but he will not be the end even if he is defeated.  He has shown the path to political victory and unleashed crude dishonest and divisive tactics that have become the norm.  He has permanently divided America and ushered in an era of propaganda and deception.  We need a real revival led by honesty and integrity in this country, but there is no one to do it.  Because Trump-like tactics work on Americans from the left and right, who have lost their moral way.

Tell me where each Dem candidate stands on switching to RBT (residence based taxation) from CBT (citizenship based taxation).  I despise Trump, but I would rather sit out this election than vote for a Dem who will destroy any chance I have at a secure financial future.  Please understand that "secure" means livable and not swimming in money.

Authoritarians are generally not removed by elections.  They have to be pushed out from misconduct.  I place my bet on Trump resigning under pressure before any "election" in the US for president.  Let's be honest, Trump has the money, he has people with no ethics running data mining for his campaign, and he will do everything he can to destroy opponents unfairly.  The real action is in investigating Trump's hidden bad conduct, not agonizing what Democrat can beat him.
An excellent essay.  Argue vigorously, but keep your eye on the ball, everyone.
Amy is up and Joe is down in a recent NH poll. Potentially finishing 5th in NH, can Joe recovery? Without a moderate, can the dems really think they can beat Trump!
as someone once said.."the most important thing is to keep the most important thing the most important thing."

YES! ANYONE!

No matter who it is, he/she will restore at least some rationality, maturity,  civility, intelligence, honesty, calm strength, hope--you name it: any valued character trait that is now absent, and will remain so, if that destructive rogue Trump prevails.

This is the fundamental choice for Americans on November 3, 2020.

Looking in from the outside as an independent - why can't the debates be about what Dems can do to improve what has started - What's the plan???
No plan, no Presidency.

Dems should not have spent so much political capital defending Biden.. It was a waste.

Look, I fully believe we, the American voters will once again elect a Democrat, as we did in Nov 2016. We did our job back then, even with all the Hillary haters, the write-ins, and the grumpy SAHVoters, by a 2.75 million majority. The American people have spoken: We want progress!

The only reason we are stuck with what’s-his-bucket is because of the Electoral College, the majority of which is controlled by republicans. Okay, the Russians had a hand in it, too, but that’s a whole other issue. All this hoopla about Dems getting their act together, uniting to elect the strongest candidate, the one who can take out the little emperor, it’s all immaterial, in my view. The Electoral College is still ruled by republicans, so we’ll probably have a repeat of Nov 2016. 

What I’m hoping for is a complete unseating of most of those traitorous, spineless republican senators who are up for re-election. That is our only hope at preserving what’s left of this country, so we can at least get aback to the progress made during the Obama administration.

The state of this race is just depressing. From one side we have candidates that in pursuit of small donations from party activists have signed up for deeply unpopular policy proposals that will never see light of the day and the only purpose they serve is to alienate potential moderate voters. They claim that they will overcome that by increasing turn out, but they fail to even increase turn out in democratic primary, and wherever they have tested this turn out theory they have failed to win. On the moderate lane we have Biden which is a disaster of a candidate, and an openly gay 37 year old . Really, in an election of this importance we have to gamble that America is ready for an openly gay president? In an election that might be determined by a few thousand votes we can afford to lose potentially significant swaths of population because they simply find the candidates lifestyle objectionable? Because in the confines of our progressive bubble candidate's sexual orientation should not matter so we have to just assume it does not matter? And Klobuchar, which lacks any Charisma. It certainly looks like democratic party is headed for a Labor party style demolition on general election, unless somehow miracusly a new face emerges. Can we ask Obama to step in and save us from this predictable disaster? Desperate times call for desperate measures.
I will for anyone but Bernie whom I don't consider a Democrat or truthful and, imho, could be even worse that Trump, if that's even possible.
YES. I cannot even fathom voting for Trump over ANY Democrat in politics right now.
Sage advice but without high turnout from people under thirty, African-American and Latino voters it may be an uphill battle.

Country first! the Whistle blower did it. Vindman did it. Those who testified in the hearings did it. Romney did it. Many Cabinet members have resigned in disgust. Against the threat of career and personal destruction, they said and lived what was true. 

They were courageous and put our beautiful country, that holds such potential above their own personal ambitions. This is what voters must do now. 

The Senate jurors failed the country, and wanted to shunt off their responsibility to us voters, the "We the people" that uphold the Constitution. Now it is up to us to decide. 

We must unite, put personal preferences and policy bickering aside and vote this current president out of office.
 
Do it for country, for future generations. Vote against 45. This is what it means to be a true patriot.

Is it possible- at all- for the electorate not to passively wait for that ideal charismatic hero, take responsibility as US citizens, understand the emergency and vote for whoever is nominated? This government is OF and BY the people (as well as FOR). Obamas and Lincolns don’t always come along. We need to get back to square one- a sane President with respect for the Constitution. That is the situation, whether we like it or not. And if you stay home or vote for Trump because you didn’t get your candy- you deserve all the bad results.

As much as I detest Donald Trump and what he has done to my nation, the outcome I fear most is not Trump’s re-election, it is the election again of an extremist who inspires cult-like devotion from his supporters, and we are in danger of a ballot with two such candidates as our choice. If Democrats as a whole truly fear most Trump’s re-election, they will not nominate a candidate who does not even belong to their party and believes that he will not have to work with others, that he will so create a groundswell of support that he will impose his will on the other side (Sanders interview with NYT Editorial Board, his version of shooting someone on Fifth Avenue). If you want to defeat Donald Trump do not nominate the left wing version of him. If Bernie Sanders is the nominee, there are not enough young voters in the country who actually will turn out to replace the rank and file voters who have supported the Democratic nominee in the last three elections who will sit this one out.

If you haven't yet go look at Bloomberg's website.  He has solid plans for many of the ills facing our country.  I would consider myself a progressive and am getting behind Bloomberg and will likely vote for him in my state's primary next month.  I see him as our best chance of removing Trump in November.  Everyone who cares about our democracy needs to vote in November, and bring your friends and neighbors too.

If these were "normal" political times, we wouldn't even have to ask this question. But with the rabid devotion of true Trump believers equally matched by Sanders supporters, we seem to be headed toward more of an extreme absolutism on both sides rather than determining the best candidate for the nation as a whole. Given the similar all-or-nothing that this extremism engenders, and how radically Sanders would take the country left, with moderates wisely cautious of such a radical shift, the onus would seen to be more on Sanders supporters to support a moderate, rather than have moderates accept Sanders. And we know how that played out in 2016. Deja vu all over again?   Time will tell, though "four more years" sounds more like a possibility in that repeat scenario.

The DNC will have Bernie Sanders as their candidate. 
This time there will be no rigging of the elections in favor of Clinton as they did in 2016.

Bernie will make a wonderful candidate against Trump.

Can our Earth stand four more years of the Destroyer-in-Chief? Anyone is better than Trump. Anyone. Anyone. Anyone. To all who say they will vote third party if their candidate doesn't win, look at what's going on in Australia. Think about the Supreme Court and other courts. Do you want the Republicans to court-pack and gerrymander until kingdom come?

I'm not sure who I'll vote for in the primary. But I will support whomever is the ultimate nominee. I repeat, anyone is better than Trump. Think about the Supreme Court. The climate. Freedom. Democracy.

David, 
Absolutely.
It is easy to tell all wings of our party to coalesce around the party. It is another thing to do it.
The evangelicals support Trump but they don't really care what people will think. This is called moral bankruptcy.

If history is any measure, our party some how snatches defeat from the jaws of victory several times.
Yes, I was a wide-eyed progressive in my younger, impressionable days---I worked for McCarthy and McGovern.
I got the two Bushes, Reagan and Trump for my trouble.
The fight in 2016 was bitter and produced a flawed candidate---some of the party stayed home or voted for the other candidate and look where we are. Being true blue is one thing but I chose not to experience the last three years ever again.
I will vote for whoever gets the nomination at this point...our democracy is in the balance.

This article really doesn't correctly identify the problem, all politically engaged democrats will unite behind the nominee, there is no doubt about that.

The problem is this: will the mass of the people, those who don't have a party loyalty, and who are not politically engaged, show up to vote.  It's all about the turnout and nothing else, the Trump voters will not be persuaded, they will vote for Trump again, it's all about generating new voters, or turning out those who do not always vote.

It is near impossible for me to imagine a voter who says he voted for Trump but will vote for Biden if he's the nominee but if it's Bernie he'll vote for Trump again.  There is no sense trying to persuade an imaginary voter.   There is no sense fighting for a middle that doesn't exist. 

So, can Biden excite new voters and sometime voters to turn out, I really don't think so.  But Bernie is a proven mobilizer.

It would be great if the Dems can gain consensus a month or two before the convention to allow the "losing" half of the party to make peace with that fact and remind themselves where the real choice is. If they don't make that peace to work toward the common goal, then I think all of these conscientious readers have to understand that they are in a minority on the national level. That would be a painful realization.

At this point, I would vote for the couple who brought their cat in a backpack inside the dog park yesterday. 

But really, the specter of climate change and a rigged Supreme Court should be enough to wake any rational person up and vote for the eventual nominee.

Do panic because Democrats are like their Iowa caucus, failure born out of incompetence.  Amy Klobuchar is the only candidate that makes sense, yet she is not the leader of the pack.   Why?  Because the others want to buy an election with the promise of paying for everyone's mistakes, through taxation of the billionaire class.  Class warfare, sanctuary cities,  open borders, free college for everybody to make up for what's missed in high school,  free healthcare for everybody especially addicts.  Productive citizens know that everyone has to carry the consequences of their own actions in order to grow in life.   Not the Democrats, they  try to defy nature.  It hasn't worked in the past, and it won't work in the future.

"Moderates worry that Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren aren’t just wrong on big issues, but too left wing to get elected. Progressives worry that Pete Buttigieg, Joe Biden, Amy Klobuchar and Michael Bloomberg are uninspiring centrists who resemble recent presidential losers and wouldn’t solve America’s problems even if they won."

Why then not take a look at the one major candidate he didn't mention? Andrew Yang neither resembles past presidential losers, nor is he too left wing to get elected, but still offers ambitious solutions to America's problems.

I'm sorry, but policy really does matter.  You cannot say that universal healthcare is the same as the proposals of Biden/Klobuchar/Pete/Warren which leave millions (probably tens of millions) of people without healthcare.

AOC said it best: in any reasonable system moderate and progressive Dems would not be in the same party.  You say we're all on the same side, but, from my perspective, that's just not the case.

It is just like the class war.  The wealthy claim we shouldn't start class struggle while conducting the class war themselves at the same time.  Moderate Dems treat progressives the same way (how many times has Bernie been asked if he's planning on being a socialist dictator?).

its simple for me as my new t-shirt says "literally anyone else 2020". I will support/vote for the democratic choice on November 4,2020. I hope that those who stayed away from the poles in 2016 did so because they didn't support either candidate because they were horrible options. Now one of those horrible options will again be on the ballot, and he shouldn't be allowed a 2nd term under any circumstance. It was in 5 states that he was able to garner enough votes (80k) to take the electoral college, lets hope those democrats, republicans and independents who stayed home turn out in big numbers is those states. As I see it trump will have to hope for a repeat, as the popular vote margin was 3 million in 2016, and will be even wider in 2020, so its another electoral college win or we can send him packing. I am for the second choice. vote blue 2020!!!

Democrats must rally behind the candidate who wins the nomination, of course. 
But unless that candidate can attract votes from beyond Democrats, he/she cannot oust Trump. 
If Trump wins the next election, no reform will happen. 
In fact, things will get a whole lot worse. 
No matter how desperately needed the progressive reforms may be, Americans won't get a step nearer them unless Trump is defeated.

I will vote for the Democratic nominee no matter who it is.  There is one reason it will be easy for me to do it:  the Supreme Court is at stake.  So is the entire federal judiciary.  

Republican officeholders and voters seem to maintain a laser-like focus on what is at stake for them in each election and look beyond the defects in their nominee.  I am not endorsing their complete lack of principle or conscience in their support of Trump.  Every Democratic candidate still standing is head, shoulders and torso above Trump in every respect, so there is no devil's bargain in supporting any of them.  But the failure to understand what was at stake in 2016 (an open seat on the Supreme Court, for one thing) led too many Democrats to quibble, cavil and even refuse to vote for Clinton.  We see the result.  

Save the court, save our form of government, save our country, save ourselves.  I might even add, save the international order that the US spent 75 years building.  Do whatever is necessary to get Trump voted out.  And don't flinch.

We’ll vote for whoever wins the nomination. But I am concerned about voter enthusiasm and turnout. We must all do more than vote- we must get our friends and neighbors to vote also. It’s going to take a record turnout to overcome the advantages this incumbent president who is willing, able, and proven  to cheat to win.

The big issue is whether each Dem candidate is running because he or she wants power (like Republicans) or whether they really want to help the nation loosen the grip of GOP tyranny. If the candidates want to help the nation, then they should guarantee that they will back whoever wins the nomination.

Come on folks!  The point of this column is not to argue that all the candidates are the same, nor that we need to agree on which one may have the best chance against Trump.  The point of this column is that we are all on the same team with a shared primary goal: preventing a second term for Trump.  As an added plus, every single Dem candidate, on every single policy issue, is better than Trump.

So during the long primary season, keep it positive. Argue for your fave candidate without demonizing or turning the others into extreme caricatures. Then once the Dems have a nominee, do everything that you are able to help elect that candidate, whether or not it was your fave.  Doing so will move us at least in the direction of your policy goals AND save our republic.

The Democrats need to form a coalition ticket, with one progressive and one moderate, in whatever order works out best. All of the candidates now running have many positive things about them but all tend to appeal to one or another single demographic. To win, the ticket has to appeal to the broadest possible range of Democratic  voters, not by excluding progressives or moderates but by including both a progressive and a moderate. This would require the Democrat Party leadership to be as grown up about this as voters are being asked to be.

Yes, I will vote for whichever Democrat wins the nomination. No single candidate's agenda would be implemented in its entirety; compromise is necessary to pass legislation. It can be helpful to bear that in mind when we're tempted to over-emphasize policy disagreements.

But you know what I do worry about? The media's and the punditocracy's constant attention to and exaggeration of those disagreements, often coupled with criticism of one candidate or another. Undue attention to the "sharp elbows" in politics, as Obama used to put it, that are inevitable and generally not all that significant. The inevitable pile-on when a candidate jumps into the lead. The endless focus on the horse race aspect of the election. 

I worry that these things turn people off to one candidate or another, or to the process as a whole. that they breed cynicism and despair.

And perhaps more important:  They take the focus away from the myriad ways Donald Trump is destroying democracy and causing harm by dividing us. That's what we need to remember every.single.day until the election.

Vote Blue, No Matter Who.

My thanks to Mr Leonhardt for reminding us that no candidate is perfect on all issues.  All come with baggage and success is often found by compromise based on points of agreement.  For the sake of 77,000 votes out of ~129 million in 2016 we could have avoided the dumpster fire that is the Trump administration.

Don't let perfection become the enemy of good and remember the opposition works 24/7 planting seeds of doubt.  

If Jesus of Nazareth were the Democratic nominee the GOP would say he walks on water to cover up the fact that he can't swim...

Seek out inspiration during the primaries. If you find someone inspiring, support them aggressively. Chances are they will inspire another person or two. 

Don't try to calculate who you think others will vote for. If everyone only votes for whom they think others will vote for, then who is actually making the decision? 

But- once the nominee is decided- if your candidate isn't on the marquee, develop amnesia and quick. After that, it's defeat Trump no matter who is at the top of the ticket.

A progressive nomination will likely result in enough voters to re-elect Trump - UNLESS the VP candidate is a younger, more centerist candidate. Both Sanders and Warren are not young and a VP like Mayor Pete or Amy Klobuchor could go a long way towards balance, picking up the important middle American centerist (and otherwise Trump) voters. Conversely, a centerist nomination like Bloomberg would also need a more progressive or a female or often underserved group for VP- again there is an age issue and Mayor Pete and Amy Klobuchor are that middle America vote. Obama picking Biden as VP got him elected, while McCain selecting Sarah Palin effectively lost him the election.

Medicare for All (along with "no more private insurance") and "Tax the Rich", as polarizing concepts, may resonate with an activist portion of the voting public, but in the end, the chances of things like that actually passing the current legislative mix are slim. 

As a moderate Democrat, I like to vote for same, but would vote for a more extreme example knowing the above. Beyond "Dump Trump" as a unifying theme, I think that "restoration of the normal order", fighting corruption, and election integrity can bring people together.  I might be wrong, but still, I like to think we live in a rational country not totally consumed by cultish tendencies.

The one thing I would really like to hear all the candidates say is that they will listen to all wings of the Democratic party, that if chosen they will give a voice to the other wings of the party. I am definitely more on the progressive side but I understand the concerns of the more moderate candidates and their supporters, they have valid concerns and need to be heard. I understand the importance of being pragmatic, I know that perfection is the enemy of done. I realize that the Democratic party needs to appeal to enough people to actually win the election. 

The centrists should also acknowledge the real concerns of the left wing of the Democratic party. Bandaid solutions won't solve the problems, a little tinkering is often times just not enough. Let's remember, we're talking about the 21st century Republican party, when you start a negotiation having already made all your concessions you've already lost. 

Warren is my preferred candidate, but if my candidate doesn't get the nomination will I support the Democratic nominee? You bet I will.

There are both "negative" and "positive" stimuli in voting choices.  The "negative" here is to prevent Trump from having  2nd term.  While this is a strong driver for many, for it to be most effective, this "negative" driver should be coupled with a "positive" one, that being a message that attracts them to the candidate.  This is where the battle in the Dem party plays out.  Sanders' strong consistent message energizes the progressive wing of the party, but may be be frightening to less liberal Americans. Biden's message may be comforting to older, more moderate Dems but may be viewed as "boring", "status quo" or "too little, too late" by the progressive wing of the party. The other candidates' positions fall along a spectrum from Warren (closest to Sanders) to Klobuchar & Bennett (closest to Biden); Bloomberg & Yang are difficult to pigeon hole. This diversity of ideas w/in the Dem party is both a strength and a weakness; a weakness if Dem voters do not accept the party's nominee (as happened in 2016 with many Sanders' supporters), but a strength only if all Dems can unite behind the nominee. This is a must if the nation is to move beyond the nightmare of Trump. Each of the Dem candidates must 2 (at least 2 things): 1. clearly delineate how his/her policies differ from Trump, and 2. state that he/she will support the ultimate nominee and encourage supporters to do so too.

When I watch the Democratic "debates," I see a lineup of intelligent, knowledgeable, public-spirited people whose views on what needs to be done in America are pretty closely aligned, and I think, "Any one of these people would be better than trump." Then they start attacking each other for shortcomings that mean nothing to me: Who held a fund-raiser in a wine cave? Who voted the wrong way on legislation 20 years ago? Whose health plan is too extreme, or not extreme enough? Blah blah blah.
   I'd like to see these candidates discussing how America needs to be fixed after the damage trump has wreaked, and who can best lead us, not picking each other apart to score trivial advantage. I'd like to see Bloomberg spend his billions on helping the whole Democratic party to regain power, not putting himself in charge.
   And, yes, of course I'll vote for whichever Democrat gets the nomination.

I have worked the last several months for my preferred candidate in Iowa.  All through the house parties, canvassing and phone banking, one idea was always uppermost.  No matter who ultimately wins the nomination, we all need to pull together for the democratic nominee.  The last thing I said to my group at the caucus was "see you all in the fall for the big race".  We are also determined to bid farewell to Sen. Joni Ernst and elect one of the highly qualified dems who are running in the primary.  We need change up and down the line including state offices but also to re-elect the dem reps we sent to Washington in 2018.  Lots of work still to do.

To my fellow Democrats and progressives: Learn from the Evangelicals' embrace of Trump.  No matter who the Democratic party nominates, you must come out to canvass, persuade and vote like there's no tomorrow, because there may not be one if Trump is re-elected.  The game is about obtaining power not ideological purity.  We need to learn this from the GOP.  If they can rally around  Trump as they have, we should have no problem rallying around any one of the Democratic candidates on offer, including Mike Bloomberg.

Yes. Yes. And yes.  I will canvass, I will make phone  calls, I will take people to the polls on election day.  Regardless of who the nominee is.  She or he may not be my first choice, but any one of the Dems is a million times better than that man.
Absolutely. I like Sanders and Warren, but I'd vote for Bloomberg or Biden if either gets the nominee. Honestly, at this point, I would vote for the tooth fairy if she were the nominee.

Sometimes the menu doesn't offer a clear favorite. Or the dish we had the last time we were at this restaurant has been 86'd. So we order something and enjoy the conversation. And are pleasantly surprised. 

What we don't do is storm out of the establishment, leaving our friends behind, winding up at McDonald's for the greasy choices we already know taste terrible.

I don't know any Democrats who are struggling with this question. We want Trump out, full stop. I also don't see evidence of disunity within the party. We want Trump out, full stop. Headlines and media reports to the contrary, all the Democrats I know, along with quite a few Republicans, are just waiting out the Democratic debates and primaries so they can throw their full weight behind whoever wins. We want Trump out, full stop.

Leonhardt's framing is a rhetorical question: the answer is most obviously no. Progressives tried to take down the DNC after 2016 and there is no way the Bernie Bros back Buttigieg, let alone Biden or Klobuchar because--to state the obvious--Sanders is not part of the Democratic Party. For their party, moderate and conservative Democrats will balk at a Sanders candidacy and probably at a Warren candidacy as well. It's over. Trump wins for more years and then tears up the constitution ala Pelosi at the end of the State of the Union speech. It's over.

The real question which did not turn out well last election is will you vote for the Democratic candidate even if it is not the candidate you prefer? I will, I have not decided who I prefer right now, my politics side with Bernie right down the line up I will vote Dem like I have done all my life.

I will vote for who the Democrats nominate.

However, if either Sanders or Warren are the nominee, I am very concerned about the negative impact they would have on down ballot elections for swing district House seats and "in play" Senate seats (e.g. NC).

A couple of the Virginia congressional districts (VA-7 and VA-2) that swung Blue (and by very narrow margins) in Nov 2018 would most likely be lost with either Sanders or Warren at the top of the ticket.

I'd like to add to the discussion the idea David Leonhardt presented in his newsletter but not in his essay and that is this quote from E.J. Dionne of the Brookings Institute and the Washington Post:
“For our time, the galvanizing idea should be dignity — in our public life and politics, but also in the lives of our citizens and in the way we treat each other.”
I am currently living in Germany whose article one of their constitution translates as: "Human dignity is inviolable (or incontestable)." It's a noble statement, nobler still if it can be applied to justice, politics, human rights, environmental rights, as well as our social relations with one another. If the Democratic Party can adopt this as a creed, then I'll support whichever candidate is the clear front-runner.

The issues at stake in this election are democracy, civil decency, telling the truth and the rule of law. Everything else is important but secondary. Democratic candidates emphasizing those issues will get my vote and likely the votes of the great number of citizens who remain undecided.

When I see reports how Bernie supporters voted for Trump, or people voted straight Democratic down ballot but not for Hillary in 2016 in numbers that exceeded Trump’s margin of victory in several key states, I wonder if this was simply because the “polls” said   that Trump could never win. I do not think that will be the case this time.  There will be no luxury of a “protest” vote.

The answer is: it depends. 
If the race was fair without any manipulative interventions of the DNC and without a relentless onslaught of hit pieces (or ignoring, in the case of Warren) in the liberal media on the progressive candidates, then yes. 
So it’s looking like a no for me at the moment.

Yes, I will vote for whoever the party candidate is. But really more importantly, we need to make the Senate blue.  In most senate races the Democratic candidate has already been identified.  Now is the time to agree on messaging that will resonate with all voters, not just democrats or republicans.  I've published this before, but it stands repeating:

A good life means:

a life where you can go to church, send your children to school, go to a concert or movie, without the fear of being killed - to get guns off the streets.

a life which includes meaningful work that will support a family - a full-time job with pay that will pay the bills.  A minimum wage increase, job training, relocation help, and much more.

a life which includes affordable and good healthcare.  Don't close rural hospitals, don't drive people into bankruptcy because of a serious health condition.

a life which does not include desolation because of destruction from floods and fires - help in case of emergency and, every day, help healing climate change.

a life where children can get a good public education.  This means early life childcare, good public schools and help with college admission and expenses.

And, most importantly, respect for everyone.  We are all in this together, we need to restore our courage, respect and decency, right now.  The Republicans do not believe in these values, vote Democratic, all down the line.

"If your preferred candidate doesn’t win the nomination, will you still do everything you can to deny Trump a second term?"
    If your answer is "NO" you should be prepared to live under authoritarian rule and to say goodbye to the 240 year old experiment in democracy that used to be the light of the world.

When I consider what Trump has already done, and considering the Justice Ginsburg is ailing, I am terrified of another Trump term.  I will vote for the Democrat who wins the nomination.  I’m not in love with any of them but they all have possibilities — Sanders and Biden, Biden and Sanders, Warren and Klobuchar could be a great ticket.  Bloomberg and Buttigieg could be a great ticket.  Warren and Yang would be an acceptable ticket. I don’t want a third candidate to gum up the works.

I love it. Not only do we need field campaigners to canvass for our preferred candidates, we need field campaigners to canvas the ones who will be canvassing. But yes, when a party become like the GOP, it's only natural for the opposition to sprout many different whiskers.

We need relentless articles like this until November. Thank you. We need commitment within the party and then maybe we don't have to fall all over one another stumbling over the shape shifting  "swing" voters in the dark.

We can't lose sight that in in 2016, 3 key states had just the right amount of Sanders - trump voters to push Hillary to a win, IF they voted for Hillary. They couldn't all be party raiders.
