There are always a lot of IFs, like Hillary could have won IF those voters had just stayed home. But they didn't, so we have to make up for them and then some, IF Sanders is not nominated, although I tend to think that many of them will NOT be voting for trump a second time. But it does tell us that Sanders has crossover support because his language is not all about being "left". And now it's the "Never Bernies" we have to solicit, along with the "If Sanders is not the candidate" electorate mixture deluxe. Daunting.   

We can rid our brains of torturous non stop analytical pundits IF we all commit to vote Democrat in November. I support Warren, but I will take great pride in any Blue vote I can offer.

Since I’m a registered New York voter, it doesn’t matter whether I vote or not in the general election, or whom I vote for at all, since New York State is solidly in the blue column and all the state’s electoral votes will go to the Democrats. That’s because of our ‘wonderful’ electoral college.

You don’t compromise at the starting gate, David.

You do so when your opponent has cards.

There in nothing uncompromising about the positions of Sanders and Warren. Both have compromised, when necessary, in the past.

Moderates are all too willing to do what Obama did: punt on first down.

Desirable policies are not enough to win elections. Voters like a fighter.
This country needs to move on from where we are and where I fear we're headed. So yes, we need someone with different thinking in the White House.

Will not help either side is my answer but if it not Bloomberg and Klobuchar there is no chance for the Dems to beat the Fraudster.  Never would I vote for Trump, or Bernie, or Warren, or Yang, or Pete or Biden or Steyer.  Or any ticket with any of them on it.  Call me a purest but it is my vote and I only use it for the worthy and those who have earned the support.

Forgive the poor analogy, but our Democracy is like a grandfather clock.  There's a natural pendulum that swings back and forth, giving and then taking away leadership from elected officials and the parties that support them.  One party rule never lasts long, and often we opt in to mixed leadership scenarios as a check on absolute power.  But like a grandfather clock, the further from the center the pendulum gets, the more extreme the swings become until finally, it breaks.  Donald Trump has brought the pendulum too far to the right.  This must be corrected.  But not by bringing the pendulum too far to the left, i.e. Sanders or Warren.  Therein lies the path to breaking the clock.  I know this will enrage the democratic socialists among us, but it's what I believe.  If the party finds reason and nominates a moderate, I'll run to the polls to cast my vote.  If not, I protest and vote 3rd party.  It's that simple.

Thank you, Mr. Leonhardt, and Mr Dionne, for reminding us (Democrats) not to be spoiled children, not to tantrum when we don't get exactly what we want. We are a family - diverse, complicated, bickering over how to, and who will, lead us, to be the organizing agent to regain what the Republicans have tried to destroy - our democracy.   We must confront and combat the enormous difficulties that America, and the world, have created.  We have to see clearly, change direction radically, and find a road to a liveable society on a liveable planet.

I hope we do not have a situation as we did in 2016.
Some people just did not like Hillary Clinton and through their vote to Trump. It got personal, instead what was best for our country.
We need to let our candidates know that it is about the party stands for above what they are saying to get votes .
Let’s call it vote “greed” when the real objectives get lost.
We just watched a guilty President get acquitted because the senators did not want to loose votes. 
When is someone going to shout from the rooftops that 2020 is important for our constitution, our rights, our planet , all other items on the list are minimal in comparison.
This fighting amongst the candidates is turning voters off. 
Someone needs to rise above it , take the risk of loosing and get peoples minds focused on the bigger issues.
Trump thinks he can do whatever he wants, this is the biggest danger. The safety of our Democracy is at risk.

David,  thank-you for this article.   Heretofore,  I thought you were a dyed-in-the-wool centrist who would not consider a Sanders presidency. 

But this opinion piece highlights what is truly important in the 2020 race-- beating Trump.  He's already,  in a handful of days, added more environmental destruction,  a severely reduced Medicare budget and an enormous request for more "wall" funding to his agenda.  

It's  only February!  Imagine the destruction to come in the next 8 months (it's probably unimaginable--his diabolic ideas never cease to surprise.)

I hope your fellow editors and journalists take a note from this piece, provide balanced, fair and accurate articles about Democrats,  and avoid using charged words like "chaos" and "debacle" in association with them. 

After all,  those charged words only accurately portray the current administration.

Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! I am voting for Sen. Warren in the primary, I love her wonkishness and longstanding support for the US consumer. But, I am happy with all the candidates, and feel, as you do, that any would serve our country far better than Mr. Trump. I hope people listen to you!

I am prepared to vote for whoever the nominee is, even my least favorite.  I hear a lot of purists out there, and they will be shooting their own cause in the foot if they sit this one out.  All the candidates, whoever prevails, needs to avail themselves of the financial help Bloomberg is prepared to give to the nominee if not himself.  We need every tool in the toolbox and this is no time to sit back and let the red tide kill everything it touches.  I suggest, to heal ourselves...if a moderate is chosen, they should pair themselves with a progressive as VP and vice versa.   While people don't necessarily vote for the 2nd part of the ticket, this can temper the executive with advice about the other half of the party and what it wants to try to unite ourselves.  Candidates need to be careful about over promising an agenda that may take much longer than their own term to accomplish and make sure the voters know that or they will be seen as a disappointment bringing a right wing backlash like we experienced in 2016.

Think Overton Window.  We gotta shift things toward the left.  When the dust settles, I’ll support the nominee, Sanders included.  (Wish more of his supporters would publicly commit to doing the same.)
Job one is beating Trump, whose latest budget proposes $400B  cut to social/safety net spending.  Nor should we lose sight of down-ticket elections.

Whether you prefer royal blue over powder blue, the hue to remove is angry red.

The question is a no-brainer for my husband and me.  Yes, absolutely.  We are supporting Elizabeth Warren, but if she isn't the nominee, we will actively campaign and vote for the Democratic candidate whoever that might be.  Another four years of Trump is unthinkable.  

Wonderful essay.  Thank you, David Leonhardt!

The strategy can’t be focused on denying Trump a second term versus that of offering the American People a better option and example of leadership with policies that lift all Americans and just not the top income earners in America. The question is flawed and if it reflects the dominant thinking of the Democrats and the Media, then there is going to be more of what we currently have on November 4.

I will vote for whoever the Democratic nominee is in November. It’s a matter of principle for me and elections are sometimes about harm reduction. Each and every Democrat would be an improvement on Trump and help tangible lives. It’ll give this country a chance at least. 

But this article fundamentally does not get it. These candidates are not essentially the same. The Buttigieg’s, Bloomberg’s, and Biden’s of the country represent a status quo that got us in this mess to begin with. It drives me insane when people seem to imply Trump fell from the sky and that removing him will solve all of our problems. No, he was an inevitability thanks to everything from our poor education system, our lack of healthcare, poverty, ignorance, propaganda, our hubris from foreign policy, etc. Nominating and electing another Democrat who is friendly with corporate interests, only gives *some* people healthcare, only does the bare minimum against climate change, and does little to truly change the rules of the game will just pave the way for another Trump and/or kick the can down the road in terms of the long-term health and sustainability of this country.

The nation’s problems go far beyond Donald Trump. And they will exist after he’s gone unless we try something new. The status quo cannot continue. Try telling millions of people in poverty and without healthcare that candidates like Buttigieg and Bloomberg are the same as Warren or Sanders. We need bold, progressive ideas. For once.

Take a deep breath. Now remember: if the primaries don’t turn out as you hope, you must still join others (even if they aren't in your particular political wheelhouse) to do everything in our shared power to deny Trump a second term. And, contrary to the title of this column by Leonhardt, this is a commitment that should not be thought of as applying solely to Democrats. Now is the time to build coalitions that include not only registered Democrats, not only independents, but also those conservatives, Republicans, as well as Working Family party members and any other party you can imagine, to join together to support the candidate who will run against Trump as a Democrat.  As I just said to cousin (who probably voted for Trump last time) as they made fun of the inefficiency of some Democratic contender's health care plan, you are going to have to choose between authoritarianism and inefficiency.

I am a conservative Texas Republican....it doesn’t get more conservative than that.

If Bloomberg were to get the nomination, I’d likely vote for him. He is the only Dem who has a snowball’s chance of defeating Trump.  In the years to come, Mayor Pete looks to be the up and comer....

As for Trump, even for someone with my political leanings, three years of never-ending non-stop drama is getting old. We need some new blood at 1600 who has the credentials and ability and Bloomberg is the best alternative.

I think people stayed home during the last election because Hilary didn't excite them.  We were complacent coming off 8 years of sane government under Obama.   For some minorities having a black president meant the country had made real progress and the country was humming along.  So how far back could the next president take us?

If you were indifferent before, you aren't now.  The pro Trump camp will go to the polls to support him.  The anti-Trump camp will go to the polls to support anyone but him.  It will make a difference in this election.

I just hope that the outcome is  in favor of the Democratic party.  None of the candidates are perfect.  But any of them would be a vast improvement over trump.

For a long time, I have sought the one word that fully describes the chaos I feel in my own life that is most likely found in many others, the one word that describes what we have lost. You brought it.

Dignity.

This election must be a referendum on Trump.  
If it is to be, our nominee should not be Sanders.  We'll lose some Sanders or die voters, but Harry Truman won in 1948 after some of my relatives split off 3rd party for Norman Thomas or Henry Wallace.

We are going to need a lot more articles like this one going forward to November. It really doesn't matter who is at the top of the ticket this year. Any one of these candidates will work with a diverse and progressive Congress. Trump and the GOP will NOT.

Anyone who stays at home on Election Day to pout should be ashamed of themselves. It would be a slap in the face to those who sacrificed to obtain voting rights, and those in other nations still hoping for voting rights.  

It's time to stop arguing about who the best Democratic candidate would be. Actually, it's time to be marching in the streets (it was time a while back) and focusing on just getting this loose cannon out of the Oval Office.  It would be great if all of the Dem candidates could lead a march TOGETHER.  I'm afraid that everyone has become so inured to drama, chaos, and acrimony that we are losing sight of how to steer this ship back on some kind of course.

Sometimes things have to get much worse, before they can really get better. I'm a socialist and I almost think that Americans need to see Trump harvest all that he sowed with another term. Americans still view politics as a spectator sport, sitting on their behinds and thinking that voting to send lame proxies to DC every 2-4 years is going to save them. Democracy is a participation sport, and the players (the people) have all checked out (like any relationship, government by the people requires hard work by the people). I also fear that the next president may inherit the greatest market crash in history. Whoever is president will be blamed for it, even though it is over a decade in the making. Finally, if Trump wins legitimately then he will not have an opportunity to steal the election, taking away the worst thing he could do to the country.
To all of you Bernie supporters who say they won't vote for a moderate and maybe even quoting AOC:  She has said she will support ANY of the Democratic candidates. If AOC can get over it, so can you.

Will I vote for whoever the Democrats nominate? Yes!  At this point, Trump is the center of the media universe. There is nothing else. The sooner a Democratic frontrunner emerges, the sooner another voice can be heard above the din of Trump's endless rants. I'll express my choice of a nominee by voting in the Virginia primary, but will have no further negative comments about any of the Democratic candidates.

As much as detest Donald Trump and what he has done to my nation, the outcome I fear most is not Trump’s re-election, it is the election again of an extremist who inspires cult-like devotion from his supporters, and we are in danger of a ballot with two such candidates as our choice. If Democrats as a whole truly fear most Trump’s re-election, they will not nominate a candidate who does not even belong to their party and believes that he will not have to work with others, that he will so create a groundswell of support that he will impose his will on the other side (Sanders interview with NYT Editorial Board, his version of shooting someone on Fifth Avenue). If you want to defeat Donald Trump do not nominate the left wing version of him. If Bernie Sanders is the nominee, there are not enough young voters in the country who actually will turn out to replace the rank and file voters who have supported the Democratic nominee in the last three elections who will sit this one out.

I would like to propose a one time change to the Democratic nominating process:  draw straws. Short straw gets the nomination and all others get vp and other cabinet positions.  Then we can get to work on our actual opponent.

Much of the burden will fall on the failed candidates to actively rally support around the primary winner. While this usually happens to some degree, the stakes are high so public demonstrations of support should be stronger than they've been.

It's not only unfair but incorrect to lump Elizabeth Warren with Bernie Sanders and call her a radical. As the endorsement by the Des Moines Register well said: Warren ideas are not radical, they are right.

" but millions of Bernie Sanders supporters have already announced that they will sit out the election if he is not the nominee."
If millions of them do this,  we'll have to somehow survive another 4 years of Trump.  If Bernie doesn't get the nomination,
the real test of his character and fitness for the presidency will be how strongly he can rally them to this realization!

Democrats fall in love, Republicans fall in line.
So true, so true.
Rest assured in 2020 the Bernie Bros cult will certainly vote for Trump just like they did last time when Bernie wasn't the nominee.
So true, so true.
YES.  YES. YES I WILL.  The candidates?  I like Mike.  Mike will also campaign against Trump no matter who the nominee is. We all should.  I hope you will too.
No, I won't vote for Bloomberg.  Any of the others will be OK.  But if Bloomberg is a Democrat, I'm not.

I don't know. Sanders wants nothing short of a revolution. Do I want a revolution? Sanders is SO far to the left of me and Trump so far to the right that I can barely see any of them from where I stand.

My preferred candidate is Amy Klobuchar but I will vote for any Democrat on the ticket.  I'm saying this because any Democrat is better than any Republican and if Democrats will all vote for the nominee we can't help but win.

For those who whine about electing a Progressive I ask you to think about what we have here.  There is still Congress that any President has to get their proposed legislation through.  Our President is not a dictator (or shouldn't be) so no matter how Progressive they are they still have to contend with Congress.  Their Progressive ideas will either pass, be moderated by those in the House or shot down.  That's the beauty of debate in Congress, new ideas that will be discussed and some will be enacted, but we all take that chance  with any President.  Why worry about that now, when the threat of a Trump still in the White House for the next 4 years is so harmful?  

Oh, and stop listening to media talking non stop about the candidate infighting.   They have jobs and positions to keep.  Just VOTE BLUE.  We can do this!!!

When it works, our system is inherently conservative because of divided government. I voted for Sanders in the primaries in 2016 not because I agreed with everything he said, but that I thought Clinton was a flawed candidate--much of it unfair. I did not want him to get all of his policies passed, but I assumed that real negotiation with the other branches of Congress would protect health care and other programs but not exactly result in complete socialism. In the same way, while I didn't vote for Mitt Romney, I did not fear him, and thought that if he had won, the other branches would--as they did in Massachusetts--also keep us somewhere in the center. Right now our system of government is being challenged, and I will vote for any of the Democrats and send what money I can afford because Trump seems to be a law until himself. He's the only one who scares me because the rules do not matter to him.

Many Americans vote with their wallet, so the question is, "How are most people doing financially and do you really think they want to risk those 401K balances, home values and their jobs by supporting a Democratic nominee?"

Hard to believe that Dems will vote for any candidate. The difference is enormous. It's time to wake up to the "stealth" factor of the Sanders candidacy. He presents as a likeable if irascible grandfatherly type, but as far as his policies, he means what he says. He is a true socialist, and his ideas are a ways to the left of the Scandinavian countries that he and his followers use as examples. The appalling comments and threats from Sanders supporters on social media and else where (remember Nevada and the DNC, 2016), the glory in others suffering should his policies became enacted, these is the true Sanders crowd. When he becomes president and starts ramming through his agenda it will be just as he said he would, which no one truly believed, just like Trump.
Not only will I vote for the Democratic candidate who wins the nomination, but I will work for her or him, too.

Thank you David for this column! Please reprint every month or so because I am afraid that we Democrats will quickly fall into our "my candidate or else" positions. If all Democratic leaning voters can bring ourselves to vote for the Democratic candidate, we can win, and that is the most important thing of all.

s the last Democratic debate showed in abundance, Amy Klobuchar has what it takes to take Trump on.

She's accomplished a lot in the Senate, more than almost all senators. She's represented folks in her state very well, and ability to cut to the chase on all issues. She gets along well with others including folks from the other side of the aisle, and is balanced and reasonable.

Amy's responses on foreign policy issues during the last two debates were out of the park. And Amy hasn't changed positions on key issues like health care, and does not propose out of this world projects that have zero chance of being passed by Congress.

Most of all, she's been an honest broker on her positions from the get go, and would be the best of all candidates in putting Trump on the defensive, all while she's got that midwestern grin and wit, and yes, a , super, well honed, sense of humor.

Amy has the best chance of grabbing undecideds and knocking Trump off. And that, above all, is exactly what we need right now.

This sounds like a reasonable column, but the truth of the matter is that most "moderate" Democrats will vote for any candidate who wins the nomination, but millions of Bernie Sanders supporters have already announced that they will sit out the election if he is not the nominee.

First, as a long time Bernie supporter, I will gladly vote for whomever the nominee is.... as will every Bernie supporter that I personally know.  I'm sure there will be some holdouts (as he had around 12-15% in 2016 that didn't vote for Hillary) as every candidate will likely have some holdouts (look at Hillary's support for Obama in 2008 and compare it to Bernie's support for Hillary in 2016!).  The thing that people don't understand is that there always has been and always will be a small portion of supporters that will do this.  It's horrible and unfortunate, but one also has to understand that it's likely that that portion of Sanders voters may not and never will vote for a Democrat.  These are radical greens and radical libertarians that have always voted 3rd party.  People are losing their minds over two competing narratives; one is that Bernie is not a "true Democrat" so they're angry he's running as a Democrat.  What would they prefer, that he run as a True 3rd party candidate?  He's running as a Democrat because he knows he needs to unite if he doesn't win. Two is that people are angry that Bernie has a portion of people who won't vote for other candidates., as I mentioned, and as proven in 2016,  these people likely NEVER would have voted for a Democrat... so then he'd be bringing in more votes under a new Democrat umbrella... isn't that what we want? 
Obviously we'd like all those never-Democrat voters that Bernie brings in to still vote no matter who the nominee.
Any one of these candidates would be infinitely better than Trump.   Trump lacks one very important trait that they all have. Leadership ability.

Very importantly, Sanders has pledged to support whoever get nominated. The real problem is the electoral college. The party may be wise to focus on senatorial races and let the popular vote become a big issue post election. Especially if it is 5 or 6 million difference but they still lose the swing states. It is to be recognized that there is not a compelling candidate like Obama who can ignite a huge voter participation rate. The Rush Limbaugh thing tells you how ripped the Trump voters will be and what they are voting for.

By supporting Trump, Republicans have deprived themselves of any semblance of respectability.  This is no longer solely about the "man" occupying the Oval Office.  It is about what everything he has done, and those who support him have done, to undermine democratic principles in this country.  It is also about what they clearly intend to do in the future as the demographics of this country change in order to maintain power.  In short, I will vote for a ficus plant if it opposes Trump and the Republicans this Fall.

There are many questions Democrats have to ask themselves if they want to beat Trump. 
But most of all they need to play the same game as the Republicans – apart from partisan unity and discipline. If not, they will be blamed for another four years of Trump, who is not at all unbeatable. 
It’s time for Democrats to get their act together – be realistic and strategic. They have to reach out to voters en masse, like advertising, and convince progressives and rebels that their main focus must be  to win the White House. Everything else can be done without Trump in power.

My preferred candidate is Pete Buttigieg. Young, smart, accomplished and capable. I’ll vote for anyone else if I have to, except Sanders, whom I loathe more than I can express. Give me Sanders and I’ll stay home.

My preferred candidate is Elizabeth Warren, but I will vote for anyone who wins the Democratic nomination, and that includes Pete Buttegeig, whom I consider a lightweight and whose failure to answer competently a question about race in the last debate showed serious weakness, and Mike Bloomberg, who has his own baggage on race and whose recent conversion to concern about income inequality is hardly believable.
Trump has already done tremendous damage to this country that to unleash him  for another term should be out of the question for anyone who cares about climate change, the divide between the very rich and the rest of us, threats to Medicare and Medicaid, brutal immigration policies, feckless-or worse-foreign policy, a woman's right to choose, the raiding of the treasury by Trump and his family on their golfing vacations, and so many other disastrous policies.

All the Democrats, even the weakest, have shown they understand more about the world we are in and how to fix it than the man in the White House who has slipped out of every credible charge against him only because the Republicans will do anything not to give up power.

For those on the left, the story is always the same:  the Democratic Party establishment presents us a centrist candidate backed by corporate power and money--who many of us feel does not represent our interests--and does not offer a single concession, only this: "Vote for this candidate or the Republicans will win."  

Yes, the Democrats are merely the 2nd most corrupt party in the country. For the most part, those on the left have held their noses and voted for the party and its corporate masters with only a small minority defecting to third party candidates.  Only now that a left candidate has a reasonable chance at winning the primaries--through legitimate grassroots support--does this same dilemma pose itself as "crisis" for the establishment.   Those who supported B. Clinton, Gore, Kerry, Obama, and H. Clinton for president, who offered nothing to the left but "vote for this candidate or the Republicans will win," must promise to do the same if Bernie is the nominee.  In my opinion, the only thing new about this primary process is that the shoe is now on the other foot.  Except we are still so far from the end and Sanders might not even be the candidate.  

For everyone who is scared about beating Trump, just consider that this is a two-party system and the country is highly polarized.  Any Democratic Party nominee will be a serious contender, yes, including Bernie Sanders who beats Trump in EVERY head-to-head poll that has been taken thus far.

The problem with this analysis is that it already overlooks Iowa, where turnout was the same as in 2016. So it’s good for everyone to agree to support the nominee but as in previous wars, it’s bodies on the front line that matter. Based on Iowa, it appears that enthusiasm and motivation to replace the current POTUS just isn’t there. And I’d like to hear the candidates answer why they think that is.

If you chose to stay home because you're unhappy with your options or the process, you lose your right to complain.  Too many squander their opportunity to be heard that many around the world don't have.  Staying home guarantees Trump and the GOP another 4 years.
Without a doubt I will support the Democratic nominee and then I will push that person with all my might to make positive moves in areas of importance to me.  Job #1 is ousting Trump.

I will vote for the Democrat because it's clear to me that Republicans are not doing what is in the best interests of the majority of Americans. However, the more extreme plans of Sanders and Warren (free, free) do not appeal to me because they will sharply increase my taxes, not just those of the rich and corporations.

The author missed the real question.  Will they turn out to vote for the democratic nominee and the down ballot races if their preferred nominee doesn't get selected?  (unless you want four more years of Trump and Republicans picking up seats in Congress)

Of all the candidates on the recent debate stage and several
of those knocked out by the party's misguided divisive debate procedures,  Bernie Sanders is my last choice.  That said, I will not follow the example of some of his followers in the last election or of  Jill Stein's supporters and refuse to vote for him if he is the party's  nominated candidate.  Trump's behavior in the 4 days since his acquittal has only underscored how imperative it is to bring his vindictive tyranny, his vile vitriol,  and his self- serving  and systematic destruction of America's democratic institutions to an end.

David Leonhardt asks exactly the right question. I get annoyed when I read or hear that the Democractic primaries are chaotic. They are not chaotic, they are a signature piece of democracy. People get to have their say, pick their favorite and argue about where they want the country to go. This is incredibly healthy!

But once the primaries are over, and we pick a single candidate, every democrac has to get behind the winner and push with all they are worth to win. It's just that simple.

While I am as undecided as many other non-Republicans, I will absolutely, definitely, without equivocation vote for the Democratic party's candidate in 2020.  Trump is far more dangerous in office than any candidate running for the Democrats.  Our future and our country's future depend on this.

Do fish swim? Yes, I will do everything I can to make sure Trump loses. All Americans who want Trump gone must vote, no matter who the nominee is. Any one of the candidates is better than Trump, even the ones who are not my favorites. They are all patriots, they will not destroy our democracy. Get over the idea that this is about policy or party, it is not, it is about saving our democracy and nothing less. If you don't believe that you have not been paying attention.

This is really easy, I would love to see Amy Klobuchar as our nominee for president however I will support any person that runs against trump. I believe getting rid of trump and Moscow mitch will go a long way in bring the country back on level ground.

As the lawn sign says, "Any functioning adult 2020." Most of the Dem candidates aren't very functional, but the alternative is unthinkable. The real test of democracy here is whether American voters can swallow their spoiled, entitled preferences and get real about the infinite differences between what we have now and a government that's not totalitarian.

As a registered Independent in a swing state, I am closely watching the Democratic primary and hoping against hope that Democrats nominate someone that I can vote for in November.  It is not a forgone conclusion that I will do so.  

It has been disheartening, to say the least, that instead of rallying together, Democrats have been bludgeoning each other, and worse, creating the very caricatures that Trump will use to sow doubt about his eventual opponent.  And the idea of "party unity" eventually working itself out seems laughable.  Does anyone really believe that Sanders supporters would support a Biden or a Mayor Pete?  Or that Warren supporters will gladly embrace Sanders after their falling out?  Or that moderates, who make up the majority of Democratic voters, will embrace Sanders's platform?  

Nope.  Nada.  No way.  

What we are careening toward is a fractured Democratic party, at a time when it's never been more important for the party to rally together.  Most importantly, the far left of the Party wants to pretend it's actually the center because of a specious argument about European socialism.  This flank of the Party has never been more emboldened and more tone deaf to the limitations of their message and it's appeal.  But Sanders isn't FDR and elections are won in the Electoral College, not by having more Blue voters in already Blue states.  Unfortunately, I fear that a Sanders primary victory will mean 4 more years of Trump.  I know I can't vote for Sanders.

My wife and I will certainly vote for any Democrat who becomes the nominee, as we have in the past. 

I like the perspective of the article: a call to reason and perspective is always crucial.

But I fear that the seeming monomania of the Trump Republicans has a great weight advantage over the many intense differences of the Democrats. That may change. But emotion always beats reason. And Trump's call to outrage and other nationalist traits may well trounce any policy agreements Democrats concur on. 

I want to hold to hope above despair. But I'm losing my grip.

Maybe I'm living in a different world, but I thought we had already decided. We will vote Democratic no matter who the candidate turned out to be. That is "Vote blue no matter who". It won't be as easy as it sounds and we have to be sure there are no really vicious fights. But I think we can certainly do it, given the stakes.
Thanks for putting into words the "feelings of facts" We need consensus and everyone needs to step back so we can move forward together.  Go Blue!
What worries me is that voters will stay home or vote for a 3rd party candidate.  That is the same as voting for Trump.

The right question to as is whether or not the DNC is prepared to get behind a Democratic Socialist in order to deny Trump a second term.  Separate from this, your question is otherwise moot, because no Democrat can win against Trump without the black vote. this excludes both Bloomberg and Buttigieg.  So let's hope the DNC can get with the popular program - otherwise all hope is lost.

I don't think that my preferred candidate will be on the ticket --- but I'm going to put that aside. Unfortunately, I've talked to people and have read social media posts, especially from Bernie supporters, who have said they won't vote if their candidate is not on the ticket. When asked if they minded that their absent vote was essentially a vote for Trump they didn't seem to mind. I hope to see record turnouts for this election. I don't care if I have to wait on line for three hours. Last presidential election in Bridgeport, CT I did not have to wait at all to vote, I just walked right in... I was absolutely stunned! We had so much to lose by staying home and yet people did not vote... and look what it gave us.

Bravo! Outstanding article. You have certainly changed my thinking. I had already decided that I would vote for any of the current candidates, regardless of my preferences in the primaries. Now I will also enthusiastically campaign for the ultimate candidate. I agree that we have much more in common in our core values, whether we support Sanders, or Pete, or Warren, or Biden.

Clearly the answer to the question posed in this column is no. Mrs. Clinton lost the last election because disappointed Democratic primary voters stayed home. Considering the total lack of leadership in the Democratic Party led by clueless Tom Perez, we are heading towards a second and more disastrous Trump presidency.

Let the primary voters decide.  All this talking head angst and Democratic establishment angst about Sanders voters is an effort to panic the party.  All this talk that Sanders is against a woman winning the presidency and that his supporters bolted to Trump in 2016 are typical.  Let the primaries decide.  Everybody knows that the objective is to defeat Trump.

Yes. Any of the candidates will be a better president than Trump. Personally, I favor Warren. I hope she runs a campaign based on truth and honesty. I hope she sheds a bright light on Trump's dishonesty. I hope she tells the Right-to-life voters that while she supports choice that she respects their view and that she assures them that all children will have a better life and future with her as president. I hope she promises no litmus test for judges, but will appoint judges who uphold the law fairly to all. 
And since we can no longer trust in our national presidential elections, I hope the Democrats will go all out to take control of the Senate and keep control of the House. That way if Trump does win, he won't be able to keep being "Trump."

YES!  This should be the time for ALL Democrats to put aside individual wants and preferences and vote for who ever is chosen as the Democratic candidate for President.  No candidate will be perfect, but I will be honored to vote for that candidate, primarily to vote Trump out off office and to put back some semblance of decorum, diplomacy, honesty, and intelligence in the Oval Office.  It will be an easy decision for me, but it should also be an simple decision for every other voter who has been horrified with the last three years.  Our votes are the only thing that can stop Trump!

I think it is plain to see that no one on the stage last week will ever be the nominee or president for that matter. Americans do not want progressives that are pledged to tank our robust economy. And the rest paying homage to the 3Rs, racism, redistribution And reparations play poorly with the majority of Americans. The Democrats on stage last week painted a very dire picture of what America is, and that also will not sell well. It seems like Mike Bloomberg is waiting in the wings, and the DNC will ensure that he is the nominee.

There are also some of us who can agree with some of the Sanders/Warren agenda (universal healthcare), but believe that it is not doable in one fell swoop, that we risk too much in trying to pull the table cloth out from under the dishes, that moving the ball in the right direction is better than going for broke and coming up with nothing at all. 

As to voting for whomever the nominee is - I will do just that. I have absolutely NO patience with Dems who are whining that if their candidate does not get the nomination they will stay home or (incomprehensibly) vote for Trump.

I have read enough of these posts to put me in despair about human intelligence. Bloomberg the billionaire, and candidates taking money from corporations, are the solution to problems I think we can--or should be able to--agree on, like wealth inequality? I went to college, but I guess I still am not smart enough to figure that one out.
For me, there is a paramount issue - removal of Donald Trump from the White House. It doesn't matter who is the DNC nominee - we'll be moving the nation in a better direction by voting for her/him.
I am curious.  In which states do Sander's supports votes truly matter.  Are they from blue states already decided, or will their vote  alter the electoral college and swing purple states?

Your columnist wrote an excellent article.  I take issue with one thing he said.  He wrote that if your candidate for the nomination is not selected  "will you still do everything in your power to deny Trump a second term?"  

Everything in my power?  Put the rest of my life on hold?  I won't even do that if my choice for President is nominated.  What I will do is work for the Democrat, give money to the Democrat, write and speak for the Democrat, but "everything in my power"?  No.

I feel sad reading some of these comments that clearly show that their authors don't "get" what you're trying to tell them. I, FOR ONE, PLEDGE TO DO EVERYTHING I CAN TO SUPPORT WHICHEVER CANDIDATE THE DEMOCRATS NOMINATE, and I would like others, including the candidates, to  do the same NOW.  As far as I can tell, none of the candidates is a saint, but all are competent, ethical human beings who believe in democracy and the rule of law.  Which makes it a no-brainer when it comes to choosing between them and the current occupant of the White House. A second Trump term would be a disaster, folks--wake up!

(Part 2... if I may.)

Because of corruption in our party (and mainstream media) in 2016, the Sanders campaign astutely demanded that the voting records be kept - classic progressive activism.  Because of this, we now see the extent of party manipulation and its damage will be mediated.  We now have a magnifying glass on Iowa and need to keep it there.  We have an opportunity to correct deep-seated party corruption (such as "State Delegate Equivalents", doled out to the counties by the party) which could allow the nomination of the candidate truly preferred by the people this year and in future years.

In Iowa we have a candidate, Bernie Sanders, who is clearly the most popular in both counts (which are now recorded).  Yet we are still told by the party and mainstream media to accept their declarations based on measures we now know are contrived.  But thanks to social and other new forms of media we can announce that the emperor is stark naked - and this is a prerequisite for progressive reform, imo.

In short, restoring democracy is the best way to change the conditions that have fueled Trump's campaign, imo.  Restoring democracy may likewise be the only way that major economic and environmental reforms, desperately needed, will occur.

Trump's reelection is not the outcome that THIS Democrat fears most.  I'm more concerned about the integrity of our democracy than four more years of Trump.

The establishment's dire predictions of Trump's first administration (along with basically all their other predictions regarding Trump) were remarkably wrong.  Four years of Trump is, infact, not as troubling of a prospect as it was three years ago.  This reality needs to be acknowledged and incorporated into our views.  Demonizing Trump is simply a losing strategy - as was supporting Hillary Clinton for president.  If we refuse to accept these emprically-supported truths then we will almost certainly guarantee four years of Trump again.

What just happened in Iowa revealed how corrupt our party is now - and was in 2016 (and surely before that).  In a two-party system, if either one (or both) of the parties is corrupt the prospect for democracy is slim.

In a perfect world,  I like Warren but right now the  world is imperfect and the democrats need a candidate that never Trump republicans will vote for.  That person is Michael Bloomberg with Amy Klobuchar as his running mate.

Whoever the Democratic nominee is, he or she would be wise to follow Lincoln’s example and create a ‘team of rivals’ by using their running mates in key positions and get their followers onboard. We cannot have four more years of trump.

We don't need the "Russians" to interfere with our fair elections or undermine confidence in our democratic process. We have always been perfectly capable of doing that all on our own. Investigate how Sanders was treated by the DNC in 2016. I think Iowa clearly demonstrated this again the last couple of weeks. Now the DNC wants all of Iowa to recount. Can we just pick some foreign power to blame this on its so much easier for us to rally around that.

The Sanders supporters will not fully back the Party if he is not nominated. They are becoming a cult like the President's enablers. Many, if not most voters, vote their pocketbook. Democrats have to appeal to voters on issues not basically economic. The votes will not trade in a decent economy for Sander's socialism.

Here is the reality: People will not vote for anyone who will impact their financial future.
Everyone of the Democrat candidates has positioned themselves to shrink our economy with their proposed actions on taxes, regulation and spending.
My investments, 401K and other assets lead me to vote for the person who will continue the growth of them.
Selfish? Maybe. But, I have to look out for me and mine. And I will.

--  let's assume the anybody-but-trumpers make up about 40 percent of the electorate, and the nobody-but-trumpers make up another 40 percent -- that means the election will be decided by the 20 percent in the middle -- i'm skeptical that a progressive like elizabeth warren or bernie sanders can win a majority of that moderate 20 percent, which is why i'm supporting mike bloomberg, and hoping he picks amy klobuchar as his running mate -- remember, beating trump really is no. 1 --

One thing that went unmentioned in this column is the probable retirement of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg during the next administration. 
Those disappointed Democrats who would rather stay home than vote for a candidate they did not choose in the primary will help set the Supreme Court into an immovable partisan conservatism that will last a generation. What a way to "stand on principle"!

Here is the reality: People will not vote for anyone who will impact their financial future.
Everyone of the Democrat candidates has positioned themselves to shrink our economy with their proposed actions on taxes, regulation and spending.
My investments, 401K and other assets lead me to vote for the person who will continue the growth of them.
Selfish? Maybe. But, I have to look out for me and mine. And I will.

I would think that it is an easy Yes even for the most die-hard Bernie supporters. The gulf between the parties has not been wider since the Civil War. There is not a single issue that even the most left leaning voter wouldn't have to leap-frog over Buttigieg or Bloomberg to land on Trump. 

The issue now is getting out the vote and supporting Democrats at the state and local level. Turning the Senate and holding the House should be an equally high priority.

Inasmuch as I don't have a particular favorite right now because all the candidates have good ideals and ideas that could altogether make a strong case against the Republican machine, there is no question that the most important task at hand is to defeat the Elephant in the room. Some candidates say that should they lose the nomination, they will support the nominee. Are we  sure that they actually do what they say? I agree with Mr. Leonhardt  that we do need to take a deep breath but it feels like climbing a mountain when " the Four Horsemen of calumny, fear, ignorance and bigotry" are knocking you down at every turn.

Will Hutton of The Guardian had an interesting column Sunday titled, "If the Democrats really want to unseat Trump, they must form a credible coalition"

It's worth a look. A good analysis of how Labour lost to the Tories and some good advice on not doing the same. 
I won't spoil it by giving Hutton's current idea of such a coalition.

Hutton's closing, "Wish the Democrats luck – the impact of another Trump term, on not just the US but the world, are too destructive to contemplate."

"If your preferred candidate doesn’t win the nomination, will you still do everything you can to deny Trump a second term?"

Straight-up answer: Not necessarily.  There are some democrats I find completely unacceptable, including Warren and Sanders, and I will have to think hard before I cast a vote for them.

Great article. Why am I getting the feeling the Democratic nominees are weakening the party’s position by the infighting. The criticisms and attacks are not productive- just the opposite - they may encourage moderates to vote for Trump. The final candidates are digging in and saying anything they can to salvage what’s left of their campaign. However, in doing so, continue alienating voters who haven’t decided which direction they’re going. The candidates need to show that solidarity against Trump - if they don’t, it may be too late.

Amen.  To those who somehow doubt the truth of Mr. Leonhardt's column, let me pose three questions.

If Mr. Trump wins a second term, will we see politicians jailed because he dislikes them?

If he wins a second term what will happen if GDP numbers or job growth numbers turn negative.  Will he tell the BEA or the DOL to produce "better" numbers?

How about culling voter registration lists.  How many more voters will be dropped for no good reason?

Unite behind the Democratic nominee?  Done deal for me.  Figure it out Democrats.  It's not that hard!

The right, in order to win over centrist Democrats, is not trying to get the most left-leaning possible Republican nominated.  That’s sounds crazy, but that’s essentially the Democratic game plan - Sanders is too far left! Republicans are nominating the most far-right, some would say fascist, anti-left, divisive candidate they can find. At some point, one has to realize this isn’t not a country that’s will be saved by compromises. I thought that point was when Hillary couldn’t get elected. Yes, I’ll vote “not Trump,” but the center needs to move left.
Will Bernie's supporters accept it if he doesn't win? Same question as last time...

My answer to your question is-- 100%  YES and that should be the answer for everyone in this country who hopes to drive trump from office. For the sake of the country's democratic institutions , values and the Constitution trump has to be stopped.

@ Mike from Virginia (who describes what the Republicans have achieved)


I do not disagree but I question a nation that voted Trump in to begin with.  Do they understand what they caused?  Your list is to their liking?  If they were hoodwinked won’t they be again?  If they weren’t but just believe in the nation we became, what choice do we have?  Split the nation into two?

Will I do everything I can to help the nominee, whoever he or she is, to win? You bet I will. Bloomberg is my favored candidate by far, as I think he can win key Electoral College states and because I have been   impressed by his campaign and campaign staff here in Ohio. But, even if it’s someone else, I will canvass and do all I can to get the vote out. Unlike Trump, each and every Democrat loves our country and believes in the rule of law.  Any of them deserves the honor of the highest office of the land, far more than the thuggish, dangerous character occupying the White House.

Defeating Trump must be  the one clear goal of every patriotic American, whether Democrat or Republican. Let's join hands and energies to restore the rule of law, decency and respect for truth and science. Let's stand united on the Old North Bridge to defeat tyranny! Although I admire Elizabeth Warren with all my heart and although I share many of Bernie's hopes for a more  progressive society, I will vote for Mike Bloomberg in the Massachusetts primary on March 3. Bloomberg is smart, experienced and made of steel. He has excellent ideas regarding climate change and a reasonable approach to expanding medicare. He has the best chance to form a broad and effective coalition of American patriots against Trump.

I wish we could stop fretting about  'candidate electability'. It gets in the way of clear thinking. 
If 2016 has taught us anything, it's that anyone is electable - when people unite to elect them. 

A sufficient number of Republicans kept their eyes on the prize, held their nose, voted for Trump, and won big. 

A sufficient number of Democrats sat on their hands rather than vote for Clinton, even against Trump, and lost the Supreme Court, federal bench, climate accords, Iran nuclear agreement ...

I guess they had their reasons. They still do. And none are worth electing Trump. Again.
In all honesty, if trump and  the Republicans win again, we are done as a republic. The next supreme court pick will be a theocrat, and the rule of law will be a thing of the past.

Mr. Leonhardt, you hit the nail on the head. 

For so many democrats, self included, the primary objective is to ensure a democratic victory.  

It is crucial that democrats come out in droves to support the democratic nominees - for President, for Congress, for Governor, for all local offices. 

Vote Blue! Vote Blue! Vote Blue!
Hopefully there will be a progressive and a moderate on the ticket.  We Democrats come all kinds, and we need everyone voting in November.

I can't imagine anything worse than not voting for any candidate other than Trump. What would be gained by saying 'this person' or no one else? We then end up with an even more dangerous president than this country has ever seen--one recently encouraged to do whatever he wants because of the myth now being propagated that his acquittal gives him even more power.

I am going for my first pick despite calls to pick a different "more electable" candidate.  But will ultimately vote for WHOMEVER gets the nomination, and will actively encourage anyone and everyone I know to do the same.  And if DJT wins the next election because Democrats couldn't rally behind one candidate and thus people sat at home, I will renounce my Democratic party affiliation.

The debate format should be limited, so that the candidates could also have numerous long meetings filmed by CSPAN discussing specific policy improvements - without orchestration by television networks.

Certainly Trump needs to be defeated. But, unless we elect a leader capable and willing to stand up to the enormous power of major corporations on climate issues and economic policy, it won't make much difference for us as a country.

The only non-GOP people on planet earth that we don't know the answer to your question are the Bernie Bros.

"Abraham (renown psychologist) then argued for oral sources of character. Those who have been overly gratified in this stage expected to be fed and given to at all times. Optimists, they expected the world to satisfy their yearnings, but when exposed to frustration, they become demanding, aggressive, and devouring."   

Quoted from Makari

Yes.  I would vote for almost anyone the Democrats run.

I might not like everything in the platform of the Democratic candidate, but far more important at this point in time is to stop the Republicans.

I don't mean just stopping Trump.  I think it has been made abundantly clear that almost the entire Republican Party is behind him and they must be removed, while there is still time.

We need an at least two-party system.  The Republican Party must be replaced with another party.  But they have to go, and I am willing to tolerate a certain amount of damage to achieve that goal.

For an example of a worst-case scenario, to me, let's say Tulsi Gabbard miraculously gets the nomination, and a day later admits that she has a major drug addiction.  I would give her the maximum campaign donation and go door-to-door in Pennsylvania to convince people to give her a chance.
As we used to say in the '70s, '80s, '90s, and early 21st century, I will hold my nose and vote for anyone with a D next to their name, especially in the Senate.
One answer - yes, I will vote for the eventual nominee.  I will also cast a vote toward getting rid of Mitch McConnell by voting for the Democrat running for against my current Republican Senator.

Alas, I think Bernie, the GOP-preferred candidate,  has no chance to win. I also think country is way more homophobic ourside of coastal cities. Millennials, the loudest Dems, the bullhorn Dems, not particularly good at imagining others, particularly the less sophisticated with whom they must reach & make common cause. I support ANY blue candidate but some with a wry shrug of an existential shoulder & no expectation of victory.
An easy question, with an easy answer!  Yes, just like 4 years ago when I voted for Bernie in the primary and Hillary in Nov.  and I am sure most Dems feel the same.

I don't know if Leonhardt is right about the progressivism of the so-called centrists or the moderation of the so-called leftists (he is correct that those supposed radicals would fit in nicely with the Eisenhower Republicans of the mid-1950s). However, I do know that Trump and the current GOP represent a existential threat to the Republic, and that any "third party" vote is actually a vote for Trump, so whoever the nominee may be I intend to vote "blue" straight down the ticket.

Absolutely not. For me Sanders is the last (real) opportunity for a chance to turn this thing around. Otherwise, I've had quite enough, thank you. As for Trump, he won't be my president when I'm a citizen elsewhere, but he'll be yours.

There are also two elephants in the room no one is talking about.  All the states that Trump won in 2016 have a large contingent of "social conservatives", regardless of what their political views are.

 One reason Hillary was edged out in those states was the most obvious one, her gender.  The "social conservatives" were not ready to accept a woman as the nation's leader as that is not a woman's job in their mind.  Living in one of those states in an area dominated by "social conservatives" that was an item that was brought up more often than not.  So, in 2020, will people be fed up enough to think different and vote for a woman?

The other elephant, in these states with a large contingent of "social conservatives" will most certainly not accept someone on the ticket with an "alternate lifestyle" and would hand Trump a second term on a platter if Pete were to be on the ticket.  These people are certainly not that enlightened no matter how bad Trump is and will certainly bring out the Trump Party voters in droves and would even flip Democrats in those areas, as distasteful as it would be, to prevent such a person from holding office.

We all need to remember one thing.  Trump won because many voters who didn't like Hillary held their nose and voted for Trump.  We need to make absolutely sure that does not happen on our side.  And we cannot allow an intra-party squabble to develop.  If Bernie or Biden or Warren loses the nomination, having a hissy fit and going home and refusing to vote for the nominee  will accomplish nothing of the agenda.  It seals the deal for Trump.  Vote like your life depends on it.  Because it very well may.  If you want to send the Republicans packing, all it takes is a little time and effort to go vote.  You don't have to march in the streets.  You don't have to donate tons of money.  You don't have to put signs on your lawn.  You don't have to go to rallies.  All you need to do is vote.  And if you need a ride, phone a friend or call the League of Women Voters or the Democratic party.  Someone will help you.  Or apply for an absentee ballot you can mail in.  There are ways to do it.  All you need to sacrifice is a little of your time.

I think the Democrats need to change their slogans and tactics.  The GOP has successfully campaigned using the "War on....." . So tear a page out of the GOP handbook and turn it again them.  Talk about the GOP war on children by using decimation of the variety health and education resources, the Democrats can talk about the GOP war on the future by using the way the EPA and Dept. of the Interior have loosened rules to allow raw sewage to enter the water system, talk about the GOP war on religion by allowing development on Native American sacred site. The possibilities are almost endless. I will vote in November and it won't, most assuredly, be Republican.

First, let's get rid of this "Bernie Bros" myth.

Second, there is much more compelling evidence to note vote for Trump than there was four years ago.

Third, Bloomberg has to drop out before he becomes another Ralph Nader.

This could come down to those same swing voters in WI, MI, and OH.

"Moderates, for their part, are right that every great progressive victory in American history — abolition, women’s suffrage, the income tax, labor rights, Social Security, civil rights, Medicare, marriage equality and more — has required compromise in the service of persuading allies who disagree with progressives on other issues. "  

You missed the central element to ALL these progressive victories-- mass movements of people MAKING them happen.  Do you think women's suffrage or civil rights happened simply because of some compromises in Congress?  They happened because millions of people marched, protested, and even got arrested for causes they believed in.

There is ONE candidate who understands this, and that's why I'm 100% behind Bernie.  If he fails to get the nomination, I'll vote for another Democrat-- but let's not pretend all are equal OR that sweeping change happens simply through congressional compromise.
If Sanders or Warren get the nomination, I will do what I did in 2016, vote for the Libertarian candidate.

That's the right question, but it's not broad enough. If we want to stop phenomena like Trumpism (or Brexit here in the UK), those of us who occupy the university-educated centrre-left not only have to knock on doors during elections to help anyone who opposes him, but knock ourselves on the head and ask how our attitudes have helped enable him. We--and the NYT is especially bad about this--drip into political and cultural debate that we think anyone who doesn't actively agree with us (especially if white) is a lesser sort of human being. We're like undergraduate film theorists sneering at the "fascists" who run the small businesses just outside campus. We think we're shocking the bourgeoisie, but we are the bourgeoisie. Really we're like Victorians lamenting the presumed inadequacy of the improperly educated and the vulgar.

I've already resigned myself to voting Democratic. Maybe not enthusiastically but a vote all the same. The only exception is if there's foul play in the primary again. If the DNC works to actively sabotage progressives, I'll write-in my vote. There's a good chance this may happen. 1 in 4 to be exact.

Mike Bloomberg's entire campaign is premised on forcing a brokered convention. A situation which could very well deny progressives the nomination despite leading in delegates. An outcome we all know would cause Sanders supporters to stay home. A situation which obviously leads to Trump's reelection. Democrats need to tread very carefully.

If moderates can't win on a straight majority, they need to consolidate around the progressive candidate. A brokered convention is going to destroy any candidate's election chances.

Amen. Please repeat this over and over. Thanks for pointing out the common goals of progressive and moderates. And remind everyone daily to keep their eye on the prize: ridding the White House of the monster within.

Thank you, thank you for a reasonably balanced commentary.  But its's much too early for this.  It's perfectly healthy for candidates and their supporters to fight it out on policy on a primary campaign.  That way, the voting public gain a much better understanding of what they're getting from the candidates.  Moreover, a feisty campaign will prepare the winner for the nuclear onslaught that will come from Trump.

But let's avoid the personal attacks.  Stick to policy and everything will be fine.

Well I sure hope so, but like last time the Bernie supporters went to the Green Party of of Climate Action.  This is why the DNC makes me so frustrated, bc this is the number 1 problem for us.  Leave RvW for the RNC.  We care about over all planet, and if they don’t work on this for the young ones it’ll be lost.  UNLESS they learned their lesson and this is what they got.  Even worse than Hillary.

Enthusiastically pulling together to beat Trump should be an issue that should have been asked to all candidates in all the debates.  Encouraging supporters wholeheartedly to get on board with the nominee.

I don't personally know any Democrats or Independents who think otherwise. Voters I know are resolute to defeat Trump. Direct this where there is some doubt: at your fellow columnists, pundits and, yes, even supposedly "objective" journalists. 

And you might as well be explicit instead of dancing around the issue, because "anxiety about the Democratic nominee" emanates primarily from the "liberal" corporate media and is code for Sanders, now, as it was code for Warren when she was riding high, before she was systematically trashed in that media and these pages for three consecutive weeks. Congratulations. Job well done. That didn't save Biden from himself and got you Sanders on top. 

You might try reassuring the voters you all have been stoking with said "anxiety" that all the policy doomsdays you have been exciting them about will be hashed out in a Congress that is not going to change all that much even if Democrats retake the Senate, as they must. Despite Trump's authoritarian-wannabe example and some candidates' rash promises to "get things done," no Democratic nominee is going to rule as President by executive fiat.

And while you are at it, you might try inveighing against all the obsessive reporting about what Trump voters think in this or that Podunk diner. What Trump or Trump-leaning voters think is irrelevant. They are not persuadable. The only thing that matters is that the rest of us turn out to defeat Trump. The votes are there. We just have to show up.

Won't matter.
Remember that Hillary actually won by close to 3 million votes.
Funny thing, she isn't president today.  Why is that?
It's called the Electoral College where regardless of what the popular vote is, it, the Electoral College selects the president.  
That WILL happen this time as well.
And so will gerrymandering and voter restriction assist with selecting a president.  
It doesn't matter who I vote for, Illinois will select the Democrat.
It doesn't matter who my sister votes for, Alabama will select the Republican.
It's only a few states that matter.

Advise to Democratic Candidates: stop putting the other candidates down a tell us WHAT YOU ARE GOING TO DO TO UNITE THE COUNTRY. Example of when and how you have and will do this.

Do not criticize the other candidates, start with hope end with winning.we are all tried of hearing bad stuff about others, trump has worn us out with ugly comments, bulling. Even his supports are getting tried of it. 2/3 of the nation are ready for something positive. Lead with hope, courage and love for America.

This may not be your time to be President. I know you believe, we must stop trump. Get behind American and work to make this happen, no matter who is the CANDIDATE, it want be most of you.

We must support whoever wins the Democratic ticket. But why not nominate Bloomberg, the sure bet to win against Trump? 

In debates the sizzle is as important as the steak. So going into the debate against Trump's pumped up sizzle means Biden, the current front runner is most likely to loose the sizzle part of the debate. We need a Democratic candidate who is sure to win the sizzle as well as the steak against Trump. Amongst the current contenders for the White House Bloomberg's multidimensional out standing successes are themselves the biggest out of the box sizzles that will ensure that his mere presence against Trump on the debate stage will out sizzle Trump's life's accomplishments' sizzle toe to toe.
We need to insure that the Democratic candidate is a sure winner in all aspects and the only one who measures up with a guaranteed win is Bloomberg.
Only IF the process is fair this time around.  Bernie wins it like he did in 2016 and gets denied again, then no.

Don't panic.  This is how it always is with primaries, then one person is chosen and we all have time to calm down and get behind that candidate (barring any shenanigans by the DNC that make the results appear unfair). At the last debate, all the candidates indicated that they would get behind the winner and support him or her. Hopefully voters will follow their example.

Mr. Leonhardt - this is exactly what everyone here needs to hear.    I agree wholeheartedly and could not have said it better myself.

Am I the only one that likes all of our candidates?  They are all left of center on the issues and they are all thoughtful and qualified.  Our goal should be to try to find the combo that has the best chance of going all the way.  

I for one will put everything I have into this, whether its Bernie, Biden or anyone in between.

We are in desperate times and desperate times require sacrifices.  I would vote for any of the Democratic candidates  as they are all reasonable, decent individuals.  Their policies whether more liberal or centrist will be tempered by Congress and reality of the democratic process anyway.  No President gets what he or she campaigned for. Why do we forget that?

When you vote Democrat in this coming election know that you are voting for an idea, not a person. For no person in the current field can come close to the sheer personal force of nature that Trump is. 

Whatever one thinks of the morality of his many questionable actions they’ve included his winning the general election, steamrolling two major political parties and dominating one, outliving the Mueller Russia investigation, numerous attempts to make his tax returns public, and survival of the impeachment inquiry, trial and his subsequent acquittal. He’s presiding over a very strong economy, has taken China down a notch in his recent trade war moves and he’s now moving across the political landscape tank-like in his dogged pursuit of a second term. Taking no prisoners along his way, much to the chagrin of his critics.

In 1968 I was a 24 year old supporter of Eugene McCarthy for the Democratic nomination. When then-V.P. Hubert Humphrey got the nomination I was livid. Humphrey refused to distance himself from LBJ's insidious support of the unwinnable war in Viet Nam. And, like many liberal graduate students, I was too pure and uncorruptible to support Humphrey.

Now, in contrast to refusing to abandon LBJ's Viet Nam policies, Humphrey was a life-long liberal: he was correct on labor, correct on civil rights, corret on every issue a liberal Democrat could name.

But I wouldn't budge. I stayed home in November 1968. In other words, because I was so righteous, so above compromise, so stalwart in my beliefs, I helped give the nation to Richard Nixon. I was thus resposible (in part) for the Southern Strategy that has riven American politics ever since and other reactionary policies -- including other needless wars -- that have damaged America for the last half century. 

Guess who I'm voting for in 2020? WHOEVER the Democrats nominate. I  learned my lesson the hard way. You don't have to.

Well David, I think you are way off on the comparison of Eisenhower's to a potential Sanders or Warren administration.  For one, Eisenhower was a fiscal conservative who maintained a balanced budget.  Nothing about Medicare for All, especially Bernie's no specifics on how to pay for a $4T year program (with a failing Federal agency that reimburses so little that rural clinics are closing) would create a balanced budget, nor would Elizabeth's Constitutionally questionable wealth tax.  Our current proposed Federal budget is only slightly more than MC4A at $4.8B.  Further differences are Eisenhower's reducing military spending by 20%, (which neither have S or W have advocated), the Lavender Scare, where gays, and lesbians were denied government service, his tacit agreement with McCarthyism, his supporting non-Democratic strong men in Latin America (to say nothing of ousting Mossadegh), and the Eisenhower Doctrine of US military intervention for any nation invaded in the Middle East, would likely resemble either of their administrations.  At least I really, really hope not.  That Democrats must unite should be a given, on this we agree, but shamefully not all in the big tent party are willing to let go of their sacred cows to do so.
