I say this as a former Republican, born and raised in Steve King's district in Iowa.

It doesn't matter what Democrats do. White people constitute 67% of the electorate.  White people preferred Trump over Hillary Clinton in 2016 by 20% and will so again no matter who the Democrats nominate. I think Trump's share may even increase.

His message of bigotry and racial division resonates with white voters who believe this country is theirs...no matter how diverse it may be.

Minorities will once again step up and strongly support the Democratic nominee but it won't matter. Wisconsin and Michigan will definitely go for Trump again and Pennsylvania likely so. He will probably pick up Minnesota as well and maybe New Hampshire.

Democrats will pick up no new states.

The situation is very sad indeed.

I will certainly vote for whomever the nominee is, but "do everything I can"? No, that requires passion for the candidate, not just fear and loathing of Trump. Going the extra mile for a candidate requires that the candidate offer something important to me and I believe s/he will fight for it. I am done with smooth-talking "inspirational" candidates and incremental band-aid policies. I want a straight-talking fighter who understands that the system is broken and the deck is stacked. I'm in the "Go big or go home" frame of mind.

"As of December 2019, Gallup polling found that 28% of Americans identified as Democrat, 28% identified as Republican, and 41% as Independent."

Even if every single Democrat voted for the the D nominee, it wouldn't be enough to swing the election away from Trump. The question to ask is how to get all of those people who aren't registered R or D to vote the way you want them to, because they're the majority. Those votes have to be won. Assuming they'll fall in and vote with a party that they've consciously and deliberately avoided joining is not wise.

This electoral system is so slow that by the time I get a voice in it out here in Oregon, the democrats will only be down to a trickle of candidates. Frankly, I don't care which one of them wins, I'll vote to oust Trump. Then again, I rarely vote FOR anyone. Instead, I tend to vote AGAINST people. I voted against Reagan, against Bush, against Clinton's second term with a vote for Nader, against Bush - both times, and Obama was the only one I voted FOR. I cast a vote for Hilary Clinton against Trump, but I wasn't all that thrilled about her. So, this time, I'll just vote for whoever the Democrats nominate so I can vote against Trump.

ANY of the Democratic candidates are going to be better than The Occupant.  All of them would surround themselves with fine people.  Fight for who you want to be the nominee.  Then back the eventual candidate 100%.  Our future depends on ridding ourselves of Trump and his minions.  

I think all the Democratic candidates would say the exact same thing.

This is the question that moderators should have asked candidates at the debates. Announce now if you will support any of those standing next to them, or other Democratic candidates. It should be asked of every candidate repeatedly. I'm not a moderate, but an iconoclast. My concern is over electability. I think Sanders is shallow, but I will absolutely vote for him in the general.

Those who understand the damage to our institutions, the danger to the world, and the cruelty that Trump has caused must all agree. Vote for the Democrat nominee. Fight for the nomination, but don't hold grudges. Those who claim the DNC is biased espouse a Russian/GOP talking point. Those who claim Sanders will create a Venezuela in the US are mouthing the same.

I would say, however, that it's time Bernie joined the Democrat party. Otherwise he leaves a giant loophole for Democrats who don't like him to not support him in the general. Unlike Republicans, many Democrats won't follow someone whose willing to destroy their party.

Please don't label Mayor Pete as leftist, centrist, right leaning etc. He is a pragmatist and wants to get the work done for the betterment of ALL Americans. He doesn't fit any of the standard labels that you in media like to give.
It's early yet  Unity is important. The goal is to get Trump out of office.  And get out the Democratic vote in the swing states.

Thank you for this brilliantly written article  . Any one of those standing on the stage at the last debate or the ones still in the race but not on the  stage would be light years better than what we have in Trump. 
      I think we all just want to nominate the candidate that will beat Trump , but the one that will beat Trump is the one that all Democrats, progressive and moderates , RALLY AROUND . 
    I was very happy to hear Sanders state unequivocally that if he is not the nominee he and everyone else must rally behind the candidate to beat Trump . Buttigieg said that too . 
    Sanders’ supporters are very loyal so if he does not win , we will need him to enthusiastically support the eventual nominee . 
      We’re all getting nervous but you’re right . We need to calm down . Let’s see what happens in Super Tuesday . That will be a big test .

I can’t explain the feeling that I’ve had since the acquittal except that I’m thinking about voting Republican for the first time in my life.

And in doing so, I’d vote for (or write in) anyone except the Great Pumpkin. Note that I am not a registered Republican, but it just seems to make sense to siphon off at least one vote.

There are still a lot of Democrats in the race, and I will vote Democrat in the General, but could someone please point out the foreign policy stance of any of them? We’re going to need one, and it’s going to have to be a good one.

"If your preferred candidate doesn’t win the nomination, will you still do everything you can to deny Trump a second term?"

Absolutely, from being a campaign volunteer to pointing out every contrarian act made by Trump and how each one has negatively impacted the very people he promised to help.

Good evening.  I respect the author and many of your points of view.  However, I am over 60.  I was in Civics class the last time we had a President like the one we have now.  Trust me, who the Democrats nominate is much more important.  If not, please go back and review what the country did to a candidate with socialist views.  McGovern did not win even his home state and was trounced.  I believe he won 3 electoral college votes.  

I hate Donald Trump just as much as most Democrats do, but I am not voting for a revolution and I do not think America will also.  So if you are worried about all that is being discussed, vote AMY!!

The Democrats are going to need every vote they can get to defeat Trump. A desire for ideological purity in a nominee will only guarantee a lost election. The Democrats have to put all differences behind them and erect the biggest tent they can. It's essential that they garner every Democratic vote and as many Independent voters as possible. To avoid another loss they have to be as inclusive as possible without abandoning their core principles. Alienating a group of voters by calling them deplorables or making any derogatory comments of that nature should be beyond the pale. It may well have cost the Democrats the 2016 election.  The Democrats should be the party that loves and wants to help everybody.

I think this is overblown. I really can’t see many Democrats refusing to help vote out Trump if their preferred candidate doesn’t win the nomination. I’m far more concerned about Trump cheating and/or refusing to accept the result.

At this point, as a life time Democrat in my sixties, I would gladly vote for G.W. Bush with enthusiasm if he were the only option available against Trump.
Thank heavens I won't have to make that choice.
But if I'd vote for a Bush to restore a vestige of normalcy to the country, would I personally vote for any candidate with a "D" next to their name.
You can bet on it! I hope I'm not just speaking for myself.

I know this question is convulsing pundits who fear Democrats turning on each other, but they must be patient and let voters vote.  It is like asking sports fans early in the season if they will back the champion when their own team falls short, even though they have every reason to believe it will be their team that wins the championship.  

As long as the Democratic National Committee doesn't panic and engage in anti-democratic, clear-the-decks behavior, most candidates' supporters will end up backing the nominee.  But now, before a single state primary has been held, it is too soon to ask.

Thank you for this.  I will use it as my mantra while I listen to soothing ocean sounds after this week of political turmoil.  And when I find myself nitpicking at one candidate or the other,  I remind myself that Chauncey Gardner would be better than who we have now.  And for those of you who have never seen "Being There" - check it out.  It was prescient!

Here is my suggestion: candidates, seek peace and cooperation at the earliest possible moment. DON'T make the mistake the Republicans did against Trump and allow one candidate to pick off all the others, one by one.

A good time for a summit meeting would likely be after Super Tuesday, March 3rd, when a wide swath of the country will vote and make their choice known. A meeting of candidates would be almost unprecedented in American history but then we are facing a choice, and danger, that is, in fact, unprecedented as well.

Of what should this meeting consist? True patriots should gather to cut short the rest of the nominating process. Someone will likely have a big lead at that point and it might be a good idea for all but one other candidate to quit, or perhaps all of them. Of course, this would be very, very difficult given the time, dedication and campaign contributions needed just to be competitive but, unlike the Republicans in the Senate, the Democrats need to put the country first, their political ambitions second.

If this were to happen, spring and summer of 2020 could be a time of healing and gathering support for the likely winner of the nomination. If the delegate count were still close, the two remaining could fight it out.

This is the question all Democrats or Republicans ask themselves every election. Usually the answer is yes. My preferred candidate didn't get nominated from 1976 through 2016, but I think I'm like most of us in that I vote for the nominee. Though, if I'm in a very red or blue state, I feel free to cast a protest vote.

I complain fiercely about candidates I fear might take the nomination and but fail to beat Trump, but my most deeply held belief is that this planet cannot withstand four more years of Trump's environmental policies. It's the only planet we have. Vote Blue No Matter Who!

I will vote for any Democratic party Presidential nominee who is a registered Democrat and supports other democrats in this and past elections.

That would exclude Bernie Sanders.

Not everyone is capable of casting a hold your nose vote. The problem is particularly acute since the two candidates with the best general election chances aren't really Democrats, even if they make some of the right noises. None of the current field can generate enthusiasm across more than half of the spectrum of likely Democratic voters. This is a problem equal to the disadvantage the electoral college saddled Democrats with.

I have gone from the decided column to the undecided, but without question I would vote for any of the individuals running for the Democratic nomination.  I think though, to have the best chance of pulling everyone in, and since the ticket has two people on it, not just one, the VP nominee should reflect the other side of the party, whether that is progressive or moderate.  The fact that they could agree to be on the ticket together would say a lot about how much we all share in common.
My concern is that having Bernie And The Crew become the face of the Democratic party will result in the loss of the presidency, the Senate, and the House to Trump.

Thank you so much for this piece. These things cannot be said enough. Your vote is a precious and awesome right and responsibility, not to be thrown away in a fit of pique. I teach citizenship classes to immigrants studying to become citizens. When asked why they want to become citizens, the number one answer is "to vote". Most of them come from places in the world where they are denied a vote or an honest election and they are anxious to be part of democracy in action.

Remember what is at stake. It's not just the presidency. It's the attorney general, the secretary of state and state department, the cabinet, the heads of our agencies, our international relations, the earth itself. Any one of these bright and capable candidates will be better than the current administration. A decision to stay home and pout about your candidate is a vote for Trump.

The awful thing is that you need to write this column.  Bernie Sanders has stated publicly that he will support the nominee, no matter who it is.  Elizabeth Warren is working to reduce gaps between herself and other candidates.  Amy Klobuchar stays her moderate course but reframes a lot of it in progressive terms.  Tom Steyer deserved mention in your column as the only candidate on state who basically took your position just about every time he opened his mouth.  I'd love Yang, Buttigieg, and Biden to join the chorus and hope they do.
Absolutely NO question. The only people are worried about are Sanders supporters. in 2016, enough of them voted for Trump to give him victory and I am concerned that that will happen again.

Democratic candidates are just competing for who gets to lose to Trump. His base is fired up since the impeachment hearings, and independents think he is basically running the country ok.  His Gallup approval rating just hit the highest level ever, at 49%. 

As for the Democrats, the Bernie bros will stay home in protest if the Democrats select a moderate (as they resent the DNC's finger on the scale against Bernie). And the moderates will not vote for the old communist, Bernie, if somehow he slips through the DNC controls. So turnout will be a problem either way.

Where does that leave us? Hillary 2024!

You bet I will. It is all I can do to fight this monster--vote. Although I do not believe in the integrity of our election process, I will still go through the motions. Any of the Democratic candidates will defend the U.S. Constitution. The best will make unifying and healing the country a priority. We have to fight this erosion, from within and from without. We are living in a very frightening time. This is not why my father fought in World War 2--to lose it all for the likes of Trump and Putin.

Every citizen should vote, regardless of party or who the nominee is. This election will include candidates other than for President who will also make a difference in our lives. As a country, we should be ashamed that turnout is so low relative to other countries. And, if turnout is high, the Democratic candidate for President will most probably win.

Sanders voters want to radically change the country, much like the Trump voters. I am afraid that they will not vote for a centrist who pledges to maintain the status quo. 
The real problem is that too many people are unhappy with the current situation and demand to change everything. Their demands may be opposite but their rage has a common cause.

Everybody is so wired up about not selecting an unwinnable candidate in the Democratic primary, that they forget that unity in the party combined with a big turnout will inevitably defeat Trump.

Thank you for every article that attempts to highlight Democratic candidates' similarities and not differences!

With any luck the current GOP will wither away with Trump's departure into a negligible fringe party and the Democratic party will split in two with a new breakaway Progressive party become the second major party.

It's rather simple for me: 

Any democratic presidential candidate who places himself/herself above the party and, more importantly, jeopardizes the chances of the party to defeat Mr. Trump will pretty much get no donations from me forever.

"If your preferred candidate doesn’t win the nomination, will you still do everything you can to deny Trump a second term?"

Yes, absolutely. Even if Sanders is the nominee.
As long as the DNC doesn’t put its heavy finger on the scales to fix the results, I’ll be happy to vote for any Democratic nominee.

To answer your question Mr. Leonhardt, the answer is yes. My daughter and I (along with many other residents) spent several hours yesterday knocking on doors making sure that voters in our area were aware of upcoming state and local elections, that they were registered to vote and had a plan to vote on election day.  We will be participating in other get out the vote drives in the coming months. I  urge Democratic voters across the nation to do the same. Democracy is not a spectator sport.

Thank you for this article. But from what I read not sure this will change the minds of those who are steadfast in their beliefs that they won't vote for a Democratic nominee if it's not the one they wanted.

For all those, sure, go ahead and enjoy 4 more years of Trump and Mitch. While you are at it don't forget to support the Republican US Rep as well just because you may not have your candidate at the top of the ticket. RBJ is just hanging on until November but I don't think she will be able to put up 4 more years. So this will be a great opportunity to nominate one more young, far to the right Supreme Court Justice.

What matters is not the person with whom people would be most comfortable but the person who would motivate them to vote. Turnout is more of a problem for Democrats than third party votes. Polls showed the public preferred Clinton but Trump’s voters turned out in the right places and hers did not.Who among the moderates inspires enthusiasm?

I've voted for Democrats my whole life, from Bill Clinton in his first term through to HRC's disastrous run in 2016. I was deeply troubled by Bill's nomination to head the party, a decision that has remained with us to this day unfortunately. Bill headed up a wing of the party that conceded so much more to the republicans than it gained for progressive causes, that if you weren't looking closely, you'd swear he was a republican himself. This trend, which Obama threatened to challenge but eventually went along with, is very troublesome to progressives. And even now, we are to be denied a meaningful vision for change since it's time for us to "put up or shut up" just long enough to kick Trump out of the white house. I will do it, too. I will vote for whoever gets the nod, although I hope it's Sanders. But I think that the Democratic party has some serious soul searching to do. It has lacked vision for so long and so consistently that we've wound up with Trump, a real (lack of) accomplishment. And now that we've got him, we're told that THIS is "no time" for bold vision too? Isn't that what got us here in the first place?

In one of his serious moments, W.C Fields said "I never vote for; I always vote against."   Make this one fundamental decision and  the angst goes away.  If you can't do this, get ready for a great stock market in a world of suffering and misery.  You'll be spending that big 401-k on personal security.  

Bloomberg has decided his legacy will be to spend whatever it takes to remove Trump and it will be fitting if Trump loses because he got outspent.

Of course I'll vote for the nominee, whoever that is. Those announcing in advance their intention to throw a temper tantrum and stay home if they don't get their way should be ashamed of themselves.

Things definitely aren't off to a good start - but I've decided not to pay much attention to the opinions of a few thousand Iowans who didn't have anything else to do for several hours on a Monday night (and who apparently can't add columns of numbers). I have serious doubts about the nationwide viability of several of the candidates, but whoever ends up on the ballot will have my vote.

After listening to The Choice podcast from the NYT's editorial board, I was struck by the intelligence and sheer capability of every single candidate. I could see just about any one of them in the Oval Office, doing a much better job than Mr. Trump. We're not in this mess because we don't have a good candidate, we actually have *too many* good candidates. No matter which way things shake out, the nominee is going to be about a hundred times smarter and more capable than Trump. There's absolutely no reason for Democrats to despair. We shouldn't be complacent, but we also shouldn't be mourning prematurely.

The answer to the question is not necessarily difficult, however, at the same time, those that wish to ignore recent history do so at their peril.  From 2010 to 2018, corporate/establishment "centrist, moderate" democrats,  
i. e. "Republican Lites" lost almost 1000 seats at the state and federal levels including ALL THREE branches of the Executive.  Veteran incumbent senate democrats believing in order to win, they should be more like Republicans(Claire Mccaskill and Joe Donnelly) lost their seats.  ALL sitting so-called "conservative Blue Dog" democrats lost their seats in 2010.   In 2016, Hillary Clinton lost to the candidate who had the worst approval rating in history.

For those that claim the same type of corporate/establishment centrist moderate candidate should be the nominee, once again, fails to comprehend why Donald Trump got elected in the first place and even, if by chance, this type of "status quo' democrat would be elected, there would be little if anything done to start seriously dealing with the issues that ultimately led to Trump's election and another one like him emerging in 2024, but this time he/she would be considerably smarter.

Democrats must have a candidate that offers a CLEAR alternative to Trump and his "Trumpublicans".  Those candidates are NOT Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar and certainly not Michael Bloomberg who, in reality, is just one Oligarch replacing another.
This is such a timely article. The Bernie or bust wing of the party will again deliver trump a victory. The best hope we have is Bloomberg who may attract independents and unhappy republicans.

The most important thing a democrat can do, if he or she lives in a state where an incumbent Republican Senator is up for re-election, eg. Arizona, Colorado, etc.is to contribute to the Democratic challenger in any way they can. If the Democrats can't win the senate Mitch's brow will remain furrowed, all significant new legislation will likely be blocked, and a Democratic  
President will likely suffer some of the same indignities that Obama endured in the last years of his Presidency. A Democratic President might well need Chuck Schumer to install a Merrick Garland in the Supreme Court. Long after Trump turns to dust we will have to endure the legacy of Trumps judicial appointments. The judicial ship needs to be lefted ASAP.

A vote for Trump is a vote for the establishment of one-party rule in this country; not on January 20th of next year, but VERY soon.

That is what's happened to basically all democratic systems that have become this polarized, and we're kidding ourselves if we think it won't happen here. 

There really is no choice but to support the Democratic nominee, and the same goes for Democrats down ballot. We don't have reasonable assurance that Republican will completely respect the rule of law at any level of government if they are faced with electoral defeat. 

Yes, this is how bad its gotten.

I think unity through Bloomberg is what the Democrats need to try to win the presidency, save the House and take the Senate. I don't think Dems fully understand what they are up against. Trump got 63 million votes the last time. He has about 70 million followers mainlining him through Twitter every day. What Trump turnout tsunami that generates is still unknown. But Democrats and Democratic leaning independents, and whatever Republicans are not in the Trump cult have to be smart about their positions and turn out come what may to beat Trump. Nominating Bernie would be an egregious self inflicted wound that woud yield a landslide loss, as well as a loss of the House, with many state and local candidates avoiding being in the stage with Bernie.

I find the argument that because I am a democrat, I should be expected to pledge my vote to a candidate I dont even yet. The article is a good one, and the thoughts will be played out after the next months of primaries. Many progressives will not back a sellout more of the same moderate, or what used to be called a conservative democrat (like Bill Clinton). Many of those in the middle will stay home if one of the far left progressives get the nomination, versus casting a vote for Trump. The same is probably true for a measurable portion of the GOP who are waiting to see  if the Dems nominate someone in the middle that they may be able to secretly vote for, or if it will be someone like Sanders or Warren that they really cant even consider.   

At least everyone knows Trump and what he is about, and that he stands a very real chance of being elected. I have been listening to my leftist friends say for a couple years how Trump was going to get pounced in 2020. Very sure of themselves that his policies were driving away people in droves. Mostly they only talk to people like themselves and are in disbelief how anyone can support the devil himself.  

Hillary was middle of the road and won the votes, just not in all the right places.

Of course I'm going to give my all to whoever wins the Democratic nomination. I honestly don't care who it is. I like Sanders, but would work for Bloomberg or Steyer, too. The most important thing in the world right now (and I do mean the world) is to get rid of Trump. Even if we can't reclaim the Senate, at least getting rid of him would put a brake on this slide toward fascism, with Trump at the helm and a supine Senate in his wake. I'm serious, because most of us alive now have never lived in an autocratic society, but I hear it isn't a picnic. In fact, I'm deeply frightened that we will go there if Trump is elected again. (Some would say we are there already, but I would say it is not complete just yet.)

The policies of Warren or Sanders, without flipping the Senate, won't get anywhere. They will have to rely on Executive Orders, which don't last past the next president, if they are not of the same party. I don't think Warren or Sander's policies would do more than issue a corrective to the vast inequality we have allowed to happen here.  Nobody needs to worry about a "revolution" (Bernie's words) because at worst he would bring us back to the New Deal, which brought us a strong middle class. It's not about socialism or communism, it's about thinking of the US as a community you would like to have go well.

There is wise counsel in your words and the commentary is equally impressive. I carefully follow our system of government by the people and believe that we have a system that permits elected leaders at all levels of government, Federal, State, and local to respond to both immediate and long-term local, national, and international economic, social, and cultural problems that arise from time to time.  

You have addressed Democrats but I believe our system must essentially ignore definitions of right, left, center as we approach the future, but we must insist that the government created by the 2020 Election campaign use this campaign to define the problems, and educate voters on how we as members of society can come together, where appropriate, and solve problems with our collective effort.

No one knows why good people are divided by politics and religion, probably because we had difficulty in getting the basic fundamentals correct on how to create a fair and just society for all our members, think slavery and native Americans, and women's equality.  Thanks to our system, we are moving toward a fair, just and inclusive society that will survive by taking advantage of the environmental, social, economic and technical changes which drive our quality life and life expectancy.

Many of my conservative G.O.P. friends are unhappy with the President's behavior and the government's failure to check it and look forward to voting in a new government that will allow all to flourish.

The Dave Clark Five sang a song back in the 1960s which had a third verse that goes like this:

They got a little place a-down the track
The name of the place is I like it like that
You take Sally and I'll take Sue
And we're gonna rock away all of our blues

The line about Sally and Sue was later rhymed by Jackson Browne with "ain't no difference between the two" and the line is also featured in other songs.

Yes the blue team needs to make a selection before they go to the big dance.  No, he or she will not be the first choice of many.  But what binds the blue team together has to prove stronger than the hate and divisiveness spewed by Trump.  

Yes Democrats, keep your integrity.   But also learn to adapt and to unify.  Let truth be your guide.

I have watched the Democrats (Clintons) and the DLC deliver
large swaths of this country  into third world conditions,by anybodys metric. All you people have to understand the economic conditions that Bernie saw happening decades
ago have come into fruition. That's why the working class is
so staunchly behind him. He stands with us. Don't tell me to
get in line and vote for a nominee that the corporate wing of the party wants. I'm over just taking it. They have to offer
something to us. We are seriously struggling here. Also

tepid critique of moderate Dems is pitiful. They could do
a little better on the economy huh? Not as long as their

Thank you, Mr. Leonhardt.  Count me as someone who will work for and vote for whomever the Democrats nominate.  I live in Maryland, so I don't get to weigh in officially until April 28 by which time many or most of the candidates will have dropped out, so I have ignored the straw polls that arrive several times daily.  My hope is that all of the candidates will make a similar commitment to work for the eventual nominee no matter who that is.  I understand the frustration of people who want to support and ultimately elect a third party candidate.  However, right now, the only imperative is to defeat Trump, so in November, there are two (2) choices: Trump or the Democratic nominee. If you don't want Trump, you must vote for the Democrat.  I will never forgive Sanders, who lost the nomination and then went home to sulk instead of actively campaigning for Clinton and telling his supporters to vote for her.  Many of them voted for Trump instead.  Are they happy with the result? Mind you, if Sanders is the candidate, I will work hard to elect him.  As a nation, we cannot tolerate four more years like the past three.

Thanks for this eminently sensible article. As Ben Franklin said, "We must all hang together, or, most assuredly, we shall all hang separately." 

Trump is in the process of executing our democracy. We have to unite against him.

Vote blue, no matter who.

No.

This is the struggle of the establishment to keep things as they are, just when we could finally win real change.

Renegade Republicans and the right wings of the Democratic Party cannot use the threat of Trump to force on me a Republican Lite.

Furthermore, many of those asking this have themselves said they would only vote for a Republican Lite, not Sanders or Warren.

This is a con, a misdirection, an attempt to get by us a bad choice at the very moment when we could finally get to a good choice.

Democrats should have no problem answering the question.  As a Democrat, of course I will support the party nominee and do whatever I can to make sure that s/he is elected in November.  The rallying cry is "Blue no matter who."  There are, however, groupies who support a candidate and may well sit on their hands if that candidate doesn't get the nomination.  They aren't actually Democrats but cult followers.

For a GOP intent on dismantling regulation and enriching the powerful, there is, presently and effectively, no one steering this ship. Not even if you count our enraged captain, drunk with a treacly dose of self-love chased by a copious dose of self-pity. 

So many GOP voters don't seem to mind the reduction of government in ways that have no real concerted plan going forward. Cases in point are the abortive effort to repeal the A.C.A. or the sudden pull-out from Syria in late 2019 Any reduction of government at all with zero planning and near-zero professional consultation is not good policy if it is stupidly executed. 

Thank-you Mr Leohardt for clarifying:  
"The substantive part of many policy debates now happens within the Democratic Party â€” which means that tensions are only natural."

If the GOP has lost its soul, it has not forgotten the most powerful edict of politics: Unity and party loyalty. Democrats would do well to remember this. 

In competitive games where one or more factions of a party cooperate in unison or defect against the party line, the optimal strategy is always complete cooperation among all possible strategic choices of the factions. Republicans often understand this concept much better than their Democratic colleagues, it seems. It is simple, requires significant inspiring leadership and not a small amount of compromise.
Bloomberg is a Republican, so I certainly hope he doesn't get the democratic nomination. Otherwise, yes.
I agree. You can sum it up in a single sentence: Don't let the perfect be the enemy of the good.

Democrats were able to win the House in 2018 because they got a lot of support from Moderates in largely suburban areas. Will those suburban voters support someone like A Sanders. There is no disguising that Sanders is a Socialist that he wants to dramatically increase taxes . Do away with Private Health Insurance spend hundreds of billions on a Green New Deal . Ban Fracking which will cost millions of jobs and make the US dependent on foreign oil. And he wants to tax Wall Street for those people who have worked hard and invested wisely to insure that they have an adequate retirement  this would be an absolute disaster. This is not some minor policy difference these are very fundamental differences between two vastly different views of how this country works. Sorry I didn't vote for Trump last time but if you give me Sanders I will this time .

With one possible exception, I am confident that the supporters of all the democratic candidates will get behind the eventual nominee. I am confident that any democrat will carry the congressional districts of The Squad: AOC, Omar, Pressley and Tlaib,who won their races with 78%, 78%, 59% and 85% respectively.

I feel like I have to be apologetic about any enthusiasm about left of center solutions to our problems. I feel like I'm being told that I have to accept some amount of corporate control over my life and future. This is all because of fear. expand health insurance (private sector OR government)

I know a lot about what Warren stands for simply because she's come out with plan after plan, both in her televised town halls and on her website elizabethwarren.com. The plans seem to be the simplicity you only get to when you understand the depth of the issues you explore and so I've gotten absorbed into reading them through. I haven't heard anything that impressive from the other candidates but then, I have to admit, reading up on Warren, I haven't taken time to read up on the others.

When I see Buttigieg or Klobuchar praised, the comments are about how they stood out in the last debate. the groups of voters they attract and other such impressions they give out. But if I'm to choose, I want to know how their plans stack up against the details provided by Warren; how are they different in scope, in methods, in feasibility. It would be a terrific public service for the Times to start filling in a grid on the policy differences between the major candidates. I know the debates strive for that, but the TV format doesn't lend itself to details. Just looking at those neon colors of red/white/blue makes me think I turned on the Oscar channel by mistake.

No, and here's why. To make such a decision I presume myself to be an expert in divining how other voters view candidate "electability". I have no skills at making such a determination. To try is a mug's game. Better I should try to win other voters over to my favorite candidate.

Pap.  The issue before us is that neither Warren nor Sanders will appeal to a range of voters -- Democrats and moderate Republicans.  Biden, Klobuchar, and Bloomberg will.  It is appropriate to oppose Warren and Sanders now so that we will not have to deal with Leonhardt's question.

If Sanders does not get the nomination it is very possible that a significant would stay home or vote for Trump: https://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2019/03/07/the_rise_of_the_trump-sanders_voter_139674.html . What I find really unnerving is that the media goes long with the myth of the economy being great. It is the economy that matters MOST to voters, their OWN economy NOT GDP etc.  The macroeconomic metrics are just that. A person working two-three-four jobs to make end meet should not be counted as 2-3-4 jobs, it should actually be counted as 'less than one worker'. More money being spent on healthcare should not be a positive on the economy. Only that spending which is pleasureful should be counted as 'consumption' in the positive sense for measuring the condition of the economy. Money spent by the government on the military should not be a positive either.

As an Independent disgusted with Mr. Trump, I share the concern about the Democrats infighting.  Here in Texas, we are hearing a lot from Mr. Bloomberg, who comes across as outside the infighting. The problems are multifold. Firstly, between gerrymandering and the electoral college, it’s always advantage Republicans. Secondly, money in politics has allowed billionaires to buy politicians with dark money who then are beholden and have to rubber stamp whatever it is the lobbyists place before them. Then there’s the media that is rife with propaganda. We’ve experienced decades of fake news masquerading as “fair and balanced” to promote a culture of distrust, hegemony, and warfare. Then there’s enough of a population supporting a sort of “benevolent plutocracy” because they have been indoctrinated to believe that in the end they are better off for it. This is the world the Democrats have had to negotiate for the better part of 40 years, at least. As a result, they’ve been forced to fight a battle under their opponents rules and resultantly deciding between compromising their principles to be effective and doing the right thing. Its a tough situation to be in and, in the greater sense, a really, really frightening place for the current state of democracy.

I experience helpful wisdom in the perspective offered in David Leonhardt's opinion here. Hopefully this can heard and applied: "Take a deep breath, and don’t make your job harder. Neither side of the party can ensure that its preferred candidate will win the nomination. But both can help avoid the outcome they fear most — Trump’s re-election." 

We need this point of view to counter those from James Carville's and Hillary Clinton's recent misguided divisive interviews  wherein they seemed quite forgetful of their own miscalculations that did little to help the nation avoid President Trump. 

IMHO the DNC leadership needs to trust the people and the process. The Clinton/Wasserman manipulative debacle during the last primary cycle misjudged the tenor of the electorate and did not serve the American people.

Too many Democrats on the left identify centrists as the equivalent of Republicans.  They would rather have a Republican in office that will ultimately fail and will bring on the revolution they so desire than vote for a centrist Democrat that will put the kabash on any potential revolutionary change.

The question all Democrats need to ask themselves: why is everything you're doing, guaranteeing Trump's re-election?  He has already won 2020.  The GOP will win again in 2024.  That should give the DNC sufficient time to go though a Chapter 11 restructuring (if it doesn't go into Chapter 7 liquidation), as it is bankrupt in the most vital currency: ideas--and credibility.

If the Democrats are going to win in 2020, they need to be flexible in their choice of a candidate and inflexible in regard to voting for the eventual nominee. Requiring total ideological compatibility in order to back the Democratic nominee will be self-defeating. In order to win, the Democratic nominee will have to appeal to a broad segment of Independent voters as well as any Republicans who may have feelings of apprehension about a second term for Trump. (There may be a handful.) The candidate who obtains the most primary votes, may as a practical matter not be the person who has the best chance of defeating Trump. If winning is the ultimate goal, identifying and nominating the Democrat with the most appeal to the whole electorate should be the objective.

Mr. Leonhardt assumes that, in the end, there will be a clear path toward the defeat of Trump.  But what if there is a brokered convention?  What if a strong third party candidate emerges?  What if Sanders or some other candidate has a serious health problem? Saying you'll do what it takes is meaningless when it isn't clear what it takes. And, indeed it isn't clear. So let's move on to something that means something.
I vote for who I think will be best for people like me, not a party.

This idea is increasingly being floated : " People who are fed up with the status quo in general are as likely to support Bernie as they are to support Trump. They just want to start with disruption on the way to reinvention." Really ?! After watching what we have watched over the past 3 years and now the past 3 weeks ? I have sent $ to Biden but am less and less confident. I've received 4 mailings, 2  texts, an e-mail and seen 2 commercials from the Bloomberg campaign. They are working very hard and I'm interested in hearing more. I don't care if he is a billionaire. I care about policy ideas, brains, having a conscience , being an adult and having control of one's temper. Both Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar are smart, hard working, very competent. I don't think that they can win though. But please not Bernie Sanders. I have never wanted to vote for him and do not want to now. And , anyway, he'd lose.

In a recent opinion piece a commenter hopes for a progressive/moderate ticket as a way to unite the party.  I'm all for that.

Right now I support whoever the nominee turns out to be, but I think I understand the Bernie supporters - our institutions are failing and it seems human nature to want to believe in something, to hope for something.  Especially younger generations, when there's so much wrong right now.  But for me, who has canvassed for and supported Russ Feingold, Gore, Kerry (and others) - I can't tell you how easy it is to lose faith in the process when the other side lies. Doesn't seem to matter how good the candidate is, we just really need to be united and fight to get our country back.

What I want to hear is why the Bros — 53% of whom say they may not support the Democratic candidate if it’s not Bernie — seem so unwilling to compromise. I will support him even though he may be the riskiest candidate. I just voted by mail for Mike because I think he has the best chance of winning, yet I will not abdicate my responsibility to back the candidate of a party to which I do not belong but whose candidates I generally support. Please write a column that explores the intransigence in greater depth so we can get on with the difficult business at hand.

Right on the money, David. I'd be proud to have Bernie, Joe, Liz, or Pete as my next President, but I agree with you on two things. First, above all, we must defeat Trump. Second, the left and center left have much in common, e.g., on abortion, the environment, and lowering health and education costs. 

That said, your use of the terms "civil rights" and "progressive" left much unclear. If I favor "civil rights," must I support "affirmative action," i.e., racial, ethnic, and gender preferences, i.e., discrimination, in employment decisions and college admissions? Does "progress" mean each of us striving never to discriminate against "any person" based on race, ethnicity, or gender (as the 14th Amendment and civil rights laws expressly command)? Or is "progress" just making sure that we discriminate against individuals of the CORRECT races, ethnicities, and gender?   

I hope and pray for a Democratic President and both Houses of Congress by 2021. But the left wing of the Democrats should recognize that for true liberals, it is the individual person, and not only members of select races, ethnicities, and one gender, that is fully, expressly, and properly protected by the 14th Amendment and civil rights laws. If they don't get that, they can't be surprised that so many people in red and purple states are so put off by the left generally that they stay home on election day or vote for Trump.

Absolutely I would, as will all passionate Ds. No candidate accomplishes anything close to what he/she campaigns on esp if not from incumbent's party. If Sanders or any D is elected, its predictable that McConnell will lead Rs soaring to new heights of obstructionism.

I support Elizabeth Warren as the best possible candidate for the presidency.   But I will vote for whichever candidate who wins the Democratic Party nomination.  I may find some of the candidates as too right or too left, I will take a Democrat any day of the week.

Leonhardt's sensible piece omits discussing particular challenges for Democrats.  If they had a powerful candidate, one whose appeal could pull together the disparate sides, unity would be easier to achieve.  So far, there is no candidate around whom they can rally.  There is also the convention with potential for charges of favoritism if superdelegates come into play, which seems likely to happen, dampening enthusiasm, creating resentment.  There's the Bloomberg factor.  Whatever his outcome, he's already creating resentment for his late entry with lots of money, resentment that is likely to grow as his prominence grows and established candidates pushed aside.  Managing their feelings is going to be a test for Democrats in order for them to work together.

Yes I will. But that said, I really don't much care which of all these candidates carries the ball. As far as I'm concerned, they should just draw straws rather than waste any more time on debates and primaries. The most important thing to me is that the Democratic Party work out and be crystal clear on its platform: Healthcare, Environment, Citizen Rights and Equality, Income and Taxation, Infrastructure, Jobs, Trade and Foreign Policy, Senate Majority. These debate arguments are over minutia - Explain the big picture. The platform, clearly communicated, is what will get the most people excited to vote Democratic. Any of these candidates can win if they have a clear platform to excite people about. None are any better than the others when it comes to this. I have no interest in personality cults when it comes to government. Get it done.

Yes, I would even vote for Bernie Sanders whose positions I generally disagree with and whom I will certainly vote against in the Maryland primary.  Regardless my differences with him he is no threat to our democracy.  Trump is.

The statement that Congress will restrain whatever a progressive president could do ignores one major exception: foreign policy. In some cases, you can say to let an undesired policy go through as the cost of ousting Trump and work to elect someone to reverse it later.

However, not all policies that a progressive president could enact with no cooperation from Congress could be reversed by a successor. For instance, surrendering Afghanistan to the Taliban cannot be reversed. Security Council resolutions condemning Israel cannot be reversed. Unlike domestic policy which requires affirmative support from Congress, both of those could be done even if both houses pass resolutions in opposition by veto proof margins.

Before voting 3rd party or not voting (in a swing state), please consider the following.
Purpose of elections is to make collective decisions.  As citizen, you owe your country your best judgement in collective decisions it faces.  If your top choice can't win, the country has already made its collective decision as to him/her: that's  what "can't win" means.   You may not like the country's decision, but it's still your country, and you still owe it your best judgement in collective decisions it still faces.   If your ballot does not reflect that judgement, you don't give the country what it needs most.  Giving it something else -- like your view of which already-rejected candidate was best --  does not make up for that.

A C.E.O. faced with a major decision can't "sit it out", opt for a no-longer-viable choice, or let others decide; he'll be fully responsible for the decision's consequences whether he makes it himself or has others make it.   Same holds for a voter.

So often, an argument is constrained by the words used to describe it.

Right, left and center are descriptive artifacts of French politics centuries ago.  They don't really apply today other than as a crutch for the lazy, or as a pejorative weapon.

What is being commonly discussed in this nomination process is what Sen. Sanders espoused four years ago.  The fact that these things are being discussed seriously is a tribute to those ideas.

But much of the strife in the Dem party today rises from the inability of the party to understand why it lost in 2016.  Those who blame Bernie supporters ignore the short deal much of the country has gotten from bipartisan policies for the last 4 decades that helped lead to the backlash. Dems had seemed to shed their mantle of protecting people.  Fixing the outgrowth of those policies should be front and center. 

None of those seeking the nomination are guaranteed, if nominated, to be elected.  And electability is not a feature; Trump was considered un-electable, until he won. Now, there has never been a better reason to work vigorously for anyone  nominated than the conditions we have today.

But this is a marathon.  Things will not be fixed overnight.  No one gives up power willingly.  And it will not be won on a single front.  A Dem president in 2020 with a GOP Senate will continue the status quo, or worse.

Any Dem that is nominated is worth our effort to elect her/him.  Let's get to work.

- Preserve and protect the solvency of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.

- Medicare for all, but allow those who would like to keep their employer insurance to do so, and aggressively tackle health care costs including prescription drugs 

- An Apollo Program like initiative on modernizing our infrastructure, including a huge renewable energy component to make us energy independent and turn us into the leading energy exporter in the world before China or others gain that status.

- Investment in education/job training for the 21st century, including trade apprenticeships.

Obviously that's not every topic, but that's what we can rally around.

In the Trump Inc. Podcast, episode Sept. 18, 2019: The Family Business, there is an interesting interview with Solomon Larte (spelling ?) a records management analyst under four US presidents. He worked in the Office of Presidential Records (OPR). Federal law states that every piece of paper that crosses the president’s desk becomes part of the presidential record. Everything is forwarded to the OPR to be catalogued and filed. Everything proceeded normally until Trump became president. First, OPR found out that official docs were being thrown in the trash. Initially, OPR figured that perhaps T-rump did not know, so he was informed. That’s when Larte began receiving Manila folders of documents that had been ripped into ‘thumb-sized pieces’ by the president before being sent to the OPR. Larte said that the OPR staff were then tasked with painstakingly taping the docs back together, ‘like doing a jigsaw puzzle’. He must have been too good at that, because after 25 years, a top secret clearance, and three other presidents, he was informed that his top secret clearance would not be renewed (you’re gone). No reason given.

The presentation by the House was conclusive and eloquent, despite obstruction by the White House.

But there was no defense.  The lawyers for the President had nothing but blather. No evidence, no witnesses, just the lie that the President did nothing wrong when it was very clear he had.

Yes, we knew it was coming, but the Kafkaesque spectacle was mind blowing in its confirmation of our country’s failure.  

We were seeing a show trial, the hallmark of corrupt dictatorships worldwide, in our United States Senate!

And Chief “Justice” Roberts stood there and let it happen, and smiled and pretended it was justice.

And Republicans stood up one by one and unconvincingly pretended they had a reason to acquit a corrupt President.

And never was our country so completely and utterly betrayed.  

We had a norm of expecting justice.  Sometimes we were disappointed, but we did expect it.  That expectation, at least at the level of our Federal government and the Supreme Court has been shattered.

We the People are still in shock.  We can understand how Iowans found it hard to turnout in great numbers for the caucus.  Some of us could barely make it out our doors for days.  

But we will vote.  By November the shock will have subsided some, but the anger!  The anger will remain.  We will not forget.  We are unable to forget this betrayal.

"Tradition and ethics alone keep them silent"
And there is the problem.  At this point in time I'm not sure I can name more than a handful of senators that I believe still have any ethics.  Rand certainly isn't one of that handful.

Federal law protects whistleblowers from retaliation. 5 U.S. Code sec. 2302(b) provides that it is unlawful to retaliate against a federal employee who discloses unlawful or corrupt practices by government officials. This means that a government employer cannot fire, demote, reduce in pay, or substantially alter the position of an employee who reports corruption or criminal activity or other wrongdoing on the part of federal  officials. There are limitations on this protection -- which would require more space than is available here -- but the key matter of law is that whistleblowers who follow the law are protected by the law. 

That is why I've been mystified by the Democrats' failure to identify the whistleblower and call him or her to testify before the House during impeachment proceedings. Was there something to fear? Probably. It is understandable why a whistleblower would prefer anonymity. But a certain amount of courage is a requirement of transparency. As a life-long Democrat and proponent of impeachment (and conviction) I'm still disturbed that we didn't hear from the whistleblower. As a life-long proponent of due process I will always harbor doubts about the witness we never heard from.

Senator Paul, I believe you may be entitled to a substantial inheritance from an anonymous fan who recently passed away. Since you now demonstrate no adherence to individual rights of privacy and protection under the law, could you please share your Social Security number and bank account number with us to expedite the transfer of  this generous sum of money? 

You may do so either here or on the Senate floor. You should have no hesitation to comply with this request.

In Robert Griffiths' seminal study of McCarthy and the Senate (The Politics of Fear), a drunken bully was allowed to have his way over an institutional body that put retention over duty. Senators watched as constitutional protections were run over by a human steamroller and lives were ruined.

Here we are again, days after Steve Israel wrote a piece here about the same cowardice in the face of Trumpism, 70 years later.

What is more complicating now, is that back then, financial support by the founders of right-wing paranoia such as the Hunts and Murchisons was only beginning. Now government serves the donors. So in addition to fear of putting service over keeping one's job, we have the added incentive of campaign cash, being targetted by negative campaigning and the loss of lucrative post "service" oportunities. Or worse, as in the case of Senator Paul, craziness in the service of extremism. Which the right holds is noble since Goldwater. 

I don't believe term limits is the answer. We should want expertise to stay. What I lament is that we have moved from pluralism to sanctioned big cat bullying in the economy, our government and politics. Reclaiming our democracy is paramount as it was 70 years ago when a brave Boston attorney spoke to a demagogue on national TV stating at long last have you no sense of decency?

Now as then, it won't be coming from an elected official frozen like a deer in the headlights.

On August 7, 2016, the Times reported that, because of  Trump's misconduct:

"you have to throw out the textbook American journalism has been using for the better part of the past half-century, if not longer, and approach it in a way you’ve never approached anything in your career. If you view a Trump presidency as something that’s potentially dangerous, then your reporting is going to reflect that. You would move [closer than you’ve ever been] to being oppositional, which is uncomfortable and uncharted territory and by normal standards, untenable."

The newspaper is saying that there will be "Trump rules" for reporting which will pretty much abandon objectivity in favor of opposition.  In short, the truth will give way to incessant opposition to Trump.

I have quoted this language before, and nobody cares that objectivity is going by the wayside.  As the piece admits, this violates the rules of traditional journalism. And yet no one but me seems to care.  

Today's piece raise the issue again. The media doesn't get to abandon the rules and tell the story it wants to tell. Like Rand Paul, it doesn't get to make up new rules to suit its purposes.  And if you don't object to this, you give free reign to the media to oppose Trump rather than to report his actions objectively.  That's using the tools of editorial writing in place of reporting the news.  You should object to this -- you're paying to be told what happened, not what the media thinks about it.

The purpose of the article is to shed light on some very serious violations to the functioning of a whistle-blower system that is vital to government accountability. But perhaps history has yet to record what happens next...

Dr. Freeman's article is fundamentally irrational.  The "whistleblower" law under which the impeachment whistleblower claims protection contains absolutely no prohibition of anyone other than the Inspector General from identifying the whistleblower publicly.   The law is intended to protect the whistleblower from retaliation (such as adverse job actions) by superiors who are members of the intelligence community.  It is not a blanket prohibition against identification by either members of Congress, or the media itself, nor by anyone else, for that matter.   The public is entitled to know the identity of witnesses, including whistleblowers, who engage in actions intended to result in the impeachment and removal of a sitting President.
